column1: Apple Inc v International Trade Com'n
name_numbers: ["Apple Inc. v. International Trade Com'n, 725 F.3d 1356 (2013)"]
author: [' Moore, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Moore, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1]  substantial  evidence  supported  ITC's  determination  that  disclosure  in  provisional  patent  application  provided
adequate written support for touchscreen-related patent that allegedly anticipated claims of patentee's patent;

[2] anticipation finding, based upon purported incorporation by reference, lacked substantial evidence;

[3]  substantial  evidence  supported  finding  that  prior  art  anticipated  claims  of  patent  disclosing  touch  panel  with
transparent capacitive sensing medium capable of detecting multiple touches at once;

[4]  substantial  evidence  supported  finding  of  no  anticipation  of  patent  claim  disclosing  how  to  make  touchscreen
transparent;

[5] ITC's failure to evaluate secondary considerations evidence before making obviousness determination warranted
vacating obviousness decision;

[6] ITC's failure to evaluate secondary considerations evidence was not harmless error; and

[7] as used in patent disclosing method to determine whether displaced charge at touchscreen nodes corresponded to finger
touching screen, term “mathematically fitting an ellipse” required software to mathematically fit an ellipse to the data.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cApple Inc. v. International Trade Com'n, 725 F.3d 1356 (2013)
35 ITRD 1921, 107 U.S.P.Q.2d 1864

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

Reyna, Circuit Judge, filed a separate opinion concurring in part and dissenting in part.

"]

["

Before MOORE, LINN, and REYNA, Circuit Judges.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

5

column1: Joseph Phelps Vineyards LLC v Fairmont Holdings LLC
name_numbers: ['Joseph Phelps Vineyards, LLC v. Fairmont Holdings, LLC, 857 F.3d 1323 (2017)']
holding:
['s, LLC, 857 F.3d 1323 (2017)
122 U.S.P.Q.2d 1733

857 F.3d 1323

United States Court of Appeals,

Federal Circuit.

JOSEPH PHELPS VINEYARDS, LLC, Appellant

v.

FAIRMONT HOLDINGS, LLC, Appellee

2016-1089

|

Decided: May 24, 2017

Synopsis
Background: Owner of trademark “INSIGNIA” used for wines sought review of decision of Trademark Trial and Appeal
Board (TTAB) denying its petition for cancellation of trademark “ALEC BRADLEY STAR INSIGNIA” used for
cigars.

[Holding:]  The  Court  of  Appeals  held  that  TTAB  applied  incorrect  all-or-nothing  measure  of  whether  trademark
“INSIGNIA” used for wines was famous in reaching conclusion that there was no likelihood of confusion as to source.

Vacated and remanded.

Newman, Circuit Judge, wrote concurring opinion.

']

RICHTER, Richter Trademarks, PL, Wilton Manors, FL.

Before Newman, Dyk, and Wallach, Circuit Judges.

']

column1: Commonwealth Scientific and Indus Research Organisation v Cisco Systems In
name_numbers: ['Commonwealth Scientific and Indus. Research Organisation v...., 809 F.3d 1295 (2015)']
author: [' Prost, Chief']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Prost, Chief Judge, held that:

[1] district court did not violate apportionment principles in employing damages model to value asserted patent by taking
account of parties' informal licensing negotiations with respect to it in multi-component end product;

[2] determination of reasonable royalty for patent infringement damages award had to account for value accruing to
adoption of patent's standard-essential status; and

[3] court had to take license agreement into account in its analysis of damages for infringement.

Vacated and remanded.

"]

column1: Radio Systems Corp v Lalor
name_numbers: ['Radio Systems Corp. v. Lalor, 709 F.3d 1124 (2013)']
author: [' Moore, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Moore, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] manufacturer's products did not infringe competitor's patent;

[2] district court did not abuse its discretion in concluding that equitable estoppel barred patentee's infringement claims
with regard to first patent; and

[3] district court abused its discretion in concluding that equitable estoppel barred patentee's infringement claims with
regard to second patent.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.

Newman, Circuit Judge, concurred in part, dissented in part, and filed opinion.

"]

Whitaker, Whitaker Law Group, of Seattle, WA.

']

column1: GE Lighting Solutions LLC v AgiLight Inc
name_numbers: ['GE Lighting Solutions, LLC v. AgiLight, Inc., 750 F.3d 1304 (2014)']
author: [' Moore, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Moore, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] “insulation displacement connector” (IDC) within meaning of patents for LED string lights was required to be given
meaning commonly used in electrical engineering to connote a range of devices;

[2] “substantially ellipsoidal inner profile” within meaning of patent disclosing an optical element housing a LED did
not require the entire inner profile to be substantially ellipsoidal;

[3] genuine issue of material fact as to whether manufacturer's housing was “substantially ellipsoidal” precluded summary
judgment; and

[4] manufacturer's dome–shaped lens used to protect LED during molding process was not an “annular gasket” within
meaning of patent.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.

Reyna, Circuit Judge, filed opinion concurring in part and dissenting in part.

"]

column1: United Construction Products Inc v Tile Tech Inc
name_numbers: ['United Construction Products, Inc. v. Tile Tech, Inc., 843 F.3d 1363 (2016)']
author: [' Wallach, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Wallach, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] it was within district court's discretion to enter default judgment in favor of patent owner as sanction, and

[2] permanent injunction prohibiting defendant from any and all acts of infringement was not overly broad.

Affirmed.

"]

column1: Rosebud LMS Inc v Adobe Systems Inc
name_numbers: ['Rosebud LMS Inc. v. Adobe Systems Inc., 812 F.3d 1070 (2016)']
author: [' Moore, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Moore, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] as a matter of first impression, the actual notice requirement for pre-issuance damages did not require an affirmative
act by the patent applicant giving notice of published patent application to the alleged infringer;

[2] fact that alleged infringer knew of patentee's grandparent patent did not establish that alleged infringer had actual
notice of the published patent application, for purposes of pre-issuance damages;

[3]  there  was  no  evidence  that  alleged  infringer  had  actual  knowledge  of  patentee's  published  patent  application,  as
required for pre-issuance damages; and

[4] district court acted within its discretion in granting summary judgment before completion of discovery.

Affirmed.

"]
lawyers_judge:
['

']

column1: Norgren Inc v International Trade Com'n
name_numbers: ["Norgren Inc. v. International Trade Com'n, 699 F.3d 1317 (2012)"]
author: [' Linn, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Linn, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] substantial evidence supported finding that patent was obvious;

[2] substantial evidence supported finding that modification of prior art four-sided clamp with hinged side would have
been obvious to person having ordinary skill in the art;

[3] prior art patent that had been directed to water pipes did not teach away from clamp claimed in patent; and

[4] substantial evidence supported finding that secondary considerations did not undercut conclusion that patent was
obvious.

Affirmed.

Moore, Circuit Judge, filed dissenting opinion.

']

column1: UltimatePointer LLC v Nintendo Co Ltd
name_numbers: ['UltimatePointer, L.L.C. v. Nintendo Co., Ltd., 816 F.3d 816 (2016)']
author: [' Lourie, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Lourie, Circuit Judge., held that:

[1] district court properly construed “handheld device”;

[2] accused device was an indirect, not a direct pointing device, and so did not infringe patent; and

[3] apparatus claims were not invalid as indefinite.

Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

']

column1: Allergan Inc v Apotex Inc
name_numbers: ['Allergan, Inc. v. Apotex Inc., 754 F.3d 952 (2014)']
author: [' Prost, Chief']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Prost, Chief Judge, held that:

[1]  district  court  did  not  commit  clear  error  in  determining  that  invention  was  not  anticipated  by  published  patent
application;

[2] district court did not commit clear error in finding that patent disclosing use of bimatoprost to treat glaucoma did
not inherently anticipate patent;

[3] patent for compositions and methods for treating hair loss using non-naturally occurring prostaglandins was invalid
for obviousness;

[4] district court committed clear error in finding corroboration of earlier priority date for claimed invention;

[5] references did not represent inventor's own work, and thus constituted prior art; and

[6] patent for topical application of bimatoprost for use to promote eyelash hair growth was invalid for obviousness.

Reversed and vacated.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cAllergan, Inc. v. Apotex Inc., 754 F.3d 952 (2014)
111 U.S.P.Q.2d 1245

Chen, Circuit Judge, dissented in part and filed opinion.

"]

column1: Pacific Coast Marine Windshields Ltd v Malibu Boats LLC
name_numbers: ['Pacific Coast Marine Windshields Ltd. v. Malibu Boats, LLC, 739 F.3d 694 (2014)']
author: [' Dyk, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Dyk, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] issue of first impression, prosecution history estoppel applies to design patents;

[2] applicant narrowed scope of his original application and surrendered subject matter, as required for prosecution
history estoppel to apply, by removing broad claim language that referred to alternate configurations and canceling
individual figures showing unelected embodiments;

[3] surrender of claim scope in order to secure patent in response to examiner's restriction requirement for not restricting
claim to single inventive design was sufficient for prosecution history estoppel to apply; and

[4] accused design did not fall within scope of surrendered subject matter.

Reversed and remanded.

"]
lawyers_judge:
["

author: [' Dyk, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Dyk, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1]  patent  claiming  methods  of  tracking  and  storing  information  was  directed  to  patent-ineligible  abstract  idea  of
budgeting;

[2] patent generally relating to customizing web page content claimed abstract idea and otherwise did not claim inventive
concept; and

[3] term, “machine readable instruction form,” in patent claiming methods for scanning hard-copy images, required that
machine readable instructions be in hard-copy.

Affirmed.

']

column1: D'Agostino v MasterCard International Incorporated
name_numbers: ["D'Agostino v. MasterCard International Incorporated, 844 F.3d 945 (2016)"]
author: [' Taranto, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Taranto, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] PTAB departed from or misapplied clear meaning of single-merchant limitation in patents, but

[2] substantial evidence supported PTAB's finding that prior art disclosed defining and designating payment category
before transaction code, as claimed by patents.

Vacated and remanded.

"]

column1: TVIIM LLC v McAfee Inc
name_numbers: ['TVIIM, LLC v. McAfee, Inc., 851 F.3d 1356 (2017)']
author: [' Reyna, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Reyna, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] claim terms including “as a result of/in response to” did not have multiple ordinary meanings;

[2] substantial evidence supported jury's non-infringement verdict with respect to claim term “as a result of/in response
to”;

[3] substantial evidence supported jury's invalidity determination based on anticipation, with respect to claim term “as
a result of/in response to”;

[4]  substantial  evidence  supported  jury's  verdict  of  non-infringement  with  respect  to  claim  term  “various  utility
functions”;

[5] substantial evidence supported jury's invalidity verdict for anticipation with respect to claim term “various utility
functions”;

[6] substantial evidence supported jury's verdict of non-infringement with respect to claim term “reporting the discovered
vulnerabilities”;

[7] substantial evidence supported jury's verdict of invalidity for anticipation with respect to claim term “reporting the
discovered vulnerabilities”; and

[8] any error by jury regarding non-infringement was harmless.

Affirmed.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cTVIIM, LLC v. McAfee, Inc., 851 F.3d 1356 (2017)
122 U.S.P.Q.2d 1381

"]

column1: DigitalVending Services Intern LLC v University of Phoenix Inc
name_numbers: ['Digital-Vending Services Intern., LLC v. University of Phoenix, Inc., 672 F.3d 1270 (2012)']
author: [' Rader, Chief']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Rader, Chief Judge, held that:

[1]  Court  of  Appeals  would  not  attempt  to  review  argument  as  to  newly  proposed  claim  construction  that  was
substantially different in scope from construction patentee sought below;

[2] “free of content managed by the architecture” limitation that had been explicitly recited in various claims could not
be read into stand-alone phrase “registration server”;

[3] by stipulating to patent claim construction that district court had adopted, patentee waived its right to challenge that
construction on appeal;

[4] Court of Appeals could not construe term, “server,” in first instance; and

[5] phrase, “registration server,” did not have to be free of content managed by architecture.

Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

Moore, Circuit Judge, filed opinion dissenting in part.

']

author: [' Dyk, Circuit']
holding:

[1] Commerce failed to provide adequate notice before withdrawal of targeted dumping regulation, in violation of APA;

[2] Commerce's invocation of good-cause exception to notice and comment requirement for rulemaking under APA not
support its decision to dispense with notice and comment rulemaking before repeal of regulation;

[3] Commerce's failure to comply with notice and comment requirement for rulemaking under APA prior to repealing
regulation did not constitute harmless error; and

[4]  Commerce's  application  of  targeted  dumping  regulation  when  accounting  for  targeted  dumping  pattern  was
reasonable.

Affirmed.

"]

column1: High Point Design LLC v Buyers Direct Inc
name_numbers: ['High Point Design LLC v. Buyers Direct, Inc., 730 F.3d 1301 (2013)']
author: [' Schall, Circuit']
holding:
["s Corporation, and Wal–Mart Stores, Inc., Third Party Defendants–Appellees,

BUYERS DIRECT, INC., Defendant/Counterclaimant–Appellant.

v.

No. 2012–1455.

|

Sept. 11, 2013.

Synopsis
Background:  Designer  and  manufacturer  of  slippers  brought  action  against  competitor  and  retailers  of  competitor's
product, alleging patent infringement and trade dress infringement. The United States District Court for the Southern
District of New York, Katherine B. Forrest, J., granted summary judgment to defendants on basis of determination that
manufacturer's design patent was invalid, and dismissed manufacturer's trade dress claim. Manufacturer appealed.

Holdings: The Court of Appeals, Schall, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1]  in  determining  whether  design  patent  for  slippers  was  invalid  for  obviousness,  “ordinary  designer,”  rather  than
“ordinary observer,” standard applied;

[2] district court's verbal description of design patent did not sufficiently evoke a visual image consonant with the claimed
design, as required for proper assessment of whether patent was invalid for obviousness,

[3] district court's failure to provide its reasoning for determining that prior art was “basically the same as the claimed
design” required remand;

[4] genuine issues of material fact existed as to whether claimed prior art were proper primary references;

[5]  district  court  applied  incorrect  standing  in  determining  whether  design  patent  for  slippers  was  invalid  as  being
“primarily functional”;

[6] district court was required to determine whether manufacturer had established good cause to modify scheduling order
to allow the proposed amendments; and

[7] remand was required to allow clarification of reason for denial of motion to amend pleadings.

Reversed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cHigh Point Design LLC v. Buyers Direct, Inc., 730 F.3d 1301 (2013)
86 Fed.R.Serv.3d 621, 108 U.S.P.Q.2d 1183

"]
lawyers_judge:
["

*1304   Jeffrey  M.  Kaden,  Gottlieb  Rackman  &  Reisman,  P.C.,  New  York,  NY,  argued  for  plaintiff/counterclaim
defendant-appellee and third-party defendants-appellees. With him on the brief were David S. Kashman and Steven
Stern.

Andrew  M.  Ollis,  Oblon,  Spivak,  McClelland,  Maier  &  Neustdt  L.L.P,  Alexandria,  VA,  argued  for  defendant/
counterclaimant-appellant. With him on the brief were Frank J. West and Philippe J. C. Signore.

Before O'MALLEY, SCHALL, and WALLACH, Circuit Judges.

"]

column1: Brooks v Dunlop Mfg Inc
name_numbers: ['Brooks v. Dunlop Mfg. Inc., 702 F.3d 624 (2012)']
author: [' Prost, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Prost, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] Due Process Clause did not prevent Congress from applying amendments to qui tam provision of patent marking
statute to pending qui tam actions;

[2] version of patent marking statute prior to amendments under America Invents Act that eliminated relators' standing
to bring a qui tam action was not offer to enter into unilateral contract with Congress; and

[3]  judicial  review  of  retroactive  amendments  to  qui  tam  provision  of  patent  marking  statute  implicated  Congress's
judgment in effectuating and maintaining patent system.

Affirmed.

"]

column1: Romag Fasteners Inc v Fossil Inc
name_numbers: ['Romag Fasteners, Inc. v. Fossil, Inc., 866 F.3d 1330 (2017)']
author: [' Dyk, Circuit']
holding:
["s, Inc., Defendants-Appellants

Dillard's, Inc., Nordstrom, Inc., The Bon-Ton Stores, Inc., The Bon-Ton Department

Stores, Inc., Belk, Inc., Zappos.com, Inc., Zappos Retail, Inc., Defendants

2016-1115

|

2016-1116

|

2016-1842

|

Decided: August 9, 2017

Synopsis
Background:  Designer  of  magnetic  snap  fasteners  used  in  handbags  and  other  accessories  that  were  protected  by
patent and sold under registered “Romag” trademark brought action against handbag manufacturer and retailers and
department stores, alleging trademark infringement, false designation of origin, state common law unfair competition,
violation of Connecticut Unfair Trade Practices Act (CUTPA), and patent infringement. Jury rendered verdict in favor
of designer. The United States District Court for the District of Connecticut, Nos. 3:10-cv-01827-JBA, 3:11-cv-00929-
CFD, Janet Bond Arterton, J., 2014 WL 4073204, awarded attorney fees and costs under Patent Act, denied them under
Lanham Act, and determined amount of fees and costs 2015 WL 5787019. Parties appealed.

Holdings: The Court of Appeals, Dyk, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] Lanham Act has same standard for recovering attorney’s fees as Patent Act;

[2] district court awarded attorney fees in patent infringement claim on clearly erroneous assessment of evidence, and
therefore abused its discretion;

[3] designer's earlier litigation misconduct associated with temporary restraining order (TRO) could not be disregarded
on theory that failure to award fees was equivalent to double-sanctioning designer; and

[4] district court properly evaluated substantive strength of manufacturer’s litigating position in connection with totality
of circumstances analysis of whether to award attorney fees.

Vacated and remanded.

Newman, Circuit Judge, filed opinion concurring-in-part and dissenting-in-part.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cRomag Fasteners, Inc. v. Fossil, Inc., 866 F.3d 1330 (2017)
123 U.S.P.Q.2d 1629

"]

column1: Monsanto Co v EI Du Pont de Nemours and Co
name_numbers: ['Monsanto Co. v. E.I. Du Pont de Nemours and Co., 748 F.3d 1189 (2014)']
author: [' Lourie, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Lourie, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1]  district  court  did  not  abuse  its  discretion  under  its  inherent  power  in  imposing  narrowly-tailored  sanctions  on
licensee for making factual misrepresentations concerning its subjective understanding of license in order to advance its
reformation counterclaims;

[2] court properly considered statements of licensee's in-house attorneys who were part of negotiation team for license
after licensee waived its attorney-client privilege to pursue those counterclaims;

[3] court did not abuse its discretion by considering statements made by licensee's negotiators after formation of license
agreement; and

[4] court correctly found that licensee had abused the judicial process and acted in bad faith by making affirmative factual
misrepresentations.

Affirmed.

"]

column1: Senju Pharmaceutical Co v Lupin Ltd
name_numbers: ['Senju Pharmaceutical Co. v. Lupin Ltd., 780 F.3d 1337 (2015)']
author: [' Plager, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Plager, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] District Court properly considered evidence of unexpected results and did not err in finding that, based on record
and testimony offered, increase in corneal permeability shown by patentees was not unexpected or surprising, but was a
product of routine optimization that would have been obvious to one of skill in the art, and

[2] District Court properly applied presumption of validity, considering both evidence of obviousness and evidence of
unexpected results, to find that defendants set forth clear and convincing evidence that patent was invalid for obviousness.

Affirmed.

Newman, Circuit Judge, filed separate dissenting opinion.

']

column1: Fresenius USA Inc v Baxter Intern Inc
name_numbers: ['Fresenius USA, Inc. v. Baxter Intern., Inc., 721 F.3d 1330 (2013)']
holding:
["s, Inc., Plaintiffs–Appellants,

v.

BAXTER INTERNATIONAL, INC., and Baxter Healthcare Corporation, Defendants–Cross Appellants.

Nos. 2012–1334, 2012–1335.

|

July 2, 2013.

Synopsis
Background: Competitor brought action seeking declaratory judgment that claims in patent directed toward hemodialysis
machine were invalid and not infringed. Patentee counterclaimed for infringement. The district court, 2007 WL 518804
and  2008  WL  928496,  granted  judgment  for  patentee,  and  parties  appealed.  The  Court  of  Appeals,  582  F.3d  1288,
affirmed in part, reversed in part, vacated in part, and remanded. The United States Patent and Trademark Office (PTO)
completed reexamination of patent and determined that all asserted claims were invalid, 2010 WL 1048980, and PTO's
determination in reexamination proceeding was affirmed, 678 F.3d 1357. Meanwhile, the United States District Court
for the Northern District of California, Phyllis J. Hamilton, J., 2012 WL 761712, entered judgment against competitor
in pending infringement proceedings. Competitor appealed.

[Holding:] The Court of Appeals, Dyk, Circuit Judge, held that under reexamination statute, cancellation of claims by
PTO was binding in pending district court infringement litigation.

Vacated and remanded.

Newman, Circuit Judge, filed dissenting opinion.

"]

['

were Sanjay K. Murthy and Devon C. Beane; and David A. Simons, of Boston, MA.

Before NEWMAN, DYK, and PROST, Circuit Judges.

']

column1: St Jude Medical Inc v Access Closure Inc
name_numbers: ['St. Jude Medical, Inc. v. Access Closure, Inc., 729 F.3d 1369 (2013)']
author: [' Plager, Circuit']
holding:
['s, Inc. v. Google, Inc., E.D.Tex., July 8, 2016

\xa0

729 F.3d 1369

United States Court of Appeals,

Federal Circuit.

ST. JUDE MEDICAL, INC., and St. Jude Medical Puerto Rico, LLC, Plaintiffs–Appellees,

ACCESS CLOSURE, INC., Defendant–Appellant.

v.

No. 2012–1452.

|

Sept. 11, 2013.

|

Rehearing and Rehearing En Banc Denied Dec. 9, 2013.

Synopsis
Background: Patentee filed action against competitor alleging infringement of patents that disclosed variety of methods
and devices for sealing vascular puncture. The United States District Court for the Western District of Arkansas, Harry
F. Barnes, Senior Judge, granted judgment for patentee after jury rendered verdict for patentee and court held after
bench trial that safe harbor applied, 2011 WL 5374424. Competitor appealed.

Holdings: The Court of Appeals, Plager, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] restriction in grandparent application resulting from election of species affected line of demarcation in continuation
patents;

[2] challenged patent and sibling patent did not maintain consonance; and

[3] competitor did not show by clear and convincing evidence that patents were obvious based on prior art.

Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Lourie, Circuit Judge, filed concurring opinion.

']

Before LOURIE, PLAGER, and WALLACH, Circuit Judges.

']

column1: Cadence Pharmaceuticals Inc v Exela PharmSci Inc
name_numbers: ['Cadence Pharmaceuticals Inc. v. Exela PharmSci Inc., 780 F.3d 1364 (2015)']
author: [' Linn, Circuit']
holding:
['s Inc., Exela Pharma Sciences LLC, Defendants–Appellants.

No. 2014–1184.

|

March 23, 2015.

Synopsis
Background:  Owner  and  exclusive  licensee  commenced  action  against  competitor,  alleging  infringement  of  patents
relating to formulations and methods for making liquid acetaminophen compositions. The United States District Court
for the District of Delaware, Leonard P. Stark, J., 886 F.Supp.2d 445, construed the claims, and ruled that competitor
infringed certain asserted claims of both patents and failed to prove invalidity. Competitor appealed.

Holdings: The Court of Appeals, Linn, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] statement in specification that concentration of buffer “may be” between 0.1 and 10 mg-ml was not limiting;

[2] sodium ascorbate present in accused formulation as antioxidant met buffering agent limitation;

[3] accused process infringed under equivalents doctrine;

[4] statements made during prosecution did not rise to level of explicit disclaimer; and

[5] patent was not obvious.

Affirmed.

']

']

column1: Organik Kimya San ve Tic AS v International Trade Commission
name_numbers: ['Organik Kimya, San. ve Tic. A.S. v. International Trade Commission, 848 F.3d 994 (2017)']
author: [" O'Malley, Circuit"]
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, O'Malley, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] Commission was not required to address prejudice to opposing party or availability or efficacy of lesser sanctions
before imposing default judgment sanctions;

[2] Commission did not abuse its discretion in implementing default judgment sanctions; and

[3] Commission did not abuse its discretion in imposing 25-year limited exclusion order.

Affirmed.

"]
lawyers_judge:
["

by JOHN ROBERT ROBERTSON, BENJAMIN HOLT.

RAYMOND N. NIMROD, Quinn Emanuel Urquhart & Sullivan, LLP, New York, NY, argued for intervenors. Also
represented by WILLIAM ADAMS, JAMES BAKER; S. ALEX LASHER, PAUL F. BRINKMAN, Washington, DC;
CHARLES KRAMER VERHOEVEN, San Francisco, CA.

Before Lourie, Mayer, and O'Malley, Circuit Judges.

"]

column1: Credit Acceptance Corp v Westlake Services
name_numbers: ['Credit Acceptance Corp. v. Westlake Services, 859 F.3d 1044 (2017)']
author: [' Dyk, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Dyk, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] PTAB determination, that estoppel statute did not bar petitioner's challenge to patent claims, was appealable by
patent owner;

[2] estoppel statute did not bar petitioner's challenge; and

[3] claims were patent-ineligible.

Affirmed.

Mayer, Circuit Judge, filed an opinion dissenting in part.

"]

column1: Aylus Networks Inc v Apple Inc
name_numbers: ['Aylus Networks, Inc. v. Apple Inc., 856 F.3d 1353 (2017)']
author: [' Stoll, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Stoll, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] as an issue of first impression, statements made by a patent owner during an inter partes review (IPR) proceeding can
be relied on to support a finding of prosecution disclaimer during claim construction, and

[2]  patent  owner's  statements  regarding  patent  claims  during  inter  partes  review  (IPR)constituted  a  clear  and
unmistakable surrender of methods.

Affirmed.

"]
lawyers_judge:
['

appellant. Also represented by BRUCE R. ZISSER; JOSHUA L. SOHN, Washington, DC.

III, San Diego, CA.

Before Moore, Linn, and Stoll, Circuit Judges.

']

column1: Luminara Worldwide LLC v Liown Electronics Co Ltd
name_numbers: ['Luminara Worldwide, LLC v. Liown Electronics Co. Ltd., 814 F.3d 1343 (2016)']
author: [' Moore, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Moore, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] affiliate provision of exclusive licensing agreement could not be interpreted in such a way as to detract from licensee's
exclusionary rights to patented technology and to deprive licensee of standing to sue for infringement;

[2] patentee did not have to be joined as party to infringement action; and

[3] substantial question as to whether prior patent for artificial flame technology anticipated claim of patent on which
licensee relied in seeking preliminary injunctive relief against alleged infringer, and as to validity of this later patent,
precluded grant of preliminary injunctive relief.

Vacated and remanded.

"]
lawyers_judge:
["

Ostlund Baer & Louwagie P.A., Minneapolis, MN.

"]

column1: Brain Life LLC v Elekta Inc
name_numbers: ['Brain Life, LLC v. Elekta Inc., 746 F.3d 1045 (2014)']
author: [" O'Malley, Circuit"]
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, O'Malley, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] doctrine of claim preclusion did not bar licensee's claims of infringement against competitor that arose from products
created after previous judgment;

[2] doctrine of issue preclusion did not bar licensee's claims of infringement of method claims against competitor;

[3] infringement claims were barred under Kessler doctrine; and

[4] Kessler doctrine did not bar licensee's infringement claims against competitor regarding accused system that did not
exist at time of previous suit.

Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

"]
lawyers_judge:
["

*1048  Paul Adams, The Adams Law Firm, of Albuquerque, NM, argued for plaintiff-appellant. Of counsel on the brief
were Michael T. Cooke, Jonathan T. Suder, and Brett M. Pinkus, Friedman, Suder & Cooke, of Fort Worth, TX.

Theresa M. Gillis, Mayer Brown LLP, of New York, NY, argued for defendant-appellee. With her on the brief were
Thomas W. Jenkins and Erick J. Palmer, Mayer Brown LLP, of Chicago, IL.

Before O'MALLEY, BRYSON, and WALLACH, Circuit Judges.

"]

column1: Tempo Lighting Inc v Tivoli LLC
name_numbers: ['Tempo Lighting, Inc. v. Tivoli, LLC, 742 F.3d 973 (2014)']
author: [' Rader, Chief']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Rader, Chief Judge, held that:

[1] intrinsic evidence supported Board's claim construction;

[2] consistency and support in the specification supported Board's claim construction;

[3] having corrected examiner's claim construction, Board erred by relying on factual findings resting on that incorrect
claim construction; and

[4] Board erred by not considering competitor's alternative arguments for holding disputed claims unpatentable.

Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

"]
lawyers_judge:
['

McLaughlin, Costa Mesa, CA, for Appeals.

Before RADER, Chief Judge, MOORE, and WALLACH, Circuit Judges.

']

column1: Nan Ya Plastics Corp Ltd v US
name_numbers: ['Nan Ya Plastics Corp., Ltd. v. U.S., 810 F.3d 1333 (2016)']
author: [' Wallach, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Wallach, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] Commerce was entitled to use highest transaction-specific margin from ongoing segment as adverse facts available
rate, and

[2] substantial evidence supported selection of adverse facts available rate of 74.34%.

Affirmed.

']
lawyers_judge:
["

*1336  Peter J. Koenig, Squire Patton Boggs (US) LLP, Washington, DC, argued for plaintiff-appellant.

David D'Alessandris, Commercial Litigation Branch, Civil Division, United States Department of Justice, Washington,
DC, argued for defendant-appellee. Also represented by Benjamin C. Mizer, Patricia M. McCarthy; Michael Thomas
Gagain, Office of the Chief Counsel for Trade Enforcement & Compliance, United States Department of Commerce,
Washington, DC.

Before PROST, Chief Judge, LOURIE and WALLACH, Circuit Judges.

"]

column1: Rembrandt Wireless Technologies LP v Samsung Electronics Co Ltd
name_numbers: ['Rembrandt Wireless Technologies, LP v. Samsung Electronics..., 853 F.3d 1370 (2017)']
author: [' Stoll, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Stoll, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] “modulation method of a different type” meant different families of modulation techniques;

[2] jury's presumed factual findings in support of verdict of nonobviousness were supported by substantial evidence;

[3] district court acted within its discretion in admitting testimony of patentee's damages expert regarding reasonable
royalty rate;

[4] jury's damages award of $15.7 million for all of competitor's infringing sales was supported by substantial evidence;
and

[5]  patentee's  disclaimer  of  claim  embodied  in  unmarked  product  did  not  retroactively  dissolve  statutory  obligation
for  patentee  to  mark  product  in  order  to  recover  damages  for  infringement  occurring  before  it  provided  notice  of
infringement to competitor.

Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cRembrandt Wireless Technologies, LP v. Samsung Electronics..., 853 F.3d 1370 (2017)
122 U.S.P.Q.2d 1301

"]

name_numbers: ['Lifetime Industries, Inc. v. Trim-Lok, Inc., 869 F.3d 1372 (2017)']
author: [' Lourie, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Lourie, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] complaint adequately alleged that competitor directly infringed patent;

[2] complaint adequately alleged that competitor induced infringement; and

[3] complaint adequately pleaded contributory infringement.

Reversed and remanded.

']

column1: Exela Pharma Sciences LLC v Lee
name_numbers: ['Exela Pharma Sciences, LLC v. Lee, 781 F.3d 1349 (2015)']
holding:
["s, Inc., Plaintiffs–Appellants

Michelle K. LEE, Deputy Director, U.S. Patent and Trademark Office, Defendant–Appellee.

Cadence Pharmaceuticals, Inc., SCR Pharmatop, Intervenors.

v.

No. 2013–1206.

|

March 26, 2015.

Synopsis
Background: A competitor brought action against the United States Patent and Trademark Office (PTO), challenging the
PTO's revival of an abandoned patent application as violative of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA). The United
States District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia, Liam O'Grady, 2012 WL 3638552, initially denied the PTO's
motion to dismiss, before granting the PTO's motion to dismiss on reconsideration, 2012 WL 6697068. The competitor
appealed.

Holding: The Court of Appeals held that the PTO's revival actions are not subject to third party challenge under the APA.

Affirmed.

Newman, Circuit Judge, filed a concurring opinion.

Dyk, Circuit Judge, filed a concurring opinion.

"]

[1] term “patent” meant both operating systems and the applications that run on them, and

[2] terms “volatile memory” and “nonvolatile memory” were not invalid for indefiniteness.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.

']

name_numbers: ['Gilead Sciences, Inc. v. Lee, 778 F.3d 1341 (2015)']
author: [' Wallach, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Wallach, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] Congress had not addressed question whether assessment of applicant delay required conduct that actually caused
delay;

[2] statute providing for assessment of applicant delay was not ambiguous; and

[3] PTO's interpretation of the statute was reasonable.

Affirmed.

"]

column1: Japanese Foundation for Cancer Research v Lee
name_numbers: ['Japanese Foundation for Cancer Research v. Lee, 773 F.3d 1300 (2014)']
author: [' Prost, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Prost, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] paralegal's mistaken belief that patentee sought to disclaim patent was not “clerical error” that PTO was statutorily
empowered to correct, and

[2] PTO did not act arbitrarily, act capriciously, or abuse its discretion in declining to use any inherent authority to
withdraw terminal disclaimer.

Reversed and vacated.

"]

column1: Kyocera Solar Inc v United States International Trade Commission
name_numbers: ['Kyocera Solar, Inc. v. United States International Trade..., 844 F.3d 1334 (2016)']
author: [' Stoll, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Stoll, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1]  statutory  scheme  governing  countervailing  and  antidumping  duties  requires  ITC  to  make  its  determinations  of
domestic injury and negligibility with respect to subject merchandise, and

[2] ITC was not required to conduct separate negligibility analysis regarding solar modules, imported from Mexico,
which incorporated Taiwanese CSPV.

Affirmed.

']

column1: Versata Development Group Inc v SAP America Inc
name_numbers: ['Versata Development Group, Inc. v. SAP America, Inc., 793 F.3d 1306 (2015)']
author: [' Plager, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Plager, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] on issue of first impression, Court had authority to review whether patent was within PTAB's authority;

[2] patent was “covered business method patent”;

[3] claims at issue did not fall within meaning of “technological invention”;

[4] Court could review whether PTAB was authorized to invoke provision defining patent-eligible subject matter as test
of validity in CBM cases;

[5] PTAB was within its statutory invalidation authority when it chose to apply jurisprudence under provision defining
patent-eligible subject matter in determining validity of challenged claims; and

[6] claims were not eligible for patent.

Affirmed.

Hughes, Circuit Judge, filed opinion concurring-in-part and dissenting-in-part.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cVersata Development Group, Inc. v. SAP America, Inc., 793 F.3d 1306 (2015)
115 U.S.P.Q.2d 1681

"]

column1: David Netzer Consulting Engineer LLC v Shell Oil Company
name_numbers: ['David Netzer Consulting Engineer LLC v. Shell Oil Company, 824 F.3d 989 (2016)']
author:
[" Lourie, J., held that:

[1] owner had standing to maintain infringement action;

[2]  “fractionating”  in  patent  meant  separating  compounds  based  on  differences  in  boiling  points,  which  excluded
conventional extraction methods, such as oil company's Sulfolane process; and

[3] oil company's Sulfolane process did not infringe patent.

Affirmed.

West Headnotes (14)

[1]

[2]

Persons Entitled to Sue;  Standing

Patents
Limited  liability  company  (LLC)  that  owned  patent  for  process  for  coproduction  of  ethylene  and  purified
benzene from refinery mixtures had standing to maintain infringement action against oil company, even though
LLC changed its name after inception of the lawsuit, as required by Texas law; patent was owned by the same
company, under its new name.

Cases that cite this headnote

Summary judgment

Federal Courts
Court of Appeals reviews a district court's summary judgment decision de novo, applying the same standard
used by the district court.

2 Cases that cite this headnote

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cDavid Netzer Consulting Engineer LLC v. Shell Oil Company, 824 F.3d 989 (2016)
118 U.S.P.Q.2d 1701

[3]

[4]

[5]

[6]

[7]

[8]

[9]

In general;  comparison with  patent claims

Patents
To determine infringement, court first construes the scope and meaning of the asserted patent claims, and then
compares the construed claims to the accused product or process.

Cases that cite this headnote

Particular questions or subject matter

Courts
Proper construction of a patent's claims is an issue of Federal Circuit law.

1 Cases that cite this headnote

Construction and Operation of Patents

Patents
Court of Appeals reviews a district court's ultimate patent claim constructions de novo and any underlying
factual determinations involving extrinsic evidence for clear error.

2 Cases that cite this headnote

Plain, ordinary, or customary meaning in general
State of the art

Patents
Patents
Words of a patent claim are generally given their ordinary and customary meaning as understood by a person
of ordinary skill in the art at the time of the invention.

3 Cases that cite this headnote

Multiple sources for construction

Patents
Ordinary and customary meaning of words of patent claims are often not immediately apparent, and because
patentees frequently use terms idiosyncratically, the court looks to the intrinsic record, including the words of
the claims themselves, the remainder of the specification, and the prosecution history, as well as to extrinsic
evidence when appropriate, to construe a disputed claim term.

2 Cases that cite this headnote

Contemporaneous construction

Patents
If patent specification reveals a special definition given to a claim term by the inventor, then the inventor's
lexicography governs, even if it differs from the term's ordinary meaning.

1 Cases that cite this headnote

Specification disclaimer

Patents
If patent specification reveals an intentional disclaimer or disavowal of claim scope by the inventor, then the
inventor's intention as expressed in the specification is regarded as dispositive.

2 Cases that cite this headnote

[10]

Patents

Fuels, oils, and lubricants

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

2

\x0cDavid Netzer Consulting Engineer LLC v. Shell Oil Company, 824 F.3d 989 (2016)
118 U.S.P.Q.2d 1701

Fuels, oils, and lubricants

Patents
“Fractionating” in patent for process for coproduction of ethylene and purified benzene from refinery mixtures
meant separating compounds based on differences in boiling points, which excluded conventional extraction
methods, such as alleged infringer's Sulfolane process.

Cases that cite this headnote

[11]

Extrinsic Evidence

Patents
Extrinsic evidence may not be used to contradict a patent claim meaning that is unambiguous in light of the
intrinsic record.

3 Cases that cite this headnote

[12]

Fuels, oils, and lubricants

Patents
Alleged  infringer's  Sulfolane  process  did  not  infringe  patent  for  process  for  coproduction  of  ethylene  and
purified benzene from refinery mixtures, given that alleged infringer's pyrolysis gasoline was refined in multiple
steps to yield a mixture containing about 57% benzene, far below the 80% required by the claims, and patentee
had disclaimed conventional extraction, including the Sulfolane process.

Cases that cite this headnote

[13]

Transitional phrases;  open-ended claims

Patents
Patent term “comprising” generally allows for additional, unclaimed steps in the accused process, but each
claimed step must nevertheless be performed as written.

1 Cases that cite this headnote

[14]

Patents
US Patent 6,677,496. Not Infringed.

name_numbers: ['M.Z. Berger & Co., Inc. v. Swatch AG, 787 F.3d 1368 (2015)']
author: [' Chen, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Chen, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] on issue of first impression, lack of a bona fide intent to use the mark in commerce is proper statutory grounds on
which to challenge a trademark application;

[2]  whether  applicant  had  bona  fide  intent  to  use  mark  in  commerce  was  objective  inquiry  based  on  totality  of  the
circumstances; and

[3] substantial evidence supported conclusion by Board.

Affirmed.

']

column1: Azure Networks LLC v CSR PLC
name_numbers: ['Azure Networks, LLC v. CSR PLC, 771 F.3d 1336 (2014)']
author: [' Chen, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Chen, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] patent rights transfer agreement constituted assignment for purposes of standing to bring or join suit;

[2] transferor did not have exclusionary rights and interests created by patent statutes, and thus did not have standing
to bring or join suit;

[3] term, “MAC address,” meant address that uniquely identified device or group of devices on shared communication
medium; and

[4] single, cursory use of “Media Access (MAC) address,” i.e., dropping word “Control,” in patent specification did
not redefine established term of art to have narrower definition than traditional “Media Access Control” or “Medium
Access Control” (MAC) address.

Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

Mayer, Circuit Judge, filed opinion dissenting-in-part.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cAzure Networks, LLC v. CSR PLC, 771 F.3d 1336 (2014)
112 U.S.P.Q.2d 1817

']

column1: Reoforce Inc v United States
name_numbers: ['Reoforce, Inc. v. United States, 853 F.3d 1249 (2017)']
author: [' Stoll, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Stoll, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] owners had standing to pursue their regulatory takings claim;

[2] six-year statute of limitations period for claims of which the Court of Federal Claims has jurisdiction over began
to run for owners' regulatory taking claim when BLM ended its mining claim validity determination by entering into
settlement agreement with owners;

[3] Court of Federal Claims did not clearly err in finding that BLM's MOU did not prevent owners from mining on their
claims, such that BLM did not effect temporary regulatory taking of owners' property through MOU; and

[4] even if BLM's MOU interfered with owners' property rights, owners did not suffer compensable regulatory taking.

Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

"]
lawyers_judge:

name_numbers: ['Celgard, LLC v. SK Innovation Co., Ltd., 792 F.3d 1373 (2015)']
author: [' Reyna, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Reyna, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] patentee was only required to make a prima facie showing of personal jurisdiction;

[2] patentee failed to establish prima facie that non-resident competitor purposefully directed its activities to forum state;

[3] patentee failed to establish prima facie that two automobile dealers in the forum state operated as either the agents
or alter egos of competitor; and

[4] patentee failed to establish prima facie that competitor was aware that its accused products were marketed in forum
state.

Affirmed.

']

column1: Alfred E Mann Foundation for Scientific Research v Cochlear Corporation
name_numbers: ['Alfred E. Mann Foundation for Scientific Research v...., 841 F.3d 1334 (2016)']
author: [' Hughes, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Hughes, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] claim for a method of testing an implantable tissue stimulating system did not require that an infringing system display
the voltage between two electrodes;

[2] substantial evidence supported determination that accused system infringed upon claim for a method of testing an
implantable tissue stimulating system;

[3] patent claims were invalid as indefinite;

[4] claim sufficiently disclosed an algorithm for achieving claimed function of processing the status-indicating signals to
derive information therefrom regarding the operation of the implanted stimulator and its plurality of tissue stimulating
electrodes;

[5] remand was required for redetermination of willfulness of infringement under preponderance of evidence standard;
and

[6] Court of Appeals lacked jurisdiction to consider claim that district court abused its discretion in granting competitor's
motion to vacate jury's damages award and order new trial on damages.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

Newman, Circuit Judge, filed opinion concurring in part and dissenting in part.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cAlfred E. Mann Foundation for Scientific Research v...., 841 F.3d 1334 (2016)

column1: Trustees of Columbia University in City of New York v Symantec Corp
name_numbers: ['Trustees of Columbia University in City of New York v...., 811 F.3d 1359 (2016)']
author: [' Dyk, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Dyk, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] term “byte sequence feature” meant a feature that was a representation of machine code instructions of the executable;

[2] term “probabilistic model of normal computer system usage” meant a model of typical attack-free computer system
usage that employs probability, with the model generated with only attack-free data; but

[3] limiting term “anomalous” to mean that model had to be built only using attack-free data was improper.

Affirmed in part and reversed and remanded in part.

']

column1: Cummins Inc v TAS Distributing Co Inc
name_numbers: ['Cummins, Inc. v. TAS Distributing Co., Inc., 700 F.3d 1329 (2012)']
author: [' Reyna, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Reyna, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] licensee could have asserted patent-based defenses in response to licensor's prior declaratory judgment action alleging
breach of license agreement;

[2] licensor's earlier action against licensee had been based on same set of transactional facts as asserted in licensee's later
action alleging patent invalidity, unenforceability, and misuse;

[3] granting relief to licensee in its subsequent action would have nullified prior action, and thus res judicata applied; and

[4] misrepresentation exception to res judicata under Illinois law did not apply.

Affirmed.

"]

Before NEWMAN, BRYSON, and REYNA, Circuit Judges.

']

holding:
['s: On remand, the Court of Appeals, Dyk, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] preponderance of the evidence standard, rather than clear and convincing evidence standard, applied when evaluating
sufficiency of evidence of willful infringement, and

[2] determination of enhanced damages for patent infringement is left to the discretion of the district court.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

Wallach, Circuit Judge, filed opinion dissenting in part.

name_numbers: ['Stryker Corp. v. Zimmer, Inc., 782 F.3d 649 (2014)']
author: [' Prost, Chief']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Prost, Chief Judge, held that:

[1] issue of whether competitor's accused device infringed the patents was for jury;

[2] issue of whether patent was anticipated by prior art was for jury;

[3] issue of whether patent's claims were obvious was for jury; and

[4] patentees were not entitled to enhanced damages for willful infringement.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

Opinion, 774 F.3d 1349, revised and superseded.

"]

[1] Court lacked jurisdiction to review Board's decision not to institute IPR on one ground;

[2] Board decision not to institute IPR based on anticipation by prior art would have no estoppel effect on challenger; and

[3] Court lacked jurisdiction to review decision that IPR petition was not time barred.

Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

Reyna, Circuit Judge, concurred specially and filed opinion.

"]

holding:

[1] the retailer forfeited its right to move for judgment as a matter of law after jury verdict on anticipation claim;

[2] the retailer preserved its right to move for judgment as a matter of law after jury verdict on unjust enrichment claim;

[3] the retailer did not receive any benefit from the patentee; and

[4] the District Court adequately explained the Court's reasoning in granting a new trial on the anticipation claim.

Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

"]

column1: Function Media LLC v Google Inc
name_numbers: ['Function Media, L.L.C. v. Google, Inc., 708 F.3d 1310 (2013)']
author: [' Reyna, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Reyna, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] patent did not provide any disclosure of structure for “transmitting” function, and thus claim was invalid for failure
to satisfy definiteness requirement;

[2] proving that person of ordinary skill could devise some method to perform “transmitting” function on invention was
not sufficient to satisfy patent definiteness requirement;

[3]  “processing”  term  in  patent  meant  executing  systematic  sequence  of  mathematical  or  logical  operations  upon
customized electronic advertisement to make it comply with presentation rules of Internet media venues;

[4] phrase, “publishing the electronic advertisement to one or more of the selected internet media venues,” in patent
meant placing or making available the customized electronic advertisement within the framework of and at each internet
media venue so that it is accessible by the end users, consumers, viewers, or buyers;

[5] patentee was not required to object to its own testimony on point that was in accord with claim construction that it
had proposed and that court had adopted;

[6] competitor's arguments to jury about claim scope did not subvert jury's ability to fairly decide issues before it;

[7] jury verdicts regarding anticipation and patent invalidity were general verdicts, not special verdicts; and

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cFunction Media, L.L.C. v. Google, Inc., 708 F.3d 1310 (2013)
105 U.S.P.Q.2d 1754

[8] argument that jury verdict was result of misapprehension of law, specifically that claims could have one meaning for
infringement and another for anticipation, did not amount to clear showing of absolute absence of evidence to support
jury's verdict of infringement, as required for new trial.

Affirmed.

"]
lawyers_judge:
['

*1314  Justin A. Nelson, Susman Godfrey L.L.P, of Seattle, WA, argued for plaintiff-appellant. With him on the brief

']

author: [' Stoll, Circuit']
holding:

[1] false testimony of expert witness for competitor denied patent owner a full and fair opportunity to present its case, and

[2] competitor engaged in fraud with respect to withholding of contradictory test results on third-party lenses known to
infringe and generated at request of competitor's counsel.

Reversed and remanded.

Dyk, Circuit Judge, filed a dissenting opinion.

"]

name_numbers: ['OSRAM Sylvania, Inc. v. American Induction Technologies, Inc., 701 F.3d 698 (2012)']
author: [" O'Malley, Circuit"]
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, O'Malley, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] factual issue existed on claim that patent had been anticipated;

[2] competitor did not face enhanced burden in establishing anticipation because examiner considered prior art patent
during prosecution of patent in suit; and

[3] factual issue existed as to whether one of ordinary skill would consider lamp shape to be irrelevant.

Reversed and remanded.

"]

column1: WiLAN Inc v Kilpatrick Townsend And Stockton LLP
name_numbers: ['Wi-LAN, Inc. v. Kilpatrick Townsend & Stockton LLP, 684 F.3d 1364 (2012)']
author: [' Clevenger, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Clevenger, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] owner's pre-litigation disclosure of opinion letter waived owner's confidentiality, as well as owner's attorney-client
privilege, at least as to letter itself;

[2]  Ninth  Circuit  law  mandated  fairness  considerations  when  determining  scope  of  express  extrajudicial  waiver  of
attorney-client privilege; and

[3] finding of legal error did not necessarily relieve law firm of penalty.

Vacated and remanded.

Reyna, Circuit Judge, filed dubitante opinion.

"]

column1: PhilInsul Corp v Airlite Plastics Co
name_numbers: ['Phil-Insul Corp. v. Airlite Plastics Co., 854 F.3d 1344 (2017)']
author: [' O’Malley, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, O’Malley, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] prior infringement proceeding, wherein Court of Appeals summarily affirmed without opinion District Court's claim
constructions for patent, collaterally estopped assignee from re-litigating claim constructions in subsequent infringement
proceeding, and

[2] infringement claims in subsequent proceeding were the same as infringement claims that assignee litigated and lost
in prior infringement proceeding, and thus, prior proceeding, wherein Court of Appeals summarily affirmed without
opinion District Court's judgments of noninfringement, collaterally estopped assignee from re-litigating infringement
claims.

Affirmed.

"]
lawyers_judge:
['

']

column1: Pregis Corp v Kappos
name_numbers: ['Pregis Corp. v. Kappos, 700 F.3d 1348 (2012)']
author: [' Reyna, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Reyna, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] jury reasonably could have found that those skilled in the art would have been motivated to simplify prior art machine,
and thus patents relating to air-pillow packaging were obvious;

[2]  commercial  success  and  purported  copied  features  of  embodiment  of  patent  on  pillow  cushion  packaging  was
uninformative to obviousness determination; and

[3] competitor was not entitled under Administrative Procedure Act (APA) to judicial review of decision of Patent and
Trademark Office (PTO) to grant patents in suit.

Affirmed.

']

name_numbers: ['Whitserve, LLC v. Computer Packages, Inc., 694 F.3d 10 (2012)']
author: [" O'Malley, Circuit"]
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, O'Malley, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] verdict that accused software infringed patents for automating delivery of professional services was supported by
substantial evidence;

[2] patent claim that allowed clients to access a central computer and copy their data records to their own computer from
across the Internet was invalid as anticipated;

[3] verdict that other claims were not invalid was supported by substantial evidence;

[4] damages award was not supported by substantial evidence;

[5] district court abused its discretion in failing to provide full explanation as to why prejudgment interest on damages
was not necessary to adequately compensate patentee;

[6] district court abused its discretion in denying patentee's motion for enhanced damages on ground that jury's damages
award provided “complete compensation” for willful infringement; and

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cWhitserve, LLC v. Computer Packages, Inc., 694 F.3d 10 (2012)
104 U.S.P.Q.2d 1024

[7] district court abused its discretion in failing to explain why award of attorney's fees was unwarranted.

Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

Mayer, Circuit Judge, filed dissenting opinion.

"]

column1: Streck Inc v Research And Diagnostic Systems Inc
name_numbers: ['Streck, Inc. v. Research & Diagnostic Systems, Inc., 665 F.3d 1269 (2012)']
author: [" O'Malley, Circuit"]
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, O'Malley, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] district court lacked jurisdiction over counterclaim seeking declaratory judgment of invalidity as to patent claims not
included by patentee in its infringement allegations;

[2] patents provided adequate written description for integrated controls using either true reticulocytes or reticulocyte
analogs;

[3] patents enabled claimed integrated hematology control using both true reticulocytes and reticulocyte analogs;

[4] priority determination by Court of Appeals in companion appeal rendered moot competitor's arguments on appeal
related to priority issue; and

[5] permanent injunction was not overbroad.

Affirmed.

See also 659 F.3d 1186.

"]

[1] “voice input” in claim did not require use of any particular type of channel for its transmission;

services to wireless device through provisioning;

[3] patent related to secure data transmissions over wireless networks was not infringed; and

[4]  summary  judgment  of  no  indirect  infringement  was  precluded  for  patent  disclosing  improved  technology  for
identifying location of wireless station.

column1: Vicor Corporation v SynQor Inc
name_numbers: ['Vicor Corporation v. SynQor, Inc., 869 F.3d 1309 (2017)']
author: [' Chen, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Chen, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] testimony by inventor of patented technology at issue, along with article and paper published before priority date of
patent, provided substantial evidence to support conclusion by Board that skilled artisan would not have been motivated
to combine prior art publication addressing controlled rectifiers with prior art patent, and therefore associated claims
were not obvious;

[2] Board had to examine more than one factor of four factor test and consider relative strength of those factors when
analyzing whether patent was obvious;

[3] Board had to provide some reasoned basis for simultaneously reaching inconsistent conclusions as to evidentiary
weight to be given to secondary considerations evidence presented as to similar patents;

[4] Board had to address competitor's arguments on obviousness claim regarding prior art patent's non-pulsed loads;

[5] patentee was not prejudiced by error on rehearing;

[6] opinion by Board sufficiently addressed patentee's argument that prior art patent lacked substantially uninterrupted
power flow due to switching delays of its synchronous rectifiers;

[7] substantial evidence supported decision by Board that voltage-range limitation claims in patent would have been
obvious; and

[8] substantial evidence supported decision by Board that secondary considerations evidence was “principally” directed
to “features of the [anticipated] independent claims,” and therefore was of lesser probative value.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cVicor Corporation v. SynQor, Inc., 869 F.3d 1309 (2017)
124 U.S.P.Q.2d 1048

Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

"]

["

column1: AntiCancer Inc v Pfizer Inc
name_numbers: ['AntiCancer, Inc. v. Pfizer, Inc., 769 F.3d 1323 (2014)']
author: [' Newman, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Newman, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1]  district  court  abused  its  discretion  by  imposing  fee-shifting  sanction  under  its  inherent  powers  conditioned  on
patentee's supplementation under local rules for “promoter monitoring” element in patent on method of monitoring
gene expression using fluorescence imaging;

[2] court abused its discretion by imposing fee-shifting sanction under its inherent powers conditioned on patentee's
supplementation under local rules for “delivering cells” element in patent; and

[3] court abused its discretion by imposing fee-shifting sanction under its inherent powers conditioned on patentee's
supplementation under local rules for “metastasis to a second site” element in patent directed to nude mouse model.

Vacated and remanded.

"]

San Diego, CA.

Jing James LI, LiLaw Inc., of Los Altos, CA, argued for defendant-appellee Crown Bioscience, Inc.

Before NEWMAN, REYNA, and TARANTO, Circuit Judges.

']

column1: International Custom Products Inc v United States
name_numbers: ['International Custom Products, Inc. v. United States, 843 F.3d 1355 (2016)']
author: [' Wallach, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Wallach, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] Court of International Trade's (CIT) reference to incorrect legal standard did not undermine CIT's decision finding
Government's position was not substantially justified;

[2]  fact  that  Government  survived  summary  judgment  did  not  prove  that  Government's  position  was  substantially
justified; and

[3] CIT did not abuse its discretion in determining that Government's position was not substantially justified.

Affirmed.

"]

author: [' Newman, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Newman, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] personal jurisdiction over patent holder was not lost when action was transferred;

[2] district court properly construed term “independent supply chain sites”;

[3] district court properly construed terms “monitoring,” “scanning,” and “detecting” as requiring that these functions
be performed at “each” independent supply chain site; and

[4] district court's failure to require proof of indefiniteness by clear and convincing evidence required remand.

Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

Wallach, Circuit Judge, filed opinion dissenting-in-part.

"]

column1: Kinetic Concepts Inc v Smith And Nephew Inc
name_numbers: ['Kinetic Concepts, Inc. v. Smith & Nephew, Inc., 688 F.3d 1342 (2012)']
author: [" O'Malley, Circuit"]
holding:
["s Limited, Plaintiffs,

and

Wake Forest University Health Sciences, Plaintiff–Appellant,

SMITH & NEPHEW, INC., Defendant–Appellee.

v.

No. 2011–1105.

|

Aug. 13, 2012.

Synopsis
Background:  Patentee  filed  action  against  competitor  alleging  infringement  of  patents  on  apparatus  and  method  of
treating tissue damage by applying negative or reduced pressure to wound over area sufficient to promote migration
of epithelial and subcutaneous tissue toward wound and for time period sufficient to facilitate closure of wound. The
United States District Court for the Western District of Texas, W. Royal Furgeson, Jr., J., granted judgment as matter
of law (JMOL) of invalidity for obviousness. Patentee appealed.

Holdings: The Court of Appeals, O'Malley, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] district court was required to accept all implicit factual findings supporting jury's conclusion with respect to ultimate
conclusion of nonobviousness that were supported by substantial evidence;

[2] substantial evidence supported finding that prior art references did not disclose treating wounds with negative pressure
as required by patents;

[3] court had to assume that jury found patentee's expert to be credible and persuasive in his opinion that prior art
reference did not disclose use of negative pressure to heal wounds as patents did;

[4] court had to defer to factual finding by jury that there was no reason to combine prior art references;

[5] substantial evidence supported jury's findings of objective indicia of nonobviousness; and

[6] competitor did not show that patents were obvious.

Reversed and remanded.

Dyk, Circuit Judge, filed concurring opinion.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cKinetic Concepts, Inc. v. Smith & Nephew, Inc., 688 F.3d 1342 (2012)
104 U.S.P.Q.2d 1001

"]

["

*1345  Matthew D. Powers, Weil, Gotshal & Manges LLP, of Redwood Shores, CA, argued for plaintiff-appellant.
With him on the brief were Elizabeth Stotland Weiswasser, Peter Sandel, Jennifer H. Wu, Danielle Rosenthal and Erin
Wiggins, of New York, NY. Of counsel was Andrew Swanson Brown.

Before BRYSON, DYK and O'MALLEY, Circuit Judges.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

column1: Genzyme Therapeutic Products Limited Partnership v Biomarin Pharmaceutical
name_numbers: ['Genzyme Therapeutic Products Limited Partnership v...., 825 F.3d 1360 (2016)']
author: [' Bryson, Circuit']
holding:
["s, LLC v. Volkswagen Group of America, Inc., Fed.Cir., June 15, 2017

\xa0

825 F.3d 1360

United States Court of Appeals,

Federal Circuit.

GENZYME THERAPEUTIC PRODUCTS LIMITED PARTNERSHIP, Appellant

BIOMARIN PHARMACEUTICAL INC., Appellee

v.

2015–1720, 2015–1721

|

Decided: June 14, 2016

Synopsis
Background: Patent holder sought judicial review of decision of thee Patent Trial and Appeal Board that its claims were
unpatentable for obviousness.

Holdings: The Court of Appeals, Bryson, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] patent holder was not denied notice of the specific combinations of references on which the Patent Trial and Appeal
Board relied in two inter partes review proceedings in finding that its claims were unpatentable for obviousness;

[2] the Board properly gave whereby clause of patent claims its broadest reasonable construction;

[3] the Board's failure to make a specific finding as to the level of skill in support of its obviousness finding was not
reversible error; and

[4] substantial evidence supported finding of the Board, in support of its determination that patents were unpatentable
for obviousness, that based on state of the art persons of ordinary skill would have had reasonable expectation of success
in arresting or reducing accumulation of glycogen in patients with Pompe's disease through injection of therapeutically
effective amounts of human acid alpha glucosidase (GAA).

Affirmed.

"]

["

column1: Tyco Healthcare Group LP v Mutual Pharmaceutical Co Inc
name_numbers: ['Tyco Healthcare Group LP v. Mutual Pharmaceutical Co., Inc., 762 F.3d 1338 (2014)']
author: [' Bryson, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Bryson, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] it is not unreasonable to file a patent infringement action based on evidence that an as-marketed drug would infringe,
even if the hypothetical drug in an ANDA would not infringe;

[2] the patentee had a reasonable probability of success in defending the validity of the patent;

[3] issue of fact whether the patentee's filing a citizen petition with the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) caused an
antitrust precluded summary judgment on an antitrust challenge to the filing of the citizen complaint; and

[4] the patentee did not have constructive knowledge that the original patent applicant obtained the patent fraudulently.

Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

Newman, Circuit Judge, filed a dissenting opinion.

"]

']

Before NEWMAN, LOURIE, and TARANTO, Circuit Judges.

"]

column1: Inventor Holdings LLC v Bed Bath And Beyond Inc
name_numbers: ['Inventor Holdings, LLC v. Bed Bath & Beyond, Inc., 876 F.3d 1372 (2017)']
author: [' Chen, Circuit']
holding:
["s, LLC v. Bed Bath & Beyond, Inc., 876 F.3d 1372 (2017)
125 U.S.P.Q.2d 1019

876 F.3d 1372

United States Court of Appeals,

Federal Circuit.

INVENTOR HOLDINGS, LLC, Plaintiff-Appellant

v.

BED BATH & BEYOND, INC., Defendant-Appellee

2016-2442

|

Decided: December 8, 2017

Synopsis
Background: After finding of patent invalidity, 123 F.Supp.3d 557, was affirmed on appeal without opinion, accused
infringer of patent related to method of purchasing goods at a local point-of-sale system from a remote seller moved for
award of attorney fees. The United States District Court for the District of Delaware, No. 1:14-cv-00448-GMS, Gregory
M. Sleet, J., 2016 WL 3090633, granted motion. Patent owner appealed.

Holdings: The Court of Appeals, Chen, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] it was within district court's discretion to award attorney fees to accused infringer, and

[2] it was within district court's discretion to award appellate attorney fees.

Affirmed.

"]

registrations;

[2] issue preclusion did not bar manufacturer's petition; and

[3] claim preclusion did not bar manufacturer's petition.

Vacated and remanded.

name_numbers: ['DSM Desotech Inc. v. 3D Systems Corp., 749 F.3d 1332 (2014)']
author: [' Schall, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Schall, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] plaintiff failed to prove an independent market for SL machines in support of its antitrust claims;

[2] plaintiff failed to present evidence that a substantial number of competitor's customers were locked in to support its
antitrust claims;

[3] plaintiff failed to establish competitor acted out of spite or ill will in support of its tortious interference claim; and

[4] competitor's statements about plaintiff's products not being licensed or authorized did not violate the Illinois Uniform
Deceptive Trade Practices Act (UDTPA).

Affirmed.

"]

[1] coin qualified as “tool” within meaning of patents that provided for repair of toilets “toollessly”;

single module;

[3] accused toilets did not have “out-turned flange” as claimed in patent; and

[4] competitor was in privity with assignor, as required for assignor estoppel to apply.

Affirmed.

patent covering DNA assay optimization techniques. Developer counterclaimed for breach of its supply agreement with
patentee. Patentee moved to compel arbitration pursuant to supply agreement's arbitration clause. The United States
District Court for the Northern District of California, Susan Y. Illston, J., denied motion to compel arbitration. Patentee
appealed.

of arbitration clause in parties' supply agreement.

Affirmed.

name_numbers: ['Agilent Technologies v. Waters Technologies Corp., 811 F.3d 1326 (2016)']
author: [" O'Malley, Circuit"]
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, O'Malley, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] in a matter of first impression, mere privies of a third-party requester lacked a cause of action to appeal an adverse
reexamination decision, and

[2] acquiring company was not successor-in-interest that stepped into alleged infringer's shoes as third-party requester
of inter partes reexamination, and thus company lacked statutory cause of action to appeal Patent Trial and Appeal
Board's decision.

Appeal dismissed.

"]

commerce” requirement for trademark registration.

column1: Otsuka Pharmaceutical Co Ltd v Sandoz Inc
name_numbers: ['Otsuka Pharmaceutical Co., Ltd. v. Sandoz, Inc., 678 F.3d 1280 (2012)']
author: [' Lourie, Circuit']
holding:
["s

BV, Synthon Laboratories, Inc., and Synthon Pharmaceuticals, Inc., Defendants,

and

Apotex Inc. and Apotex Corp., Defendants–Appellants,

and

Teva Pharmaceuticals USA, Inc., Barr Laboratories, Inc.,
and Barr Pharmaceuticals, Inc., Defendants–Appellants.

Nos. 2011–1126, 2011–1127.

|

May 7, 2012.

|

Rehearing En Banc Denied Aug. 7, 2012.

Synopsis
Background:  Patentee  filed  action  against  generic  drug  manufacturers  alleging  infringement  of  patent  on  active
ingredient in drug approved by Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for treatment of schizophrenia, bipolar disorder,
irritability associated with autistic disorder in pediatric patients, and as add-on treatment for depression. Manufacturers
counterclaimed alleging that claims were invalid for obviousness and obviousness-type double patenting. The United
States District Court for the District of New Jersey, Mary L. Cooper, J., 2010 WL 4596324, sustained validity of asserted
claims of patent after bench trial. Defendants appealed.

Holdings: The Court of Appeals, Lourie, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] carbostyrils could not be considered prior art;

[2] patent was not obvious based on prior art patent that disclosed unsubstituted butoxy compound and “laundry list”
of potential central nervous system controlling effects from carbostyril;

[3] patent was not obvious based on prior art declaration that disclosed three sets of test data comparing carbostyril
derivatives on mice;

[4] manufacturers did not prove by clear and convincing evidence that patent was obvious based on prior art foreign
patent application;

[5] patent was not obvious based on patentee's own prior art development compound; and

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cOtsuka Pharmaceutical Co., Ltd. v. Sandoz, Inc., 678 F.3d 1280 (2012)
102 U.S.P.Q.2d 1729

[6] person of ordinary skill would not have been motivated to pursue 2,3–dichloro substitution on phenyl ring as would
have been required to convert unsubstituted butoxy to aripiprazole.

Affirmed.

"]
lawyers_judge:
['

plaintiff-appellee. With him on the brief were Michael J. Flibbert, Paul M. Browning and Denise Main. Of counsel on the

Inc., et al. With her on the brief was Maria Luisa Palmese.

Before LOURIE, MOORE, and REYNA, Circuit Judges.

']

author: [' Stoll, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Stoll, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] PTAB improperly dismissed some of patentee's evidence of praise related to features that were not available in prior
art;

[2]  PTAB  improperly  dismissed  evidence  that  licensee  was  motivated  to  take  license  because  of  merits  of  claimed
invention; but

[3] PTAB reasonably concluded that patent was invalid as obvious under prior art; and

[4] term “identity information” meant something that identifies, such as name that identifies phone number as particular
person.

Affirmed.

"]

column1: Aria Diagnostics Inc v Sequenom Inc
name_numbers: ['Aria Diagnostics, Inc. v. Sequenom, Inc., 726 F.3d 1296 (2013)']
author: [' Rader, Chief']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Rader, Chief Judge, held that:

[1] phrase, “paternally inherited nucleic acid,” did not mean “DNA sequence known [in advance] to be received only
from the father which is not possessed by the mother”;

[2] prosecution history estoppel did not apply to limit phrase; and

[3] claim language that required “amplifying” paternally inherited nucleic acid, without any mention of effect on quantity
of other nucleic acid, stood infringed without regard to whether, or not, other nucleic acid was amplified.

Vacated and remanded.

']

column1: La Crosse Technology Ltd v US
name_numbers: ['La Crosse Technology, Ltd. v. U.S., 723 F.3d 1353 (2013)']
author: [" O'Malley, Circuit"]
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, O'Malley, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1]  devices  could  not  be  classified  under  HTSUS  pursuant  to  general  rule  of  interpretation  (GRI)  applicable  when
imported article was described in whole by a single classification heading or subheading;

[2] meteorological capabilities of imported devices provided their essential character in determining classification under
HTSUS; and

[3] given their forecasting capabilities, devices had to be classified under HTSUS subheading covering meteorological
instruments and appliances.

Reversed.

Bryson, Circuit Judge, filed a separate opinion concurring in part and dissenting in part.

column1: Amdocs (Israel) Limited v Openet Telecom Inc
name_numbers: ['Amdocs (Israel) Limited v. Openet Telecom, Inc., 841 F.3d 1288 (2016)']
author: [' Plager, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Plager, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] claims in a patent for processing network accounting information possessed an inventive concept sufficient to render
the claims eligible for patent protection;

[2] claims in a patent for a distributed network accounting and billing system possessed an inventive concept sufficient
to render the claims eligible for patent protection;

[3] claims in a patent for reporting on the collection of network usage information from a plurality of network devices
possessed an inventive concept sufficient to render the claims eligible for patent protection; and

[4] claims in a patent for generating a single record reflecting multiple services for accounting purposes possessed an
inventive concept sufficient to render the claims eligible for patent protection.

Reversed and remanded.

Reyna, Circuit Judge, filed a dissenting opinion.

']
