column1: Outside the Box Innovations LLC v Travel Caddy Inc
name_numbers: ['Outside the Box Innovations, LLC v. Travel Caddy, Inc., 695 F.3d 1285 (2012)']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals held that:

[1]  competitor  did  not  establish  inequitable  conduct  in  Patent  and  Trademark  Office  (PTO)  rendering  patents
unenforceable based on nondisclosure of litigation;

[2]  finding  that  patents  were  unenforceable  based  on  inequitable  conduct  was  not  warranted  based  upon  patentee's
purportedly erroneous assertion of small entity status;

[3] testimony of patentee's proffered technical expert on issue of obviousness could not be excluded on ground that expert
was not attorney;

[4]  erroneous  exclusion  of  proffered  expert  testimony  warranted  vacating  rulings  of  invalidity  for  obviousness  and
remand for redetermination of issue;

[5] term “between,” as used in patents, excluded embodiments in which bottom, front, or back panels extended beyond
edges of end panels; and

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cOutside the Box Innovations, LLC v. Travel Caddy, Inc., 695 F.3d 1285 (2012)
104 U.S.P.Q.2d 1890, 89 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 671

[6] term “flexible fabric front panel,” as used in patents, was not reasonably construed to include plywood-stiffened fabric
panel.

Affirmed in part, vacated in part, reversed in part, and remanded.

Newman, Circuit Judge, filed a separate opinion concurring in part and dissenting in part.

"]

column1: KTEC Inc v VitaMix Corp
name_numbers: ['K-TEC, Inc. v. Vita-Mix Corp., 696 F.3d 1364 (2012)']
author: [' Lourie, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Lourie, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] accused blending jar literally infringed asserted claims;

[2] design patents for nonblender five-sided containers were not analogous to asserted patents, as required for design
patents to constitute prior art that could render asserted patents invalid for obviousness;

[3] district court acted within its discretion in allowing parties to discuss extent to which Patent and Trademark Office
(PTO) had considered purported prior art reference in non-final reexamination proceedings;

[4] district court did not unfairly prejudice competitor by changing court's claim construction prior to trial;

[5] jury's finding that patents were not invalid as anticipated was supported by substantial evidence;

[6] district court's finding, that competitor willfully infringed patents, was supported by substantial evidence; and

[7] district court's finding, that patentee provided adequate notice of accused product's infringement for period prior to
amendment of complaint in infringement action, as required to trigger accrual of damages for infringement of unmarked
but patented product, was supported by substantial evidence.

Affirmed.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cK-TEC, Inc. v. Vita-Mix Corp., 696 F.3d 1364 (2012)
104 U.S.P.Q.2d 1408

"]

column1: Liberty Ammunition Inc v United States
name_numbers: ['Liberty Ammunition, Inc. v. United States, 835 F.3d 1388 (2016)']
author: [' Stoll, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Stoll, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] patent term “reduced area of contact” meant that area of contact between interface and rifling of firearm was less
than  that  of  conventional  jacketed  lead  projectile,  which  derived  from  corresponding  caliber  North  Atlantic  Treaty
Organization (NATO) standard-issue round as of specific date;

[2] accused projectiles did not meet “reduced area of contact” limitation, as properly construed;

[3] term “intermediate opposite ends” meant that interface was positioned between or in middle of opposite ends of
forward end of nose portion and trailing end of tail portion, such that interface did not extend all the way to front or
to end of projectile;

[4] accused projectiles did not meet “intermediate opposite ends” limitation, as properly construed; and

[5] government agent did not have implied actual authority to bind government to NDA with assignee.

Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Newman, Circuit Judge, filed opinion concurring in part and dissenting in part.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cLiberty Ammunition, Inc. v. United States, 835 F.3d 1388 (2016)
119 U.S.P.Q.2d 1830

']

that patentee expressly stated that competitor's product “may infringe” patentee's patents and that licenses were available,
that patentee advised that claim charts would be forthcoming after competitor rejected license offer and that competitor
was not given a deadline to respond, were sufficient to constitute a case or controversy.

Vacated and remanded.

"]

column1: ArcelorMittal France v AK Steel Corp
name_numbers: ['ArcelorMittal France v. AK Steel Corp., 700 F.3d 1314 (2012)']
author: [' Dyk, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Dyk, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] scope of term, “hot-rolled steel sheet,” did not exclude steel sheet that had been cold-rolled to its final thickness
following initial hot-rolling;

[2] term, “hot-rolled steel sheet,” meant steel sheet that had been hot-rolled during its production;

[3] phrase, “steel sheet has a very high mechanical resistance,” meant that flat-rolled steel was subjected, after rolling, to
additional controlled heating and cooling and had ultimate tensile strength of 1500 megapascals (MPa) or greater;

[4] substantial evidence did not support jury's verdict that prior art article disclosed coating with aluminum or aluminum
alloy;

[5] substantial evidence supported jury's determination that asserted claims of patent were obvious;

[6] commercial success of patentee's cold-rolled embodiment had to be considered to extent that its success resulted from
claimed combination of elements that constituted invention; and

[7] new trial on obviousness was required to address issue of commercial success.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

Wallach, Circuit Judge, filed opinion dissenting-in-part.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cArcelorMittal France v. AK Steel Corp., 700 F.3d 1314 (2012)
105 U.S.P.Q.2d 1211

"]

[4] design patent for baseball jersey was invalid for obviousness.

Affirmed.

Sept. 25, 2014.

Synopsis
Background: In action alleging infringement of patent for system and method for enabling beneficiaries of retirement
benefits to convert future benefits into current resources to meet current financial and other needs and objectives, the
United States District Court for the District of Delaware, Leonard P. Stark, J., stayed litigation pending Patent Trial
and Appeal Board's (PTAB) covered business method (CBM) review of asserted claims. Patentees appealed.

Holding: The Court of Appeals, Prost, Chief Judge, held that stay was warranted.

Affirmed.

column1: Microsoft Corp v Proxyconn Inc
name_numbers: ['Microsoft Corp. v. Proxyconn, Inc., 789 F.3d 1292 (2015)']
author: [' Prost, Chief']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Prost, Chief Judge, held that:

[1] Patent and Trademark Office permissibly adopted “broadest reasonable interpretation” standard for use in inter
partes review proceedings;

[2] phrase, “two other computers,” was limited to sender-receiver and computer-receiver;

[3] terms, “sender/computer” and “receiver/computer,” were not broad enough to include intermediary gateway and
caching computers;

[4] phrase, “searching for data with the same digital digest in said network cache memory,” meant identifying, from
among a set of data objects, data object with matching digital digest;

[5] prior art protocol anticipated claim in patent; and

[6] Board permissibly denied patentee's motion to amend.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cMicrosoft Corp. v. Proxyconn, Inc., 789 F.3d 1292 (2015)
115 U.S.P.Q.2d 1198

"]

column1: Los Angeles Biomedical Research Institute at HarborUCLA Medical Center v
name_numbers: ['Los Angeles Biomedical Research Institute at Harbor-UCLA..., 849 F.3d 1049 (2017)']
author: [' Bryson, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Bryson, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] phrase, “an individual with at least one of penile tunical fibrosis and corporal tissue fibrosis,” was individual with
penile tunical fibrosis or corporal tissue fibrosis;

[2] limitation “arresting or regressing the at least one of the penile tunical fibrosis and corporal tissue fibrosis” added
patentable efficacy requirement;

[3]  limitation  providing  for  “continuous  long-term  regimen”  did  not  exclude  any  treatment  that  failed  to  maintain
unvarying level of drug within patient's body;

[4] findings by Board were not sufficient to establish obviousness under correct claim constructions;

[5] remand was required for Board to make findings as to whether any reference or combination of references rendered
claim limitation obvious regarding “arresting or regressing the at least one of a penile tunical fibrosis and corporal tissue
fibrosis”; and

[6] substantial evidence supported findings by Board regarding limitation “at a dosage up to 1.5 mg/kg/day for not less
than 45 days.”

Vacated and remanded.

Newman, Circuit Judge, concurring in part and dissenting from the judgment.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cLos Angeles Biomedical Research Institute at Harbor-UCLA..., 849 F.3d 1049 (2017)
121 U.S.P.Q.2d 1800

"]

Newman, Circuit Judge, filed opinion concurring in part and dissenting in part.

column1: Mortgage Grader Inc v First Choice Loan Services Inc
name_numbers: ['Mortgage Grader, Inc. v. First Choice Loan Services Inc., 811 F.3d 1314 (2016)']
author: [' Leonard P. Stark, Chief District']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Leonard P. Stark, Chief District Judge, United States District Court for the District
of Delaware, sitting by designation, held that:

[1] competitor had good cause to amend its invalidity contentions;

[2] claim limitations were directed to abstract idea, and thus were not eligible for patent unless they had inventive concept;

[3] claim limitations did not have inventive concept, and thus were not patent-eligible; and

[4] expert's summary judgment declaration did not raise genuine issue of material fact, as required to preclude summary
judgment.

Affirmed.

"]
lawyers_judge:
["

*1317  Craig R. Kaufman, TechKnowledge Law Group LLP, Redwood City, CA, argued for plaintiff-appellant. Also
represented by Michael Chaocha Ting.

Rebecca Jean Stempien Coyle, Levy & Grandinetti, Washington, DC, argued for defendants-appellees. Also represented
by Paul Grandinetti.

Before O'MALLEY and TARANTO, Circuit Judges, and STARK, Chief District Judge. *

"]

column1: Dome Patent LP v Lee
name_numbers: ['Dome Patent L.P. v. Lee, 799 F.3d 1372 (2015)']
author: [' Federal Circuit, Hughes, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Federal Circuit, Hughes, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] PTO was required to show by a preponderance of the evidence that under ex parte reexamination the patent claim
was shown to be obvious;

[2]patent claim disclosed motivation to combine prior art, and thus was invalid for obviousness;

[3] a person of ordinary skill would not have been dissuaded from combining prior art, and thus prior art did not teach
away from combining elements of claim; and

[4] PTO did not improperly shift burden onto patentee to prove nonobvious-ness once PTO established prima facie case
of obviousness.

Affirmed.

']

sensible tempo for pacing the user.

Affirmed.

']

column1: Novartis AG v Torrent Pharmaceuticals Limited
name_numbers: ['Novartis AG v. Torrent Pharmaceuticals Limited, 853 F.3d 1316 (2017)']
author: [' Chen, Circuit']
holding:
["s, LLC v. Volkswagen Group of America, Inc., Fed.Cir., June 15, 2017

\xa0

853 F.3d 1316

United States Court of Appeals,

Federal Circuit.

NOVARTIS AG, Mitsubishi Pharma Corp., Appellants

v.

TORRENT PHARMACEUTICALS LIMITED, Apotex Inc., Mylan Pharmaceuticals Inc., Appellees

2016-1352

|

Decided: April 12, 2017

Synopsis
Background: Competitors filed separate petitions seeking to institute inter partes review (IPR) of patent that disclosed
a solid pharmaceutical composition suitable for oral administration used to treat certain autoimmune diseases such as
multiple sclerosis. In consolidated proceeding, the United States Patent and Trademark Office, Patent Trial and Appeal
Board, Nos. IPR2014-00784 and IPR2015-00518, 2015 WL 5719630, found claims of the patent unpatentable as obvious.
Patentee appealed.

Holdings: The Court of Appeals, Chen, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] Board did not violate Administrative Procedure Act's (APA) notice and opportunity to be heard provisions by using
prior patent as part of its motivation to combine analysis in its unpatentability decision;

[2] Board considered ingredient's negatives as required to find that person of skill in the art would have been motivated
to combine ingredients in the manner claimed by patent;

[3] substantial evidence supported Board's finding that person of skill in the art would have been motivated to combine
ingredients in the manner claimed by patent; and

[4] patentee's proffered commercial success evidence was not probative of nonobviousness inquiry.

Affirmed.

"]

["

Novartis  AG  also  represented  by  JANE  M.  LOVE;  MICHAEL  A.  VALEK,  DALLAS,  TX;  ALEXANDER  N.

column1: Qingdao SeaLine Trading Co Ltd v US
name_numbers: ['Qingdao Sea-Line Trading Co., Ltd. v. U.S., 766 F.3d 1378 (2014)']
author: [' Reyna, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Reyna, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1]  Commerce  reasonably  concluded  that  best  available  information  consisted  of  prices  on  largest  grade  of  non-
contemporaneous whole garlic bulbs;

[2]  Commerce  reasonably  concluded  that  Wholesale  Price  Index  for  India,  as  primary  comparable  market
economy,  published  by  International  Monetary  Fund  (IMF)  constituted  best  available  information  to  adjust  non-
contemporaneous garlic prices;

[3] Commerce reasonably used financial statement of Indian tea producer to calculate surrogate financial ratio;

[4] substantial evidence supported conclusion by Commerce that financial statement from garlic processor was not best
available information for purposes of calculating surrogate financial ratio; and

[5] importer's failure to raise arguments before Department of Commerce constituted failure to exhaust its administrative
remedies.

Affirmed.

"]

column1: Therasense Inc v Becton Dickinson and Co
name_numbers: ['Therasense, Inc. v. Becton, Dickinson and Co., 745 F.3d 513 (2014)']
author: [' Rader, Circuit']
holding:
["s, LLC v. Bed Bath & Beyond Inc., D.Del., July 14, 2016

\xa0

745 F.3d 513

United States Court of Appeals,

Federal Circuit.

THERASENSE, INC. (now known as Abbott Diabetes Care, Inc.) and Abbott Laboratories, Plaintiffs–Appellees,

BECTON, DICKINSON AND COMPANY and Nova Biomedical Corporation, Defendants–Appellants,

v.

and

Bayer Healthcare LLC, Defendant.

No. 2012–1504.

|

March 12, 2014.

Synopsis
Background: Following remand in patent infringement case, 649 F.3d 1276, the United States District Court for the
Northern District of California, William Alsup, J., 2012 WL 1877895,denied alleged infringers' request for additional
attorney fees, and they appealed.

Holdings: The Court of Appeals, Rader, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1]  district  court's  determination  that  patentee  owed  alleged  infringers  attorney  fees  only  if  its  inequitable  conduct
judgment was “upheld on appeal” did not entitle alleged infringers to attorney fees on appeal and on remand;

[2] patentee's appeal from order finding its patent invalid for inequitable conduct and its petition for rehearing en banc
did not independently qualify as exceptional circumstances entitling alleged infringers to attorney fees; and

[3]  district  court  did  not  abuse  its  discretion  in  refusing  to  award  alleged  infringers  fees  and  expenses  for  pursuing
additional fees on appeal and on remand, and any fees for their appeal regarding fees.

Affirmed.

Dyk, Circuit Judge, filed opinion dissenting in part.

"]

[1] patentee's sales under clearly-communicated, lawful restriction did not confer “authority” to engage in use or resale
barred by restriction without infringing patent, and

[2] patentee's foreign sales did not confer authority to import item into United States or to sell and use it here, nor did
such sales waive patentee's rights.

Affirmed in part and reversed and remanded in part.

Dyk, Circuit Judge, with whom Hughes, Circuit Judge, joined, dissented and filed opinion.

"]

column1: Alcon Research Ltd v Apotex Inc
name_numbers: ['Alcon Research, Ltd. v. Apotex Inc., 687 F.3d 1362 (2012)']
author: [' Moore, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Moore, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] claims which taught use of therapeutically effective amount of olopatadine to stabilize conjunctival mast cells would
have been obvious over prior art, and

[2]  prior  art  would  not  have  motivated  person  of  ordinary  skill  in  art  to  try  0.1%  w/v  olopatadine  formulation  for
treatment of eye allergy.

Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

']

column1: Association for Molecular Pathology v US Patent and Trademark Office
name_numbers: ['Association for Molecular Pathology v. U.S. Patent and..., 689 F.3d 1303 (2012)']
author: [' Lourie, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Lourie, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] only competitor with unequivocal intent to resume clinical diagnostic testing of DNA sequences had standing;

[2] various organizational plaintiffs lacked standing;

[3] composition claims covering isolated DNA sequences associated with predisposition to breast and ovarian cancers
were directed to patent-eligible subject matter;

[4] claimed complementary deoxyribonucleic acids (cDNAs), which lacked non-coding introns in naturally occurring
chromosomal DNA, were eligible for patent;

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cAssociation for Molecular Pathology v. U.S. Patent and..., 689 F.3d 1303 (2012)
103 U.S.P.Q.2d 1681

[5] method claims for comparing or analyzing isolated DNA sequences associated with predisposition to breast and
ovarian cancers were not patentable; and

[6] method claim for screening potential cancer therapeutics via changes in cell growth rates claimed patentable subject
matter.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.

Moore, Circuit Judge, filed opinion concurring in part.

Bryson, Circuit Judge, filed opinion concurring in part and dissenting in part.

']

column1: Rovalma SA v BohlerEdelstahl GmbH And Co KG
name_numbers: ['Rovalma, S.A. v. Bohler-Edelstahl GmbH & Co. KG, 856 F.3d 1019 (2017)']
author: [' Taranto, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Taranto, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] Board did not sufficiently explain the basis for its obviousness determinations to permit Court of Appeals to resolve
substantial-evidence issues raised by patentee, and thus, remand for further explanation from the Board was required;

[2] Board did not exceed its statutory authority in inter partes review proceeding by relying on patentee's submissions in
determining that claims would have been obvious over competitor's asserted prior art and thus were unpatentable; and

[3] Board did not sufficiently explain the basis for its obviousness determinations to permit Court of Appeals to decide
whether  Board  violated  patentee's  procedural  rights,  and  thus,  remand  for  further  explanation  from  the  Board  was
required.

Vacated and remanded.

"]
lawyers_judge:

represented by THOMAS A. DOUGHERTY, Denver, CO.

Before Wallach, Taranto, and Stoll, Circuit Judges.

']

remand; and

Vacated and remanded.

']

column1: Intellectual Ventures I LLC v Erie Indemnity Company
name_numbers: ['Intellectual Ventures I LLC v. Erie Indemnity Company, 850 F.3d 1315 (2017)']
author: [' Prost, Chief']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Prost, Chief Judge, held that:

[1] agreement assigning listed patents did not transfer unlisted child patent to previous assignee;

[2] vacatur of District Court's determination that unlisted child patent was directed at patent-ineligible subject matter
was warranted;

[3] patent claims relating to use of index to locate information in computer database were drawn to patent-ineligible
abstract idea;

[4] patent claims relating to use of index to locate information in computer database lacked any inventive concept, and,
thus, patent was invalid;

[5] patent claims relating to accessing remotely stored data and files were drawn to patent-ineligible abstract idea; and

[6] patent claims relating to accessing remotely stored data and files lacked any inventive concept, and, thus, patent was
invalid.

Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cIntellectual Ventures I LLC v. Erie Indemnity Company, 850 F.3d 1315 (2017)
121 U.S.P.Q.2d 1928

"]

column1: Salem Financial Inc v US
name_numbers: ['Salem Financial, Inc. v. U.S., 786 F.3d 932 (2015)']
author: [' Bryson, Circuit']
holding:
["s USA, Inc. v. United States, D.Mass., November 13, 2015

\xa0

786 F.3d 932

United States Court of Appeals,

Federal Circuit.

SALEM FINANCIAL, INC., as Successor–in–Interest to Branch Investments LLC, Plaintiff–Appellant

v.

UNITED STATES, Defendant–Appellee.

No. 2014–5027.

|

May 14, 2015.

Synopsis
Background: Bank's subsidiary brought action seeking tax refund relating to complex financial transaction, known as
STARS (Structured Trust Advantaged Repackaged Securities), in which bank was a party. The Court of Federal Claims,
Thomas C. Wheeler, J., 112 Fed.Cl. 543, denied the refund claim, and subsequently denied bank's motion to alter or
amend the judgment, 119 Fed.Cl. 84. Bank appealed.

Holdings: The Court of Appeals, Bryson, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] trustee's private payments in STARS transaction, for which subsidiary incurred and paid foreign taxes and then
claimed foreign tax credits on its federal income taxes, were not tax effects, but were appropriately regarded as income
to subsidiary;

[2] trustee's payments lacked economic reality;

[3] trustee's payments lacked bona fide business purpose;

[4] loan portion of STARS transaction satisfied economic substance test and thus subsidiary was entitled to claim interest
deductions for interest it paid on loan; and

[5] imposition of accuracy-related penalties on subsidiary was warranted.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.

"]
lawyers_judge:
["

Before O'MALLEY, BRYSON, and HUGHES, Circuit Judges.

"]

column1: WiLan Inc v Apple Inc
name_numbers: ['Wi-Lan, Inc. v. Apple, Inc., 811 F.3d 455 (2016)']
author: [' Reyna, Circuit']
holding:
[" Corporation, N.D.Ill., July 20, 2018

\xa0

811 F.3d 455

United States Court of Appeals,

Federal Circuit.

Wi–LAN, INC., Plaintiff–Appellant

v.

APPLE INC., Defendant–Cross Appellant.

Nos. 2014–1437, 2014–1485.

|

Jan. 8, 2016.

Synopsis
Background: Assignee of patent, concerning wireless data communication technique, brought action against technology
companies  for  allegedly  infringing  patent  by  manufacturing  and  selling  products  complying  with  various  wide-area
communication standards. Following jury verdict finding non-infringement and that claims were invalid, the United
States District Court for the Eastern District of Texas, Rodney Gilstrap, J., 2014 WL 1347871, denied assignee's motion
for judgment as matter of law with respect to infringement, but granted motion of no invalidity. Assignee and companies
appealed.

Holdings: The Court of Appeals, Reyna, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] substantial evidence supported jury's verdict of non-infringement under the doctrine of equivalents, and

[2] district court's judgment as matter of law determination of no invalidity was based on impermissible post-verdict
reconstruction, rather than permissible clarification, of claim term “first computing means” in patent.

Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

"]

[1] term “substantially pure” should not have been construed to have same meaning in different patent claims;

[2] term “substantially pure” only applied regioisomeric impurities; and

[3] term “substantially pure” meant largely, but not wholly, the para regioisomer of the intermediate of the structure
shown, as compared to the meta isomer.

Reversed and Remanded.

Bryson, Circuit Judge, filed dissenting opinion.

column1: Sukumar v Nautilus Inc
name_numbers: ['Sukumar v. Nautilus, Inc., 785 F.3d 1396 (2015)']
author: [' Prost, Chief']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Prost, Chief Judge, held that:

[1] developer did not suffer “competitive injury,” and thus could not satisfy standing requirement under patent marking
statute;

[2] developer did not attempt to enter market to sell fitness machines, and thus could not satisfy standing requirement
under patent marking statute; and

[3] manufacturer's false marking of products with expired patents was not “immediate cause” under California law or
“but-for cause” under Washington law of damages allegedly suffered by developer, and thus developer did not have
viable unfair competition claims.

Affirmed.

"]
lawyers_judge:
['

column1: Arlington Industries Inc v Bridgeport Fittings Inc
name_numbers: ['Arlington Industries, Inc. v. Bridgeport Fittings, Inc., 759 F.3d 1333 (2014)']
author: [' Hughes, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Hughes, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] order was an interpretation or clarification the original injunction, rather than an appealable modification, and

[2] contempt order was not “final except for an accounting” within meaning of statutory exception to the final judgment
rule for appeals in patent infringement cases.

Appeal dismissed.

']

name_numbers: ['Move, Inc. v. Real Estate Alliance Ltd., 709 F.3d 1117 (2013)']
author: [' Lourie, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Lourie, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] accused interactive websites did not directly infringe patent and

[2]  standard  to  find  induced  infringement  required  that  accused  inducer  knew  of  asserted  patent  and  performed  or
knowingly induced performance of steps of claimed methods, and that all of those steps were in fact performed.

Vacated and remanded.

column1: Landmark Screens LLC v Morgan Lewis And Bockius LLP
name_numbers: ['Landmark Screens, LLC v. Morgan, Lewis, & Bockius, LLP, 676 F.3d 1354 (2012)']
author: [' Clevenger, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Clevenger, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1]  substantial  question  of  patent  law  had  been  presented  by  patentee's  claims  alleging  breach  of  contract,  legal
malpractice, negligence, and breach of fiduciary duty;

[2] patentability of invention invoked patent law sufficiently to sustain district court jurisdiction on claim of actual fraud;

[3] equitable tolling applied to limitations period on patentee's fraud claim; and

[4] patentee could suffer harm after issuance of reissue patent.

Reversed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

O'Malley, Circuit Judge, filed concurring opinion.

"]

["

Daniel E. Jackson and Steven P. Ragland.

Before BRYSON, CLEVENGER, and O'MALLEY, Circuit Judges.

"]

name_numbers: ['Personal Web Technologies, LLC v. Apple, Inc., 848 F.3d 987 (2017)']
author: [' Taranto, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Taranto, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] term “content-based identifier” meant identifier for data item being based, at least in part, on given function of at
least some bits in particular sequence of bits of particular data item, and

[2] Board did not sufficiently explain and support its conclusions.

Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

']

name_numbers: ['Bascom Global Internet Services, Inc. v. AT&T Mobility LLC, 827 F.3d 1341 (2016)']
author: [' Chen, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Chen, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] patent's claims were directed to the abstract idea of filtering Internet content, but

[2] the ordered combination of claim limitations revealed an inventive concept that transformed the abstract idea into
a patent-eligible invention.

Vacated and remanded.

Newman, Circuit Judge, filed opinion concurring in result.

"]

column1: Takeda Pharmaceutical Co Ltd v Zydus Pharmaceuticals USA Inc
name_numbers: ['Takeda Pharmaceutical Co. Ltd. v. Zydus Pharmaceuticals..., 743 F.3d 1359 (2014)']
author: [' Prost, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Prost, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] the term “fine granules having an average particle diameter of 400 μm or less” in patent for orally disintegrable tablet
meant fine granules having an average particle diameter of precisely 400 μm or less;

[2] the patent was not invalid for indefiniteness; and

[3] the patent was not invalid for lack of enablement.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.

']

column1: Cubist Pharmaceuticals Inc v Hospira Inc
name_numbers: ['Cubist Pharmaceuticals, Inc. v. Hospira, Inc., 805 F.3d 1112 (2015)']
author: [' Bryson, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Bryson, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] claims in patent were not limited to variant of daptomycin containing the L-isomer of asparagine;

[2]  claims  of  reissue  patent  directed  to  antibiotic  compounds,  compositions,  formulations,  and  methods  of  treating
bacterial infections were not invalid;

[3] claims in patents directed at administration of doses of either 4mg/kg or 6mg/kg given only once per day or once every
48 hours were invalid for obviousness; and

[4] patents directed to the purification of daptomycin compositions were invalid for obviousness.

Affirmed.

']

name_numbers: ['Gemalto S.A. v. HTC Corp., 754 F.3d 1364 (2014)']
holding:
['s: The United States Court of Appeals, Dyk, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] term “memory” meant all program memory;

[2] term “programmable device” meant a single semiconductor substrate integrating electronic circuit components that
includes a central processing unit and all program memory making it suitable for use as an embedded system; and

[3] patentee failed to establish infringement under doctrine of equivalents.

Affirmed.

']

column1: Genetic Technologies Ltd v Merial LLC
name_numbers: ['Genetic Technologies Ltd. v. Merial L.L.C., 818 F.3d 1369 (2016)']
author: [' Dyk, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Dyk, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] patent claim was directed toward law of nature, a patent-ineligible concept;

[2] physical steps of DNA amplification and analysis of amplified DNA to provide user with sequence of non-coding
region did not provide inventive concept necessary to render claim patent-eligible; and

[3] patent claim limitation, requiring analysis to be performed upon amplified, non-coding DNA to detect coding region
allele, did not provide inventive concept necessary to render claim patent-eligible.

Affirmed.

']

column1: Arctic Cat Inc v Bombardier Recreational Products Inc
name_numbers: ['Arctic Cat Inc. v. Bombardier Recreational Products Inc., 876 F.3d 1350 (2017)']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit, Moore, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1]  even  if  evidence  did  not  rise  to  level  of  teaching  away,  potential  hazards  of  prior  art  combination  provided
substantial evidence upon which jury could conclude that skilled artisan would not have anticipated success with claimed
combination;

[2] substantial evidence supported jury's presumed factual finding that claimed invention received industry praise;

[3] substantial evidence supported jury's presumed finding that claimed invention solved long-felt need for off-throttle
steering;

[4] substantial evidence supported jury's presumed fact findings regarding motivation to combine or expectations of
success;

[5] competitor met initial burden of production to identify unmarked products that it alleged should have been marked;

[6] after competitor carried its burden of production to identify unmarked products that it alleged should have been
marked, patentee had burden to prove that those products did not practice patent-at-issue;

[7] district court did not abuse its discretion in admitting damages testimony from expert for patentee that relied on
opinion of another expert for patentee to use competitor's later developed technology as value benchmark; and

[8] substantial evidence supported jury's willfulness finding.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cArctic Cat Inc. v. Bombardier Recreational Products Inc., 876 F.3d 1350 (2017)
124 U.S.P.Q.2d 1885

Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

"]

author: [' Prost, Circuit']

[1] patentee's litigation misconduct was sufficient to render the case exceptional under patent law's attorney fee provision;

[2] district court did not clearly err in making exceptional case finding; and

[3] district court's full award of attorney fees against patentee did not constitute an abuse of discretion.

Affirmed.

"]

name_numbers: ['Indacon, Inc. v. Facebook, Inc., 824 F.3d 1352 (2016)']
author: [' Stoll, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Stoll, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] terms “alias” and “alias term” were limited to textual expression;

[2] terms “custom link,” “custom linking relationship,” and “link term” could not be construed broader than disclosure
in patent specification; and

[3] terms “custom link,” “custom linking relationship,” and “link term” were limited to allowing each instance of a link
term to be identified and displayed as a link.

Affirmed.

']

column1: WiLAN USA Inc v Apple Inc
name_numbers: ['Wi-LAN USA, Inc. v. Apple Inc., 830 F.3d 1374 (2016)']
author: [' Chen, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Chen, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] patent term “specified connection” excluded embodiments where intermediary node can maintain only one specified
connection, and

[2] patent term “UL connections” corresponded to connections between intermediary node and its user devices.

Affirmed.

']

author: [' Taranto, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Taranto, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] Court of Federal Claims reasonably found that per-unit royalty, rather than one-time lump-sum payment, would
have been outcome of hypothetical negotiation;

[2] award of 10%-per-unit royalty was not clearly erroneous;

[3] Court of Federal Claims did not clearly err by not altering base of $5.4 million in revenue; and

[4] multi-component product analysis did not apply.

Affirmed.

']

column1: Secured Mail Solutions LLC v Universal Wilde Inc
name_numbers: ['Secured Mail Solutions LLC v. Universal Wilde, Inc., 873 F.3d 905 (2017)']
author: [' Reyna, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Reyna, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] claims in patents embraced the abstract idea of using a marking affixed to the outside of a mail object to communicate
information about the mail object;

[2] claims in patents did not contain an inventive concept sufficient to transform claims into patent-eligible application
of the abstract idea; and

[3] district court did not erroneously shift burden of proof on question of whether more than just industry-standard
technology was claimed by patents.

Affirmed.

']

column1: LaserDynamics Inc v Quanta Computer Inc
name_numbers: ['LaserDynamics, Inc. v. Quanta Computer, Inc., 694 F.3d 51 (2012)']
author: [' Reyna, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Reyna, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] patentee could not use entire market value rule to establish reasonable royalty damages against assembler;

[2] assembler had implied license to patent with respect to ODDs that were made by manufacturer to fulfill bona fide
orders from licensees and then sold to assembler by licensees;

[3] issue of whether end users of accused laptop computers directly infringed claim of patent was for jury;

[4] erroneous instruction was not plain error warranting new trial;

[5] date for hypothetical negotiation of license to be used in determining reasonable royalty damages was date on which
sales of accused laptop computers into United States began causing underlying direct infringement by end users;

[6] probative value of evidence pertaining to settlement in another case was substantially outweighed by danger of unfair
prejudice, confusion of issues, and misleading jury; and

[7] expert's opinion that reasonable royalty would be six percent of each ODD sold within laptop computer by assembler
was arbitrary and speculative, warranting new trial on damages.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cLaserDynamics, Inc. v. Quanta Computer, Inc., 694 F.3d 51 (2012)
104 U.S.P.Q.2d 1573, 89 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 348

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.

"]

name_numbers: ['Ferring B.V. v. Watson Laboratories, Inc.-Florida, 764 F.3d 1401 (2014)']
author: [' Lourie, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Lourie, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] competitor did not prove by clear and convincing evidence that asserted claims of patents for tranexamic acid drug
were invalid as obvious;

[2] competitor's ANDA submission and generic tranexamic acid product did not infringe asserted claims; and

[3] competitor's act of filing an ANDA, by itself, did not establish infringement sufficient to preclude consideration of
the ANDA specification and any amendments before the FDA.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

"]

column1: Energy Transp Group Inc v William Demant Holding AS
name_numbers: ['Energy Transp. Group, Inc. v. William Demant Holding A/S, 697 F.3d 1342 (2012)']
author: [' Rader, Chief']
holding:
[" A/S, 697 F.3d 1342 (2012)
105 U.S.P.Q.2d 1061

697 F.3d 1342

United States Court of Appeals,

Federal Circuit.

ENERGY TRANSPORTATION GROUP, INC., Plaintiff–Cross Appellant,

v.

WILLIAM DEMANT HOLDING A/S, WDH Inc., Oticon Inc., Oticon

A/S, Bernafon AG, and Bernafon LLC, Defendants–Appellants,

Widex A/S and Widex USA, Inc., Defendants–Appellants.

and

Nos. 2011–1487, 2011–1488, 2011–1489.

|

Oct. 12, 2012.

|

Rehearing and Rehearing En Banc Denied Dec. 19, 2012.

Synopsis
Background: Patentee brought action for alleged infringement of two patents related to technology for reducing acoustic
feedback in programmable digital hearing aid. The United States District Court for the District of Delaware, Gregory M.
Sleet, Chief Judge, 2008 WL 6060516, construed patent terms, and, after jury rendered judgment in patentee's favor, 2011
WL 2222066, declined to order new trial or relief from judgment that defendants infringed one patent, denied motion for
judgment as a matter of law of no willful infringement, and granted judgment as a matter of law of noninfringement of
second patent on basis that prosecution history estoppel barred finding of infringement under doctrine of equivalents.
Parties cross-appealed.

Holdings: The Court of Appeals, Rader, Chief Judge, held that:

[1] plain and ordinary meaning of patent claim term “programmed” was not limited to external or fixed programming;

[2] substantial evidence supported jury's determination that patent was not invalid for lack of written description;

[3] whether prior art rendered patent invalid for anticipation was question for jury;

[4]  substantial  evidence  permitted  jury  to  conclude  that  accused  devices  met  disputed  limitations  literally  or  under
doctrine of equivalents;

[5] district court did not act irrationally or arbitrarily in finding that report's probative value outweighed potential for
unfair prejudice;

[6] substantial evidence supported jury's award of damages, which thus did not warrant new trial; and

[7] prosecution history estoppel applied to bar assertion of infringement of patent under the doctrine of equivalents.

Affirmed.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cEnergy Transp. Group, Inc. v. William Demant Holding A/S, 697 F.3d 1342 (2012)
105 U.S.P.Q.2d 1061

"]

column1: Aspex Eyewear Inc v Marchon Eyewear Inc
name_numbers: ['Aspex Eyewear, Inc. v. Marchon Eyewear, Inc., 672 F.3d 1335 (2012)']
author: [' Bryson, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Bryson, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] reexamination of patent, which resulted in modified and added claims, did not prevent application of res judicata
doctrine to preclude instant infringement action;

[2] res judicata did not bar action with respect to accused products that were made or sold after patentee's earlier actions
against same competitors alleging infringement of same patent;

[3]  settlement  agreement  that  terminated  earlier  action  precluded  infringement  claims  only  with  respect  to  accused
products with specified design that were made or sold as of effective date of agreement, not accused products with new
design that were introduced after action was filed;

[4] preamble language in independent claims did not limit claims;

[5] term “magnetic member” included ferromagnetic materials;

[6] “rearwardly directed free end” meant the end of the arm that extended rearwardly from auxiliary eyeglass frame and
was not attached to the side portion of the frame; and

[7] “said arms and said pair of magnetic members adapted to extend across respective side portions of a primary spectacle
frame” meant that the arms and the pair of magnetic members were made to extend across the top of the respective side
portions of the primary frame.

Reversed and remanded.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cAspex Eyewear, Inc. v. Marchon Eyewear, Inc., 672 F.3d 1335 (2012)
101 U.S.P.Q.2d 2015

"]

column1: ClearValue Inc v Pearl River Polymers Inc
name_numbers: ['ClearValue, Inc. v. Pearl River Polymers, Inc., 668 F.3d 1340 (2012)']
author: [' Moore, Circuit']
holding:
[' Company, Defendants–Appellants.

v.

Nos. 2011–1078, 2011–1100.

|

Feb. 17, 2012.

Synopsis
Background: Patentee brought action against competitor alleging trade secret misappropriation and infringement of
patent  directed  toward  process  for  clarifying  water  and  wastewater.  After  sanctions  were  imposed  on  patentee  for
discovery violation, 242 F.R.D. 362, and sanctions were affirmed in part and reversed in part on appeal, 560 F.3d 1291,
jury returned verdict in favor of patentee on one trade secret misappropriation claim and on indirect patent infringement
claim. Competitor moved for judgment as a matter of law (JMOL) or new trial, and patentee moved for entry of final
judgment and to vacate sanctions. The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Texas, Leonard Davis,
J., 735 F.Supp.2d 560, denied motion for JMOL of invalidity, and granted motion for JMOL of misappropriation of
trade secrets. Cross-appeals were taken.

Holdings: The Court of Appeals, Moore, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] patent was invalid as anticipated, and

[2] competitor did not misappropriate trade secret.

Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

']

['

Umphrey Law Firm, LLP, of Tyler, TX; and Howard L. Close and R. Russell Hollenbeck, Wright & Close, LLP, of
Houston, TX.

Before PROST, SCHALL, and MOORE, Circuit Judges.

']

column1: Robert Bosch LLC v Pylon Mfg Corp
name_numbers: ['Robert Bosch, LLC v. Pylon Mfg. Corp., 719 F.3d 1305 (2013)']
holding:
["s: On referral by an appellate panel, the Court of Appeals, en banc, Prost, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] an accounting includes both the calculation of an infringer's profits and a patentee's damages;

[2] a jury trial on damages in a patent infringement case did not fall outside the scope of the accounting; and

[3] an accounting includes the determination of whether the infringement was willful.

Questions answered.

Moore, Circuit Judge, filed opinion concurring in part and dissenting in part.

Reyna, Circuit Judge, filed opinion concurring in part and dissenting in part.

O'Malley, Circuit Judge, filed dissenting opinion, in which Wallach, Circuit Judge, joined.

"]

column1: Pfizer Inc v Lee
name_numbers: ['Pfizer, Inc. v. Lee, 811 F.3d 466 (2016)']
author: [" O'Malley, Circuit"]
holding:
["s
Corporation, A Maine Corporation, Plaintiffs–Appellants

v.

Michelle K. LEE, Under Secretary of Commerce for Intellectual Property and

Director of the United States Patent and Trademark Office, Defendant–Appellee.

No. 2015–1265.

|

Jan. 22, 2016.

Synopsis
Background: Patentee brought action against the Patent and Trademark Office (PTO), claiming that the PTO failed to
calculate all of the patent term adjustment (PTA) for its patent for pharmacological method utilized in the treatment of
cancer. The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia, Gerald Bruce Lee, J., 119 F.Supp.3d 385,
2014 WL 10212543, granted summary judgment in favor of the PTO. Patentee appealed.

Holdings: The Court of Appeals, O'Malley, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] patentee did not waive its challenge to the calculation of PTA, and

[2] 197-day period that elapsed between the PTO's issuance of initial restriction requirement and mailing of corrected
restriction requirement did not constitute “A-Delay.”

Affirmed.

Newman, Circuit Judge, filed a dissenting opinion.

"]

for defendant-appellee. Also represented by Dana J. Boente; Kakoli Caprihan, Brian Racilla, Sydney O. Johnson, Jr.,
Nathan K. Kelley, Office of the Solicitor, United States Patent and Trademark Office, Alexandria, VA.

Before NEWMAN, DYK, and O'MALLEY, Circuit Judges.

"]

holding:

[1] Court of International Trade lacked jurisdiction over claims against sureties;

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

[2] producers did not qualify as third–party beneficiaries under new shipper bond contracts;

[3] judicial review was barred on challenges related to Customs' discretionary actions or non–actions; and

[4] producers failed to state various claims related to non–collection of over $700 million in duties.

Affirmed in part, affirmed on other grounds in part, and vacated in part.

"]

column1: McRO Inc v Bandai Namco Games America Inc
name_numbers: ['McRO, Inc. v. Bandai Namco Games America Inc., 837 F.3d 1299 (2016)']
author: [' Reyna, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Reyna, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] “first set of rules” in patents were limited to rules evaluating sub-sequences consisting of multiple sequential phonemes

[2] patent claims were limited to rules with specific, common characteristics, i.e., genus, rather than covering all rules; and

[3] patent claim was not directed to abstract idea, and did not merely invoke generic processes and machinery, thus
favoring patentability.

Reversed and remanded.

']

column1: Enzo Biochem Inc v Applera Corp
name_numbers: ['Enzo Biochem Inc. v. Applera Corp., 780 F.3d 1149 (2015)']
holding:
[':] The Court of Appeals, Prost, Chief Judge, held that claim stating that “ ‘A’ comprises at least three carbon
atoms and represents at least one component of a signaling moiety capable of producing a detectable signal” means that
the signaling moiety is composed of multiple parts, of which at least one is “A,” thus allowing only indirect detection.

Reversed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

Newman, Circuit Judge, filed dissenting opinion.

']

Appeal dismissed.

column1: Apple Inc v Samsung Electronics Co Ltd
name_numbers: ['Apple Inc. v. Samsung Electronics Co., Ltd., 695 F.3d 1370 (2012)']
author: [' Prost, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Prost, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] district court abused its discretion in determining that patentee sufficiently established causal nexus between alleged
irreparable harm and alleged infringement of patented unified search feature, and

[2] district court abused its discretion in determining that patentee established likelihood of success on the merits of its
claim that accused phones satisfied limitation for unified search feature that recited “a plurality of modules ... wherein ...
each heuristic module ... employs a different, predetermined heuristic algorithm.”

Reversed and remanded.

']

column1: Woods v DeAngelo Marine Exhaust Inc
name_numbers: ['Woods v. DeAngelo Marine Exhaust, Inc., 692 F.3d 1272 (2012)']
author: [' Linn, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Linn, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] competitor's purported supplement to interrogatory violated the discovery rules;

[2] district court did not abuse its discretion in excluding drawings disclosed by competitor as a sanction;

[3] legally sufficient basis existed on which jury could have found competitor's notched diffusers infringed patents; and

[4] district court did not abuse its discretion in declining to sanction exclusive licensee under Rule 11.

Affirmed.

"]

holding:

[1] competitor's use of patented process, which was reasonably related to submission of information under Federal Food,

[2]  remand  was  required  for  district  court  to  determine  whether  competitor's  post-submission  activities  constituted
infringement.

Vacated and remanded.

"]

name_numbers: ['Cisco Systems, Inc. v. International Trade Commission, 873 F.3d 1354 (2017)']
author: [' Reyna, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Reyna, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] “router configuration data” referred to in patent for network device, rather than “commands supplied by a user,”
was required to be “stored in said database;”

[2] ITC's exclusion order properly barred importation of components of importer's infringing products;

[3] substantial evidence supported ITC's determination that imported network device did not infringe patent for a system
to detect a change to a configuration of a subsystem in a network device.

Affirmed.

"]

column1: Dow Chemical Co v Nova Chemicals Corp (Canada)
name_numbers: ['Dow Chemical Co. v. Nova Chemicals Corp. (Canada), 803 F.3d 620 (2015)']
author: [' Dyk, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Dyk, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] Supreme Court decision in Nautilus, Inc. v. Biosig Instruments, Inc. changed the law, thus supporting determination
that change of law exception to doctrine of claim preclusion applied to permit Court of Appeals to reconsider whether
plastic patents were invalid for indefiniteness;

[2] Court of Appeals' original decision applied the law as it existed prior to Nautilus, thus supporting same determination;
and

[3] patent claims, the specification, and the prosecution history did not provide one skilled in the art with the scope of
the invention, and thus were invalid as indefinite.

Reversed.

"]

holding:

[1] relator satisfied the redressability element for Article III standing to challenge the AIA;

[2] the AIA was not a pardon, for purposes of constitutional separation of powers; and

[3] the AIA did not violate the common-law principle prohibiting the use of a pardon to vitiate a qui tam action.

Affirmed.

']

column1: Institut Pasteur And Universite Pierre Et Marie Curie v Focarino
name_numbers: ['Institut Pasteur & Universite Pierre Et Marie Curie v. Focarino, 738 F.3d 1337 (2013)']
author: [' Taranto, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Taranto, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] Patent and Trademark Office (PTO) was precluded from issuing amended claims for expired patent;

[2] Board committed prejudicial errors in determining claims of patent claiming methods for the site-specific insertion of
DNA sequences into chromosomes of living cells were invalid due to obviousness; and

[3]  patent  which  claimed  mammalian  chromosome  that  contained  group  I  intron-encoded  (GIIE)  endonuclease
recognition site was not so likely to succeed as to render the claims invalid due to obviousness.

So ordered.

']

column1: Dynamic D Geosolutions LLC v Schlumberger Limited (Schlumberger NV)
name_numbers: ['Dynamic 3D Geosolutions LLC v. Schlumberger Limited..., 837 F.3d 1280 (2016)']
author: [' Lourie, Circuit']
holding:
["s

Corporation, Schlumberger Technology Corporation, Defendants–Appellees

v.

2015–1628, 2015–1629

|

Decided: September 12, 2016

Synopsis
Background:  Owner  of  patent  directed  to  systems  and  methods  of  combining  seismic  and  well  log  data  into  a  real-
time, interactive three-dimensional display brought patent infringement action. The United States District Court for
the Western District of Texas, Lee Yeakel, J., 2015 WL 4578681, disqualified counsel and dismissed complaint. Patent
owners appealed.

Holdings: The Court of Appeals, Lourie, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] disqualification of in-house counsel was warranted;

[2] disqualification of patent owner's outside counsel was warranted; and

[3]  it  was  within  district  court's  discretion  to  dismiss  patent  infringement  action  without  prejudice  based  on
disqualification of patent owner's counsel.

Affirmed.

Wallach, Circuit Judge, filed a concurring opinion.

"]
lawyers_judge:
['

MICHAEL JAMES COLLINS, Collins, Edmonds, Pogorzelski, Schlather & Tower PLLC, Houston, TX, argued for
plaintiff-appellant. Also represented by JOHN J. EDMONDS, SHEA NEAL PALAVAN.

appellants. Also represented by MARC J. SCHNEIDER, TRAVIS PHILLIP BRENNAN.

represented by GABRIEL BELL, THOMAS J. HUMPHREY; TERRENCE J. CONNOLLY, New York, NY; ANN
MARIE WAHLS, Chicago, IL.

Before Lourie, Wallach, and Hughes, Circuit Judges.

']

column1: Massachusetts Institute of Technology v Shire Pharmaceuticals Inc
name_numbers: ['Massachusetts Institute of Technology v. Shire..., 839 F.3d 1111 (2016)']
author: [' Stoll, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Stoll, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] during prosecution of patents, there was no clear and unmistakable disclaimer of including skin in construction of
term “vascularized organ tissue”;

[2] during prosecution of patents, there was no clear and unmistakable disclaimer to preclude construction of term “cells
derived from a vascularized tissue” to include both parenchymal and non-parenchymal cells; and

[3] term “three-dimensional scaffold” was not invalid as indefinite and thus, according to its ordinary meaning, meant
“a supporting structure that allows cells to attach along its width, length, and height.”

Affirmed.

O'Malley, Circuit Judge, filed concurring opinion.

"]

name_numbers: ['Bard Peripheral Vascular, Inc. v. W.L. Gore & Associates, Inc., 682 F.3d 1003 (2012)']
author: [' Gajarsa, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Gajarsa, Circuit Judge, granted petition and held that, as matters of first impression:

[1] threshold determination of objective recklessness is a question of law based on underlying mixed questions of law
and fact and is subject to de novo review, and

[2]  ultimate  legal  question  of  whether  a  reasonable  person  would  have  considered  there  to  be  a  high  likelihood  of
infringement of a valid patent should always be decided as a matter of law by the judge.

Affirmed in part, vacated in part and remanded in part.

Newman, Circuit Judge, filed opinion concurring in the vacatur, and dissenting from the partial remand.

']

column1: Abbvie Inc v Mathilda and Terence Kennedy Institute of Rheumatology Trust
name_numbers: ['Abbvie Inc. v. Mathilda and Terence Kennedy Institute of..., 764 F.3d 1366 (2014)']
author: [' Dyk, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Dyk, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1]  obviousness-type  double  patenting  doctrine  continued  to  apply  even  after  the  Uruguay  Round  Agreement  Act
(URAA) where two patents that claimed same invention had different expiration dates, and

[2] later expiring patent that claimed to treat subset of patients with more severe rheumatoid arthritis was obvious variant
of reference patent that claimed treatment of rheumatoid arthritis patients generally.

Affirmed.

column1: Bayer Pharma AG v Watson Laboratories Inc
name_numbers: ['Bayer Pharma AG v. Watson Laboratories, Inc., 874 F.3d 1316 (2017)']
author: [' Moore, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Moore, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] district court clearly erred in finding that there was no motivation to formulate ED drug as an ODT formulation;

[2] district court clearly erred in finding that a person of ordinary skill in the art would not have been motivated to
formulate ED drug in an ODT using sorbitol and mannitol;

[3] district court erred in determining that the expected bitter taste and increased bioavailability of immediate-release
ODT formulation of ED drug would have taught away from an immediate-release formulation of drug; and

[4] patent for immediate-release formulation of ODT version of ED drug was invalid for obviousness.

Reversed.

']

author: [' Reyna, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Reyna, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] Commerce's decision to exclude India as surrogate country was supported by substantial evidence;

[2] that India had long history as serving as surrogate country to China did not restrain Commerce from considering
adequacy of other countries to serve that role; and

[3] Commerce's selection of Thailand over Philippines as surrogate country was supported by substantial evidence.

Affirmed.

"]

column1: Zoltek Corp v US
author: [' Gajarsa, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Gajarsa, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] statute waiving government's sovereign immunity from suit when an invention claimed in a United States patent is used
or manufactured by or for the United States, and United States has no license or would be liable for direct infringement
of the patent right for such use or manufacture if the United States was a private party created an independent cause
of action for direct infringement by the government or its contractors that was not dependent on patent infringement
statute; abrogating Zoltek Corp. v. United States, 442 F.3d 1345, and

[2] use or importation “within the United States [of] a product which was made by a process patented in the United
States” constituted use of the invention without lawful right within meaning of statute eliminating government liability
for patent infringement claims “arising in a foreign country.”

Reversed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

Dyk, Circuit Judge, filed dissenting opinion.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cZoltek Corp. v. U.S., 672 F.3d 1309 (2012)
102 U.S.P.Q.2d 1001, 87 A.L.R. Fed. 2d 559

"]

column1: Bancorp Services LLC v Sun Life Assur Co of Canada (US)
name_numbers: ['Bancorp Services, L.L.C. v. Sun Life Assur. Co. of Canada (U.S.), 687 F.3d 1266 (2012)']
author: [' Lourie, Circuit']
holding:
['s, LLC v. Hotels.com, L.P., Fed.Cir.(Tex.), December 5, 2014

\xa0

687 F.3d 1266

United States Court of Appeals,

Federal Circuit.

BANCORP SERVICES, L.L.C., Plaintiff–Appellant,

v.

SUN LIFE ASSURANCE COMPANY OF CANADA (U.S.), Defendant–Appellee,

and

Analect LLC, Defendant.

No. 2011–1467.

|

July 26, 2012.

|

Rehearing and Rehearing En Banc Denied June 13, 2013.

Synopsis
Background: Suit was brought alleging infringement of patents describing a system for administering and tracking the
value of separate-account life insurance policies issued pursuant to corporate owned life insurance (COLI) and bank
owned life insurance (BOLI) plans. The district court, 2002 WL 32727071, granted summary judgment of invalidity for
indefiniteness. Patentee appealed. The Court of Appeals, 359 F.3d 1367,reversed. On remand, the district court, 421
F.Supp.2d 1196, granted summary judgment of noninfringement. Patentee appealed. The Court of Appeals, 527 F.3d
1330,vacated and remanded. On remand, the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri, Carol
E. Jackson, J., 771 F.Supp.2d 1054, granted summary judgment of invalidity for defendant, and denied reconsideration,
2011 WL 1599550. Plaintiff appealed.

Holdings: The Court of Appeals, Lourie, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] asserted dependent system claims required “one or more computers”;

[2] asserted dependent computer-readable medium claims required “one or more computers”;

[3] independent method claims did not require implementation on computer;

[4] asserted system and medium claims were no different from asserted method claims for patent eligibility purposes;

[5] system and method claims were equivalent for purposes of patent eligibility; and

[6] claims in patents were not patent eligible.

Affirmed.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cBancorp Services, L.L.C. v. Sun Life Assur. Co. of Canada (U.S.), 687 F.3d 1266 (2012)
103 U.S.P.Q.2d 1425

']

['

With him on the brief was Charles K. Verhoeven; and Ian S. Shelton, of Los Angeles, CA.

Matthew B. Lowrie, Foley & Lardner, LLP, of Boston, MA, argued for the defendant-appellee. With him on the brief
were Aaron W. Moore and Kevin M. Littman.

Before LOURIE, PROST, and WALLACH, Circuit Judges.

']

name_numbers: ['Semiconductor Energy Laboratory Co., Ltd. v. Nagata, 706 F.3d 1365 (2013)']
author: [' Lourie, Circuit']
holding:

[1] claim seeking declaratory judgment that co-inventor violated assignor estoppel doctrine was not viable as matter of
federal law;

[2] state law claims that had been based on co-inventor's testimony repudiating his signature on patent assignment did
not invoke federal question subject matter jurisdiction; and

[3] district court did not abuse its discretion in declining to exercise supplemental jurisdiction over remaining state law
claims after dismissing purported federal law claim.

Affirmed.

"]

author: [' Moore, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Moore, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] there was no clear error in district court's decision that the isopropyl myristate in generic drug manufacturer's product
and the claimed triglyceride and lecithin performed substantially the same function, under the doctrine of equivalents;

[2] there was no reversible error in district court's finding infringement under the doctrine of equivalents did not ensnare
prior art;

[3] there was no error in district court's determination that prosecution history estoppel did not apply; and

[4] there was no clear error in the district court's findings with respect to objective indicia of nonobviousness.

Affirmed.

"]

name_numbers: ['Memorylink Corp. v. Motorola Solutions, Inc., Motorola Mobility, Inc., 773 F.3d 1266 (2014)']
author: [' Lourie, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Lourie, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] explicit acknowledgment of consideration in assignment was sufficient to show that consideration existed to support
sale, assignment, and transfer of patent rights;

[2] examination of adequacy of consideration was not warranted;

[3] transferor's fraud-based claims against transferee accrued when transferor reasonably should have concluded that
legal claim existed based on transferee having contributed nothing to conception of invention yet being included as co-
inventor on various documents relating to invention; and

[4] accrual of transferor's fraud-based claims was not delayed by alleged false statements and omissions associated with
inventorship determination by transferee's in-house attorney.

Affirmed.

"]

"]

column1: Toshiba Corp v Imation Corp
name_numbers: ['Toshiba Corp. v. Imation Corp., 681 F.3d 1358 (2012)']
author: [' Moore, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Moore, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] competitor's customers' use of unfinalized DVDs was substantial noninfringing use of manufacturer's patent directed
to writing of data onto DVDs;

[2] genuine issue of material fact existed at to whether customers' use of competitor's DVDs and devices directly infringed
on manufacturer's patent;

[3] district court improperly read a “purpose” requirement into claim requiring an optical disc's lead-in area contain
information identifying the structure of the recording medium; and

[4] genuine issue of material fact existed as to whether competitor's single-sided recordable DVDs infringed on patent.

Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

Dyk, Circuit Judge, filed opinion concurring in part and dissenting in part.

"]

column1: Tinnus Enterprises LLC v Telebrands Corporation
name_numbers: ['Tinnus Enterprises, LLC v. Telebrands Corporation, 846 F.3d 1190 (2017)']
author: [' Stoll, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Stoll, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] application of plain and ordinary meaning to term “attached” in patent was reasonable when analyzing patentee's
likelihood of success on the merits;

[2] it would review district court's determination that competitor failed to raise a substantial question that patent was
invalid for indefiniteness for plain error, rather than for abuse of discretion;

[3] competitor failed to raise a substantial question of patent's validity by arguing that patent claim term “substantially
filled” was invalid for indefiniteness;

[4] competitor did not show that patent was invalid as obvious; and

[5] patentee demonstrated irreparable harm as a result of competitor's allegedly infringing product.

Affirmed.

"]

name_numbers: ['Trading Technologies Intern., Inc. v. Open E Cry, LLC, 728 F.3d 1309 (2013)']
author: [' Lourie, Circuit']
holding:
['s, Inc., Defendants–Appellees,

and

Tradestation Securities, Inc., and Tradestation Group, Inc., Defendants–Appellees,

IBG, LLC, Thinkorswim Group, Inc., TD Ameritrade, Inc., TD Ameritrade

Holding Corp., and Interactive Brokers, LLC, Defendants–Appellees,

and

and

CQG, INC., and CQGT, LLC, Defendants–Appellees,

and

Futurepath Trading LLC, Sungard Data Systems, Inc., Sungard Investment

Ventures LLC, and GL Trade Americas, Inc., Defendants–Appellees,

and

Stellar Trading Systems, Ltd., and Stellar Trading Systems, Inc., Defendants–Appellees,

and

Espeed Markets, LP, BGC Capital Markets, LP, and Eccoware Ltd., Defendants–Appellees,

and

Rosenthal Collins Group, LLC, Defendant.

No. 2012–1583.

|

Aug. 30, 2013.

|

Rehearing and Rehearing En Banc Denied Nov. 27, 2013.

Synopsis
Background:  Patentee  brought  action  alleging  infringement  of  patents  for  trading  software  used  to  place  orders  on
electronic commodity exchanges. The United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, Virginia M.
Kendall, J., 852 F.Supp.2d 1027, granted summary judgment in part against patentee, and then denied reconsideration
and certified partial judgment for immediate appeal, 883 F.Supp.2d 772. Patentee appealed.

Holdings: The Court of Appeals, Lourie, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] remand was required for district court to consider whether claims drawn to non-“static” display satisfied written
description requirement;

[2] claims were not invalid for lack of adequate written description; and

[3] neither prosecution history estoppel nor prosecution disclaimer applied to continuation-in-part patent.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cTrading Technologies Intern., Inc. v. Open E Cry, LLC, 728 F.3d 1309 (2013)
107 U.S.P.Q.2d 2085

Reversed and remanded.

']

column1: Epos Technologies Ltd v Pegasus Technologies Ltd
name_numbers: ['Epos Technologies Ltd. v. Pegasus Technologies Ltd., 766 F.3d 1338 (2014)']
author: [' Hughes, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Hughes, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] term, “drawing implement,” in patents contemplating a device that attaches to a conventional marker, pen, or the
like, preferably a dry-erase marker, meant a writing utensil that can be used alone or together with the invention;

[2] term, “given time interval,” in patents related to a system developed to convert handwritten markings into a digital
image for display, storage, or further manipulation, could not be fixed at a few seconds or less;

[3] term, “marking implement,” in patent relating to digital pens that were portable and usable with any writing surface,
could not be limited to “marker” or exclude “pen tip”;

[4] term, “temporary attachment,” in patent directed to “graphic dataacquisition system” with “retrofittable apparatus
for converting a substantially planar surface into an electronic data capture device,” could not be limited to retrofittable
apparatus; and

[5]  inquiry  as  to  whether  competitor's  accused  products  infringed  under  equivalents  doctrine  could  not  be  limited
to  whether  accused  product  had  ultrasonic  receiver  or  transmitter  device  for  receiving  or  transmitting  intermittent
ultrasound signal, as claimed by patent related to presentation board digitizers.

Reversed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cEpos Technologies Ltd. v. Pegasus Technologies Ltd., 766 F.3d 1338 (2014)
112 U.S.P.Q.2d 1132

"]
lawyers_judge:
['

*1340   Deanne  E.  Maynard,  Morrison  &  Foerster  LLP,  of  Washington,  DC,  argued  for  plaintiff/counterclaim
Defendant-appellee. With her on the brief were Anthony L. Press, Hector G. Gallegos, Wendy J. Ray, and Christian

column1: Ford Motor Co v US
name_numbers: ['Ford Motor Co. v. U.S., 688 F.3d 1319 (2012)']
author: [' Reyna, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Reyna, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] CBP could not defeat jurisdiction under Tariff Act's grant of residual jurisdiction to Court of International Trade
over matters concerning enforcement and administration of, inter alia, duty assessment by simply creating new remedial
opportunity;

[2] complaint set forth proper grounds at time lawsuit was filed for Court of International Trade to exercise jurisdiction;

[3] merits of allegations of importer were ripe for review; and

[4] case or controversy existed over importer's complaint.

Reversed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

"]

column1: Shukh v Seagate Technology LLC
name_numbers: ['Shukh v. Seagate Technology, LLC, 803 F.3d 659 (2015)']
author: [' Moore, Circuit']
holding:
[" Company of the Cayman

Islands, Seagate Technology PLC, an Irish Public Limited Company, Defendants–Appellees.

No. 2014–1406.

|

Oct. 2, 2015.

Synopsis
Background: Former employee, a leading scientist in the field of semiconductor physics, brought action against employer
for correction of inventorship of disputed patents related to semiconductor technologies. The United States District
Court for the District of Minnesota, John R. Tunheim, J., 2013 WL 1197403, granted summary judgment in favor of
employer. Employee appealed.

Holdings: The Court of Appeals, Moore, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] concrete and particularized reputational injury can give rise to Article III standing to pursue a claim for correction
of patent inventorship;

[2] genuine issues of material fact precluded summary judgment on employee's claim for correction of inventorship; and

[3] employee's inability to obtain employment in the field of technology covered by disputed patents was a concrete and
particularized financial harm sufficient to create Article III standing for employee to pursue his claim.

Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

"]

['

David J.F. Gross, Elizabeth Cowan Wright, Aaron D. Van Oort, Charles Feeney Knapp, Jeya Paul; Calvin L. Litsey,
East Palo Alto, CA.

Before MOORE, WALLACH, and TARANTO, Circuit Judges.

']

[2] holder did not assume meaningful obligation to enforce or defend its design patents under licensing agreement' and

allegations in support of personal jurisdiction.

Affirmed.

"]

column1: Ericsson Inc v DLink Systems Inc
name_numbers: ['Ericsson, Inc. v. D-Link Systems, Inc., 773 F.3d 1201 (2014)']
author: [" O'Malley, Circuit"]
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, O'Malley, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] substantial evidence supported jury's findings that accused product infringed limitation over “service type identifier
which identifies a type of payload information”;

[2] term, “responsive to the receiving step, constructing a message field for a second data unit, said message field including
a type identifier field” meant responsive to the receiving step, generating a message field including a field that identifies
the message type of the feedback response message from a number of different message types;

[3] accused devices met “responsive to the receiving step, constructing a message field for a second data unit, said message
field including a type identifier field” step;

[4] competitor induced indirect infringement of method claim;

[5] accused products did not infringe claim requiring that “a transmitter command [ ] a receiver to a) receive at least one
packet and b) release any expectation of receiving outstanding packets”;

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cEricsson, Inc. v. D-Link Systems, Inc., 773 F.3d 1201 (2014)
113 U.S.P.Q.2d 1001

[6] jury was entitled to credit patentee's expert testimony over competitor's expert testimony to conclude that prior art
publication did not anticipate patent;

[7] competitor waived argument that the district court prejudicially erred by allowing patentee's counsel to reference total
cost of laptop when discussing requested royalty rate; and

[8] on issue of first impression, district court could not include all 15 Georgia–Pacific factors in its damages instruction
without considering their relevance to record created at trial and whether they were misleading.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

Taranto, Circuit Judge, filed opinion dissenting-in-part.

"]

to remotely manage their employees' mobile devices.

column1: Versata Software Inc v SAP America Inc
name_numbers: ['Versata Software, Inc. v. SAP America, Inc., 717 F.3d 1255 (2013)']
author: [' Rader, Chief']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Rader, Chief Judge, held that:

[1] jury verdict was supported by substantial evidence that accused software was capable of performing customer and
product hierarchies without added computer instructions;

[2] jury verdict was supported by substantial evidence that accused software used denormalized numbers in its pricing
tables;

[3] jury's award of lost-profits damages was supported by sufficient evidence of demand for patented product;

[4] jury's award of lost-profits damages was supported by sufficient evidence of quantum of patentee's lost profits;

[5] jury's award of royalties damages was supported by sufficient evidence of hypothetical license agreement; and

[6] district court's permanent injunction was overbroad.

Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

106 U.S.P.Q.2d 1649

"]

column1: Per Aarsleff AS v United States
name_numbers: ['Per Aarsleff A/S v. United States, 829 F.3d 1303 (2016)']
author: [' Wallach, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Wallach, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] phrase “shall not be registered as a subsidiary of a foreign company,” as used in solicitation, was ambiguous;

[2] but it required only that bidder register its company in Denmark, and did not require contracting officer to consider
ownership of bidder's company as criteria in making award;

[3] purported defect in solicitation was “patent,” rather than “latent,” and thus waived when not raised prior to award;
and

[4] solicitation requirement that government maximize purchases and subcontracts from Danish and Greenlandic sources
pertained only to post-award performance.

Reversed; Reyna, Circuit Judge, concurred and filed opinion.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cPer Aarsleff A/S v. United States, 829 F.3d 1303 (2016)

"]

column1: SCA Hygiene Products Aktiebolag v First Quality Baby Products LLC
name_numbers: ['SCA Hygiene Products Aktiebolag v. First Quality Baby..., 807 F.3d 1311 (2015)']
holding:
['s: On rehearing, the Court of Appeals, Prost, Chief Judge, held that:

[1] Congress codified laches defense in provision governing defenses to claim for patent infringement;

[2] laches remained viable defense to legal relief in patent law; and

[3]  court  had  to  weigh  facts  underlying  laches  when  considering  an  injunction,  however,  absent  extraordinary
circumstances, laches did not preclude ongoing royalty, rejecting A.C. Aukerman Co. v. R.L. Chaides Construction Co.,
960 F.2d 1020.

Reversed and remanded.

Hughes, Circuit Judge, filed opinion concurring-in-part and dissenting-in-part, in which, Moore, Wallach, Taranto, and
Chen, Circuit Judges, joined.

']
lawyers_judge:
["

column1: WBIP LLC v Kohler Co
name_numbers: ['WBIP, LLC v. Kohler Co., 829 F.3d 1317 (2016)']
author: [' Moore, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Moore, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] substantial evidence supported jury's presumed finding that a nexus existed between the objective evidence of non-
obviousness of patents and merits of claimed invention;

[2] substantial evidence supported jury's presumed finding that patents solved long-felt need for reduction in carbon
monoxide emissions from marine engines;

[3] substantial evidence supported jury's presumed finding of industry praise for patentee's claimed invention;

[4] substantial evidence supported jury's presumed factual finding that there was skepticism in the industry that low-
carbon monoxide marine generators could be produced;

[5] substantial evidence supported jury's presumed finding that competitor copied patentee's claimed invention;

[6]  substantial  evidence  supported  jury's  presumed  finding  that  objective  evidence  of  non-obviousness  of  patented
invention outweighed evidence of obviousness; and

[7] district court did not abuse its discretion in enhancing damages.

Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cWBIP, LLC v. Kohler Co., 829 F.3d 1317 (2016)
119 U.S.P.Q.2d 1301

"]

column1: Ethicon EndoSurgery Inc v Covidien LP
name_numbers: ['Ethicon Endo-Surgery, Inc. v. Covidien LP, 812 F.3d 1023 (2016)']
author: [' Dyk, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Dyk, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] Leahy-Smith America Invents Act (AIA) provision, prohibiting review of decision to institute inter partes review, did
not preclude Court of Appeals from reviewing patentee's challenge to authority of PTAB to issue final decision;

[2] PTO's assignment of the institution of inter partes review and final decisions to one panel of PTAB did not violate
patentee's due process rights;

[3] Director of PTO had authority to delegate the decision to institute inter partes review to PTAB, and thus AIA did not
preclude the same panel of PTAB that made decision to institute inter partes review from making final determination; and

[4] patentee failed to establish that commercial success of allegedly infringing surgical stapler resulted from claimed
invention, and thus commercial success was not pertinent to PTAB's determination that patent was obvious in view of
prior art.

Affirmed.

Newman, Circuit Judge, filed dissenting opinion.

"]
