column1: Frolow v Wilson Sporting Goods Co
name_numbers: ['Frolow v. Wilson Sporting Goods Co., 710 F.3d 1303 (2013)']
author: [' Moore, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Moore, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] sporting goods company's patent marking of certain rackets did not estop the company from asserting the rackets
were not covered by the patent;

[2] fact issue existed as to whether marked products were covered by claims of the patent;

[3] sporting goods company's payment of royalties on certain accused rackets did not estop company from denying that
those models were subject to the license agreement;

[4] fact issue existed as to whether rackets on which sporting goods company paid royalties were covered by the patent;

[5] patent owner's failure to identify accused rackets in a timely manner was not a proper basis to grant summary judgment
against patent owner; and

[6] patent owner failed to establish certain accused rackets met “horizontal and vertical strings” limitation of patent.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.

Clevenger, Circuit Judge, filed an opinion expressing additional views.

Moore, Circuit Judge, filed an opinion expressing additional views.

Newman, Circuit Judge, filed a concurring opinion.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cFrolow v. Wilson Sporting Goods Co., 710 F.3d 1303 (2013)
106 U.S.P.Q.2d 1089

"]

column1: Comcast IP Holdings I LLC v Sprint Communications Company LP
name_numbers: ['Comcast IP Holdings I LLC v. Sprint Communications..., 850 F.3d 1302 (2017)']
author: [' Chen, Circuit']
holding:
["s I LLC v. Sprint Communications..., 850 F.3d 1302 (2017)
121 U.S.P.Q.2d 1906

850 F.3d 1302

United States Court of Appeals,

Federal Circuit.

COMCAST IP HOLDINGS I LLC, Plaintiff-Appellee

v.

SPRINT COMMUNICATIONS COMPANY, L.P., Sprint

Spectrum LP, Nextel Operations, Inc., Defendants-Appellants

2015-1992

|

Decided: March 7, 2017

Synopsis
Background: Patentee brought action against competitor, alleging infringement of patents generally directed to use of
computer network technology to facilitate telephone call. Jury rendered verdict in favor of patentee. The United States
District  Court  for  the  District  of  Delaware,  No.  1:12-cv-00205-RGA,  Richard  G.  Andrews,  J.,  denied  competitor's
motion for judgment as matter of law (JMOL), or in alternative, for new trial, and added prejudgment interest to damages
award. Competitor appealed.

Holdings: The Court of Appeals, Chen, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] competitor was not prejudiced by court not construing phrase, “switched telecommunication system,” to exclude any
element of data-gram-based system;

[2] jury reasonably could have determined in its infringement finding that “a call destination” claim did not require
destination to be final point on path of call, but could be more than one destination;

[3] jury reasonably could have determined in its infringement finding that phrase “identifier of a second party” did not
require “unique identifier of a second party”;

[4] competitor waived any arguments for consideration on motion for judgment as a matter of law concerning how it
was prejudiced by broader construction of “parsing”;

[5] patentee did not exclude processes such as “mapping,” “lookup,” and “translating” from “parsing”; and

[6] prejudgment interest ran from earliest date of infringement for any patent issued at time of hypothetical negotiation,
and  thus  prejudgment  interest  did  not  have  to  be  apportioned,  although  some  patents  had  not  issued  at  time  of
hypothetical negotiation.

Affirmed.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cComcast IP Holdings I LLC v. Sprint Communications..., 850 F.3d 1302 (2017)
121 U.S.P.Q.2d 1906

"]
lawyers_judge:
["

MATTHEW B. LEHR, Davis Polk & Wardwell LLP, Menlo Park, CA, argued for plaintiff-appellee. Also represented
by ANTHONY I. FENWICK, GARETH DEWALT, DAVID LISSON.

THOMPSON, Raleigh, NC.

Before O'Malley, Reyna, and Chen, Circuit Judges.

"]

[2] advantage of resolving potentially dispositive issues at outset of investigation could not trump need for ITC to follow
its own rules and regulations; and

[3] two cease-and-desist orders did not create established practice sufficient to put public on notice that remedial orders
had to explicitly mention digital data for it to be covered.

Vacated and remanded.

name_numbers: ["Motorola Mobility, LLC v. International Trade Com'n, 737 F.3d 1345 (2013)"]
author: [' Rader, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Rader, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1]  substantial  evidence  supported  Commission's  conclusion  that  competitor  did  not  present  clear  and  convincing
evidence that operating system in prior art did not anticipate patent;

[2]  substantial  evidence  supported  Commission's  conclusion  that  competitor  did  not  prove  by  clear  and  convincing
evidence that asserted claims would have been obvious to one of ordinary skill in art; and

[3] substantial evidence supported Commission's determination that patentee's investments and employment satisfied
Tariff Act's domestic industry requirement.

Affirmed.

column1: Power Integrations Inc v Fairchild Semiconductor International Inc
name_numbers: ['Power Integrations, Inc. v. Fairchild Semiconductor..., 843 F.3d 1315 (2016)']
author: [' Chen, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Chen, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] substantial evidence supported jury's finding that patent for power supply controller chips that jittered or varied the
frequency of the chips was valid;

[2]  reasonable  jury  could  find  that  competitor  took  affirmative  acts  to  induce  third-parties  to  infringe  on  assignee's
patents;

[3] substantial evidence did not support jury's finding that patent claims were not anticipated by a prior patent for a
protection device;

[4] patent term “sampling a voltage from the auxiliary winding of the transformer and a discharge time of the transformer”
meant sampling a voltage from the auxiliary winding of the transformer when the transformer was discharging;

[5] substantial evidence supported jury's finding that patent claims for power supply controller chips were not obvious
in light of prior patents for a switched-mode power supply and for power supply controller chips that used frequency
jittering; and

[6] jury's finding of infringement under doctrine of equivalents vitiated requirement in patent claims that feedback signals
remain distinct.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cPower Integrations, Inc. v. Fairchild Semiconductor..., 843 F.3d 1315 (2016)
121 U.S.P.Q.2d 1087

"]

name_numbers: ['Cheese Systems, Inc. v. Tetra Pak Cheese and Powder..., 725 F.3d 1341 (2013)']
author: [' Rader, Chief']
holding:
['s & Finance S.A., Defendants/Counterclaimants–Appellees.

v.

Nos. 2012–1463, 2012–1501.

|

Aug. 6, 2013.

|

Rehearing and Rehearing En Banc Denied Oct. 8, 2013.

Synopsis
Background: Competitor filed declaratory judgment action, seeking declaration that patent involving commercial cheese-
making vats was invalid and not infringed. Patent owner counterclaimed for infringement and moved for summary
judgment. The United States District Court for the Western District of Wisconsin, Barbara B. Crabb, Senior District
Judge,  2011  WL  3739475,granted  summary  judgment  that  claims  were  not  invalid  and  were  infringed.  Competitor
appealed.

Holdings: The Court of Appeals, Rader, Chief Judge, held that:

[1] accused product literally infringed patent;

[2] patent was not invalid as anticipated; and

[3] patent was not invalid based on obviousness.

Affirmed.

']

column1: STCUNM v Intel Corp
name_numbers: ['STC.UNM v. Intel Corp., 767 F.3d 1351 (2014)']
lawyers_judge:
["

*1352   George  C.  Summerfield,  Stadheim  &  Grear  Ltd.,  of  Chicago,  IL,  filed  a  petition  for  rehearing  en  banc  for
plaintiff-appellant. With him on the petition was Rolf O. Stadheim. Of counsel was Steven R. Pedersen.

Robert A. Van Nest, Keker & Van Nest LLP, of San Francisco, CA, filed a response for defendant-appellee. With him
on the response were Brian L. Ferrall and Steven A. Hirsch. Of counsel on the response were Dan L. Bagatell and Chad
S. Campbell, Perkins Coie LLP, of Phoenix, AR.

Before PROST, Chief Judge, NEWMAN, LOURIE, DYK, MOORE, O'MALLEY, WALLACH, TARANTO, CHEN,
and HUGHES, Circuit Judges. *

PER CURIAM.

ORDER

A petition for rehearing en banc was filed by plaintiff-appellant STC.UNM, and a response thereto was invited by the
court and filed by defendant-appellee Intel Corporation. The petition for rehearing en banc and response were referred
to the panel that heard the appeal, and thereafter, the petition for rehearing en banc and response were referred to the
circuit judges who are authorized to request a poll of whether to rehear the appeal en banc. A poll was requested, taken,
and failed.

Upon consideration thereof,

IT IS ORDERED THAT:

(1) The petition for panel rehearing is denied.

(2) The petition for rehearing en banc is denied.

(3) The mandate of the court will issue on September 24, 2014.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cSTC.UNM v. Intel Corp., 767 F.3d 1351 (2014)
112 U.S.P.Q.2d 1294

DYK, Circuit Judge, with whom MOORE and TARANTO, Circuit Judges, join, concurs in the denial of the petition
for rehearing en banc.

NEWMAN, Circuit Judge, with whom LOURIE, O'MALLEY, and WALLACH, Circuit Judges, join, dissents from
the denial of the petition for rehearing en banc.

O'MALLEY, Circuit Judge, with whom NEWMAN, LOURIE, and WALLACH, Circuit Judges, join, dissents from
the denial of the petition for rehearing en banc.

DYK, Circuit Judge, with whom MOORE and TARANTO, Circuit Judges, join, concurring in the denial of the petition
for rehearing en banc.
In my view, en banc review is properly denied. The panel decision here in no way departs from the proper construction
of Rule 19.

Rule 19(a) provides the procedural mechanism by which a party can join necessary parties. It applies if, “in [a] person's
absence, the court cannot accord complete relief among existing parties....” Fed.R.Civ.P. 19(a)(1). It goes on to provide
that: “If a person has not been joined as required, the court must order that the person be made a party. A person who
refuses to join as a plaintiff may be made either a defendant or, in a proper case, an involuntary plaintiff.” Fed.R.Civ.P.
19(a)(2).

Rule 19 by its terms presupposes the existing parties' substantive entitlement to “relief” from another source of law. It
therefore does not authorize compulsory  *1353  joinder when the plaintiff has no substantive right to relief without the
consent of that person, i.e., where the right can be asserted only jointly, not unilaterally by the plaintiff. In that situation,
without the absent person's consent, the existing plaintiff has no right to “relief” to which Rule 19 applies.

A contrary view of Rule 19 would overstep the boundaries of congressional authorization. Procedural rules cannot be
used to abridge, enlarge, or modify any substantive right. 28 U.S.C. § 2072; see also Amchem Prods., Inc. v. Windsor,
521 U.S. 591, 613, 117 S.Ct. 2231, 138 L.Ed.2d 689 (1997) (“[R]ules of procedure ‘shall not abridge, enlarge or modify
any substantive right.’ ” (quoting § 2072)). Where, as here, there is a substantive right not to join in the assertion of the
plaintiff's claim, Rule 19(a) does not apply. Applying the Rule both to compel joinder as a party and on that basis to
allow assertion of the infringement claim, as STC.UNM argues, would abridge the rights of the joined party and enlarge
the rights of the initial plaintiff.

In other contexts, courts have read Rule 19 as authorizing involuntary joinder of plaintiffs only if the proposed plaintiff
is substantively obligated to join. Caprio v. Wilson, for example, explained that joinder of involuntary plaintiffs was
intended for circumstances in which there was a trust relationship between the plaintiff and involuntary co-plaintiff,
obligating the involuntary co-plaintiff to allow its name to be used in the suit. 513 F.2d 837, 839–40 (9th Cir.1975).
When that trust or contractual relationship is lacking, courts have declined to allow plaintiffs to involuntarily join other
plaintiffs. See, e.g., Diagnostic Unit Inmate Council v. Films, Inc., 88 F.3d 651, 654 (8th Cir.1996) (Arkansas Department
of Corrections could not be joined as involuntary plaintiff under Rule 19(a) because it “has no obligation, contractual or
otherwise, to allow the inmates to use its name to secure declaratory judgment relief” in copyright infringement action);
Caprio, 513 F.2d at 839–40 (Post Office could not be joined as involuntary plaintiff because there was no trust relationship
between appellant and the Post Office who each had an “independent right”); Coast v. Hunt Oil Co., 195 F.2d 870, 871–
72 (5th Cir.1952) (no involuntary joinder of partner with 51% interest under Rule 19(a)).

For these reasons, the decision in this case fully comports with Rule 19. That Rule, as its authorizing statute requires,
directs the inquiry to the nature of the underlying substantive rights. It does not alter the scope of those rights. It is
substantive patent law, not Rule 19, that answers the dispositive question here: whether one co-owner may unilaterally
enforce a patent, without the consent of other co-owners.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

2

\x0cSTC.UNM v. Intel Corp., 767 F.3d 1351 (2014)
112 U.S.P.Q.2d 1294

As to that underlying substantive-rights question, precedent has long provided a clear answer. This court has consistently
recognized that the substantive right to enforce the patent does not belong unilaterally to each co-owner, but requires
all  of  the  co-owners'  agreement,  so  that  each  co-owner  has  a  substantive  right  not  to  be  involuntarily  joined  in  a
patent infringement suit without such agreement. See, e.g., Ethicon, Inc. v. U.S. Surgical Corp., 135 F.3d 1456, 1468
(Fed.Cir.1998), cert. denied, 525 U.S. 923, 119 S.Ct. 278, 142 L.Ed.2d 229 (1998) (“[A]s a matter of substantive patent law,
all co-owners must ordinarily consent to join as plaintiffs in an infringement suit.”); Schering Corp. v. Roussel–UCLAF
SA, 104 F.3d 341, 345 (Fed.Cir.1997) (“Ordinarily, one co-owner has the right to impede the other co-owner's ability to
sue infringers by refusing to voluntarily join in such a suit.” (citing  *1354  Willingham v. Lawton, 555 F.2d 1340, 1344
(6th Cir.1977))); DDB Techs., L.L.C. v. MLB Advanced Media, L.P., 517 F.3d 1284, 1289 n. 2 (Fed.Cir.2008) (“[W]e
have explicitly held that Rule 19 does not permit the involuntary joinder of a patent co-owner in an infringement suit
brought by another co-owner.” (citing Ethicon, 135 F.3d at 1468)); Taylor v. Taylor Made Plastics, Inc., 565 Fed.Appx.
888, 889 (Fed.Cir.2014) (“If any co-owner should refuse to join as a co-plaintiff, the suit must be dismissed for lack of
standing.”) (citation omitted); Israel Bio–Eng'g Project v. Amgen, Inc., 475 F.3d 1256, 1264–65 (Fed.Cir.2007) ( “Absent
the voluntary joinder of all co-owners of a patent, a co-owner acting alone will lack standing.”) (citation omitted); Gal–
Or v. U.S., 470 Fed.Appx. 879, 884 (Fed.Cir.2012) (same).

The panel dissent and the dissents from the denial of rehearing en banc do not point to any case law that, contrary to
this consistent line of precedent, imposes a substantive obligation on a patent co-owner to consent to the assertion of an
infringement claim or, therefore, to join an infringement suit absent an agreement or implied agreement to join. Case law
indicating that Rule 19 is available to an owner to join a co-owner under circumstances in which there is an agreement
by  the  co-owner  to  join, 1   or  available  to  someone  who,  by  agreement,  is  an  exclusive  licensee, 2   only  underscores
the importance of absent owners' consent to joinder. Under circumstances in which a plaintiff has a contractual right
to unilaterally enforce the patent, Rule 19 unremarkably allows that plaintiff to join involuntary plaintiffs. Without
agreement, no precedent has held that a co-owner may be involuntarily joined. 3

Section 262 as long construed provides a foundation for the consistent conclusion that an individual co-owner has no
unilateral substantive right to enforce a patent, i.e., that another co-owner has a substantive right not to be involuntarily
joined in enforcing the patent. Section 262 provides that, absent agreement to the contrary by the patent holders, each
patent  holder  has  the  right  to  unilaterally  practice  the  patent.  35  U.S.C.  §  262. 4   That  right,  both  before  and  after
enactment of the provision, has been consistently interpreted to include the unilateral right to grant another a license to
practice the patent, see Shum v. Intel Corp., 629 F.3d 1360, 1369 (Fed.Cir.2010); Schering, 104 F.3d at 344; Willingham,
555  F.2d  at  1344  (“It  has  been  held  that  a  co-owner  of  a  patent  can  even  grant  a  license  to  a  third  party  without
consent of the other owners and neither the co-owner-licensor nor the third-  *1355  party-licensee is liable to the other
owners. Talbot v. Quaker–State Oil Refining, 104 F.2d 967 (3d Cir.1939); Bendix Aviation Corp. v. Kury, 88 F.Supp. 243
(E.D.N.Y.1950). See Aberdeen Hosiery Mills Co. v. Kaufman, 96 U.S.P.Q. 133 (E.D.N.Y.1953).”). If a co-owner can
unilaterally license third parties, it follows that such a co-owner may decline to sue for infringement, and another co-
owner may not unilaterally sue for infringement. Hence the longstanding recognition that “[o]rdinarily, one co-owner
has the right to impede the other co-owner's ability to sue infringers by refusing to voluntarily join in such a suit.”
Schering, 104 F.3d at 345.

Changing this court's approach would disrupt settled precedent of this court, which has not been drawn into question
by the Supreme Court. That precedent provides a clear definition of substantive rights that may, then, be altered by
contract. The value of stability is especially great for such rights. See Pearson v. Callahan, 555 U.S. 223, 233, 129 S.Ct.
808, 172 L.Ed.2d 565 (2009). Moreover, allowing involuntary joinder of co-owners might compel them to incur attorney's
fees, subject them to sanctions in exceptional cases under § 285, and disrupt established business relationships with the
defendant or related parties.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

3

\x0cSTC.UNM v. Intel Corp., 767 F.3d 1351 (2014)
112 U.S.P.Q.2d 1294

The rule against involuntary joinder is well established. Changing that rule would upset settled expectations. There is
no reason for en banc review.

NEWMAN, Circuit Judge, with whom LOURIE, O'MALLEY, and WALLACH, Circuit Judges, join, dissenting from
the denial of the petition for rehearing en banc.
The University of New Mexico (through its licensing arm STC.UNM) and the Sandia Corporation are joint owners of
the patents in suit, which STC seeks to enforce against Intel Corporation. A split panel of this court held that such an
infringement suit cannot proceed, because Sandia has not joined in the suit, and cannot be involuntarily joined despite
Federal Rule 19 and its provisions for involuntary joinder of a necessary party. The Rule includes:

Rule 19. Required Joinder of Parties

(a) Persons Required to Be Joined if Feasible.

(1) Required Party. A person who is subject to service of process and whose joinder will not deprive the court of subject-
matter jurisdiction must be joined as a party if:

(A) in that person's absence, the court cannot accord complete relief among existing parties....

....

(1) Joinder by Court Order. If a person has not been joined as required, the court must order that the person be made
a party. A person who refuses to join as a plaintiff may be made either a defendant or, in a proper case, an involuntary
plaintiff.

Rule 19 is not permissive—yet this court holds that Rule 19 uniquely does not apply in patent cases. The court today
denies STC's petition for en banc review, confirming this further removal of patent causes from the mainstream of the
law. I previously commented on this flawed direction, see STC.UNM v. Intel Corp., 754 F.3d 940, 947 (Fed.Cir.2014)
(Newman, J., dissenting), and write again to stress the constitutional and statutory and common law principles that are
violated by withdrawal of disputes from judicial resolution. When access to the courts is barred, a foundation of the
nation is eroded. The Court has observed:

Freedom of access to the courts is a cherished value in our democratic society.... The courts provide
the mechanism  *1356  for the peaceful resolution of disputes that might otherwise give rise to
attempts at self-help. There is, and should be, the strongest presumption of open access to all levels
of the judicial system.

Talamini v. Allstate Ins. Co., 470 U.S. 1067, 1070–71, 105 S.Ct. 1824, 85 L.Ed.2d 125 (1985) (Stevens, J., concurring).

The Federal Rules of Civil Procedure have “the force of a federal statute,” Sibbach v. Wilson & Co., 312 U.S. 1, 13, 61
S.Ct. 422, 85 L.Ed. 479 (1941). Here Sandia, as patent co-owner, is necessary to the infringement suit in order to protect
the defendant from separate suits for the same transgression. Sandia is within the district court's jurisdiction, is subject
to process, and can readily be joined.

The requirement that all co-owners must be included in a patent enforcement action flows from the common law, where
the Court explained in Waterman v. Mackenzie, 138 U.S. 252, 11 S.Ct. 334, 34 L.Ed. 923 (1891), that in order to protect
defendants from multiple suits by owners of “an undivided part or share” of the patent, all such owners should be included
in suit enforcing the patent:

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

4

\x0cSTC.UNM v. Intel Corp., 767 F.3d 1351 (2014)
112 U.S.P.Q.2d 1294

The  monopoly  thus  granted  is  one  entire  thing,  and  cannot  be  divided  into  parts,  except  as
authorized by those laws. The patentee or his assigns may, by instrument in writing, assign, grant,
and convey, either (1) the whole patent, comprising the exclusive right to make, use, and vend the
invention throughout the United States; or (2) an undivided part or share of that exclusive right; or
(3) the exclusive right under the patent within and throughout a specified part of the United States.

138 U.S. 252, 255, 11 S.Ct. 334, 34 L.Ed. 923 (1891); see also Indep. Wireless Tel. Co. v. Radio Corp. of Am., 269 U.S.
459, 474, 46 S.Ct. 166, 70 L.Ed. 357 (1926) (noting that joinder of all entities with a right of enforcement averts multiple
suits for the same acts).

In turn, the patent statute has codified the rights of joint owners of patents, each to have full enjoyment of the patent
right (absent contrary agreement). Such enjoyment includes the right to exclude. Article III states the judicial obligation
to assure these rights:

[U]nder Article III, Congress established courts to adjudicate cases and controversies as to claims of
infringement of individual rights whether by unlawful action of private persons or by the exertion
of unauthorized administrative power.

Stark v. Wickard, 321 U.S. 288, 310, 64 S.Ct. 559, 88 L.Ed. 733 (1944).

The Federal Rules state the procedural foundations of the processes of law. The unique exclusion of patent cases from
Federal Rule 19 is as peculiar as it is unjustified. See Provident Tradesmens Bank & Trust Co. v. Patterson, 390 U.S. 102,
88 S.Ct. 733, 19 L.Ed.2d 936 (1968) (discussing the criteria for necessary parties to litigation).

The Federal Rules of Civil Procedure are “in every pertinent respect, as binding as any statute duly enacted by Congress,
and federal courts have no more discretion to disregard the Rule's mandate than they do to disregard constitutional or
statutory provisions.” Bank of Nova Scotia v. United States, 487 U.S. 250, 255, 108 S.Ct. 2369, 101 L.Ed.2d 228 (1988);
see also, e.g., 28 U.S.C. § 2072; Shady Grove Orthopedic Assocs., P.A. v. Allstate Ins. Co., 559 U.S. 393, 406–07, 130 S.Ct.
1431, 176 L.Ed.2d 311 (2010).

The Federal Rules have consistently been applied to facilitate judicial dispute resolution, to settle legal controversies—not
to bar aggrieved persons from access  *1357  to judicial attention. “Under the Rules, the impulse is toward entertaining
the broadest possible scope of action consistent with fairness to the parties; joinder of claims, parties and remedies is
strongly encouraged.” United Mine Workers v. Gibbs, 383 U.S. 715, 724, 86 S.Ct. 1130, 16 L.Ed.2d 218 (1966); see also
Fed. Res. Corp. v. Shoni Uranium Corp., 408 F.2d 875, 877–78 (10th Cir.1969) (“To obtain this result [of an adjudication
binding on all interested persons] is the very purpose of Rule 19 and reflects the true interest of all litigants, both state
and federal courts, and, indeed, the public itself. Legal controversies should be settled, when possible, in whole and not
through multiple litigation.” (citing Provident Tradesmens Bank, 390 U.S. at 108, 88 S.Ct. 733)).

No justification can be found for withdrawing or excluding the co-owner of a patent from access to legal process. Section
281  of  Title  35  provides  that  “A  patentee  shall  have  remedy  by  civil  action  for  infringement  of  his  patent.”  Rights
in patent property as between joint owners are the rights of owners “in common,” Pitts v. Hall, 19 F.Cas. 758, 760
(C.C.N.D.N.Y.1854) ( No. 11,193); Clum v. Brewer, 5 F.Cas. 1097 (C.C.D.Mass.1855) (No. 2,909), and are enforceable
in accordance with the patent statute, the laws of property, and the procedural Rules of the federal courts.

In accordance with the common law right of owners in common, such owners are not liable to share their profits, see
35 U.S.C. § 262 (“In the absence of any agreement to the contrary, each of the joint owners of a patent may make, use,
offer to sell, or sell the patented invention within the United States, or import the patented invention into the United
States, without the consent of and without accounting to the other owners.”). The right to use and sell the patented

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

5

\x0cSTC.UNM v. Intel Corp., 767 F.3d 1351 (2014)
112 U.S.P.Q.2d 1294

invention necessarily includes the right to exclude others from the patented invention, in analogy to the right and duty
to avoid waste of property owned in common. See Edwards Lifesciences AG v. CoreValve, Inc., 699 F.3d 1305, 1314
(Fed.Cir.2012) (the right to exclude “is a fundamental tenet of patent law”).

The “proper case” for involuntary joinder of a plaintiff is predicated on a duty owed to the plaintiff by the party whose
joinder is sought. Cf., e.g., Sheldon v. West Bend Equip. Corp., 718 F.2d 603, 606 (3d Cir.1983) (“[W]e must ask, first,
whether [employer] had a duty to permit [plaintiff] to use its name to protect the rights asserted in the action....”); Caprio v.
Wilson, 513 F.2d 837, 839–40 (9th Cir.1975) (“[A]uthorization in Rule 19(a) to join a party as an involuntary plaintiff may
be invoked only when the party sought to be joined has a duty to allow plaintiff to use his name in the action.” (quotation
omitted)). For patent cases, to facilitate 35 U.S.C. § 281 (“A patentee shall have remedy by civil action for infringement
of his patent.”), Rule 19 implements the duty discussed in Independent Wireless, for joinder in an action brought by the
exclusive licensee arises because the patent owner

holds the title to the patent in trust for such a licensee, to the extent that he must allow the use of his
name as plaintiff in any action brought at the instance of the licensee in law or in equity to obtain
damages for the injury to his exclusive right by an infringer, or to enjoin infringement of it....

269 U.S. at 459, 46 S.Ct. 166. Likewise, patent owners in common have a similar duty to avoid waste of the property
they own in common. Rule 19 provides a simple procedure for implementing that right, while continuing to protect the
defendant.

*1358  This court holds that a party who is necessary to the action cannot be joined, and therefore that the action cannot
proceed. Yet our constitutional framework provides for resolution of property disputes through judicial attention. An
arbitrary rule that excludes enforcement of a property right that is owned in common, cannot be reconciled with the
principles of the rule of law. At a minimum, this ruling should be reviewed by the en banc court, not tacitly confirmed.

O'MALLEY, Circuit Judge, with whom NEWMAN, LOURIE, and WALLACH, Circuit Judges, join, dissenting from
the denial of the petition for rehearing en banc.
The panel majority “holds that the right of a patent co-owner to impede an infringement suit brought by another co-owner
is a substantive right that trumps the procedural rule for involuntary joinder under Rule 19(a)” of the Federal Rules of
Civil Procedure. STC.UNM v. Intel Corp., 754 F.3d 940, 946 (Fed.Cir.2014). It reaches this conclusion, however, without
adequately explaining the legal footing upon which it is premised. It fails to ground its holding in either federal common
law or the provisions of the Patent Act and ignores the mandatory nature of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure.

Several things are clear about Rule 19. First, Rule 19(a)(1)(A) provides that “[a] person who is subject to service of
process and whose joinder will not deprive the court of subject-matter jurisdiction must be joined as a party if in that
person's absence, the court cannot accord complete relief among existing parties.” Fed.R.Civ.P. 19(a)(1)(A) (emphasis
added). Second, Rule 19, like all other Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, is “as binding as any federal statute.” Stone
Container Corp. v. United States, 229 F.3d 1345, 1354 (Fed.Cir.2000) (“[T]he Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, like
the Federal Rules of Criminal procedure, are ‘as binding as any federal statute.’ ”) (quoting Bank of Nova Scotia v.
United States, 487 U.S. 250, 255, 108 S.Ct. 2369, 101 L.Ed.2d 228 (1988)). Third, again, like all other Rules of Civil
Procedure, Rule 19 applies in patent cases just as fully as it applies in all other federal civil actions. See, e.g., eBay Inc.
v. MercExchange, LLC, 547 U.S. 388, 393–94, 126 S.Ct. 1837, 164 L.Ed.2d 641 (2006) (rejecting this court's attempt
to develop a rule regarding the right to injunctive relief “unique to patent disputes,” holding that “the traditional four-
factor framework ... governs the award of injunctive relief”). And, finally, it is Rule 19—not substantive judge-made
laws governing joinder-that establishes the criteria for assessing joinder. See Provident Tradesmens Bank & Trust Co. v.
Patterson, 390 U.S. 102, 118 n. 13, 88 S.Ct. 733, 19 L.Ed.2d 936 (1968) (citing with approval to a commentator who
noted that “there is no case support for the proposition that the judge—made doctrines of compulsory joinder have

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

6

\x0cSTC.UNM v. Intel Corp., 767 F.3d 1351 (2014)
112 U.S.P.Q.2d 1294

created substantive rights beyond the reach of the rulemaking power”) (quoting 2 Barron & Holtzoff, Federal Practice
& Procedure § 512, n. 21.14 (1967 Supp.) (Wright ed.)).

Despite these principles, the panel majority concludes that there is a substantive patent law right which not only makes
a patent co-owner a necessary party to an infringement action, but prohibits involuntary joinder of that necessary party
and “trumps” the dictates of Rule 19. Careful scrutiny of the cases upon which the majority relies to create this overriding
substantive patent law right reveals, however, that it is predicated upon a series of misinterpretations and misstatements
of that purported authority. There is nothing, moreover, in either the panel majority opinion or the cases upon which
it relies  *1359  which explains why any such substantive patent law right would be powerful enough to overcome the
mandatory requirements of Rule 19(a).

I believe we should consider this case en banc to analyze whether there is any statutory or other foundation for the so-
called substantive patent law right to which the panel majority clings and, if so, whether it is that right, or Rule 19, that
provides the criteria for our analysis of joinder in this and other patent cases that come before us and the district courts.
I respectfully dissent from the court's refusal to do so.

I. RULE 19 IS MANDATORY

Absent  any  statutory  support  and  without  federal  common  law  authority,  there  is  no  source  from  which  the  panel
majority's alleged substantive right derives. Accordingly, we are required to apply Rule 19, and the panel majority's
refusal to do so violates the Rules Enabling Act.

The Rules Enabling Act provides that “[t]he Supreme Court shall have the power to prescribe general rules of practice
and procedure and rules of evidence for cases in the United States district courts ... and courts of appeals.” 28 U.S.C.
§ 2072(a). Those rules “shall not abridge, enlarge or modify any substantive right.” Id. at § 2072(b). Pursuant to this
statutorily-granted authority, the Supreme Court promulgated the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, which: (1) “have
the force [and effect] of a federal statute,” Bright v. United States, 603 F.3d 1273, 1279 (Fed.Cir.2010) (“In light of this
statutory promulgation scheme, the Supreme Court has held that the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure are deemed to
have ‘the force [and effect] of a federal statute.’ ”) (citation omitted); and (2) apply in all civil actions, see Fed.R.Civ.P.
1 (with certain limited exceptions, the Federal Rules “govern the procedure in all civil actions and proceedings in the
United States district courts”).

Rule 19(a) provides for the involuntary joinder of a necessary party. The rule states, in relevant part, that:

(a) Persons Required to be Joined if Feasible.

(1) Required Party. A person who is subject to service of process and whose joinder will not deprive the court of
subject-matter jurisdiction must be joined as a party if:

(A) in that person's absence, the court cannot accord complete relief among existing parties; or

(B)that person claims an interest relating to the subject of the action and is so situated that disposing of the action
in the person's absence may:

(i) as a practical matter impair or impede the person's ability to protect the interest; or

(ii) leave an existing party subject to a substantial risk of incurring double, multiple, or otherwise inconsistent
obligations because of the interest.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

7

\x0cSTC.UNM v. Intel Corp., 767 F.3d 1351 (2014)
112 U.S.P.Q.2d 1294

(2) Joinder by Court Order. If a person has not been joined as required, the court must order that the person be
made a party. A person who refuses to join as a plaintiff may be made either a defendant or, in a proper case, an
involuntary plaintiff.

Fed.R.Civ.P. 19(a)(1)-(2). By its terms, therefore, when a person satisfies the requirements of Rule 19(a), joinder of that
person is required.

If joinder of a required party is not feasible, Rule 19(b) provides that “the court must determine whether, in equity and
good conscience, the action should proceed among the existing parties or should be dismissed.” Fed.R.Civ.P. 19(b).
That analysis involves consideration of several  *1360  factors specified in Rule 19(b), including: (1) “the extent to which
a  judgment  rendered  in  the  person's  absence  might  prejudice  that  person  or  the  existing  parties”;  (2)  “the  extent  to
which any prejudice could be lessened or avoided”; (3) “whether a judgment rendered in the person's absence would be
adequate”; and (4) “whether the plaintiff would have an adequate remedy if the action were dismissed for nonjoinder.”
Fed.R.Civ.P. 19(b)(1)-(4).

We  have  determined  that  “[w]hether  a  party  is  indispensable  under  Rule  19(b)  is  a  matter  of  regional  circuit  law.”
Dainippon Screen Mfg. Co., Ltd. v. CFMT, Inc., 142 F.3d 1266, 1269 (Fed.Cir.1998). The Tenth Circuit applies a three
part test to determine whether a party is “indispensable” to an adjudication. N. Arapaho Tribe v. Harnsberger, 697 F.3d
1272, 1278 (10th Cir.2012). First, the court must find that the party is “required to be joined” under Rule 19(a). Id.
Second, “the court must determine that the required party cannot feasibly be joined.” Id. Finally, the court must assess
under Rule 19(b) “whether the required-but-not-feasibly-joined party is so important to the action” that it cannot “in
equity and good conscience” proceed in the person's absence. Id. at 1278–79.

Here, the district court essentially collapsed the three prongs of its Rule 19 analysis into one. The court found that:
(1)  Sandia  is  a  necessary  party  because  “substantive  patent  law  requires  that  co-owners  of  a  patent  be  joined  in  an
infringement action”; (2) joinder of Sandia is not feasible “due to substantive patent law, which allows a co-owner to
decline to participate in an infringement action”; and (3) Sandia is indispensable because to find otherwise “would be to
negate one of the rights of patent ownership: to block an infringement action by refusing to participate.” Memorandum
"]

the competitor's customers were acting as agents of or otherwise contractually obligated to the competitor, or that the
customers were acting in a joint enterprise when performing some steps of the patented method.

Affirmed.

Moore, Circuit Judge, filed a dissenting opinion.

column1: MobileMedia Ideas LLC v Apple Inc
name_numbers: ['MobileMedia Ideas LLC v. Apple Inc., 780 F.3d 1159 (2015)']
author: [' Chen, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Chen, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] Court could not second guess or reevaluate weight that jury gave to expert testimony to find that person of skill in
the art would not have been motivated to combine prior art references;

[2]  structures  corresponding  to  claimed  function  of  “means  for  processing  and  storing”  in  patent  on  camera  phone
encompassed only camera unit's processor and memory units;

[3] camera module in accused product did not infringe “means for processing and storing” limitation in patent on camera
phone;

[4] patent directed to display of call handling options in menu on mobile phone's display screen using one key was obvious
on basis of prior art that disclosed telecommunications system that allowed users to make and receive phone calls from
computer using two keys;

[5] patent describing method for allowing user to reject incoming cellular telephone call when user already was active on
another call by pressing a key was obvious on basis of protocols in global system for mobile communications standard;
and

[6] phrase, “controlling the alert sound generator to change a volume of the generated alert sound” by the “control
means” encompassed both stopping and reducing volume of alert sound.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cMobileMedia Ideas LLC v. Apple Inc., 780 F.3d 1159 (2015)
114 U.S.P.Q.2d 1001

"]

column1: Douglas Dynamics LLC v Buyers Products Co
name_numbers: ['Douglas Dynamics, LLC v. Buyers Products Co., 717 F.3d 1336 (2013)']
author: [' Rader, Chief']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Rader, Chief Judge, held that:

[1] claims in one patent required A-frame to support lift frame in both unmounted and mounted positions;

[2] term “connected to” in claim in patent was not limited to direct connections;

[3] accused snowplow assembly that included A-frame connected to support frame with support frame then connected
to mounting frame infringed patent on snowplow mounting assembly;

[4] patentee would suffer irreparable harm without permanent injunction;

[5] remedies at law were inadequate to compensate patentee at least for reputation loss that patentee had suffered from
competitor's infringement;

[6] balance of hardships factor favored patentee; and

[7] public interest factor favored patentee.

Reversed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

Mayer, Circuit Judge, filed dissenting opinion.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cDouglas Dynamics, LLC v. Buyers Products Co., 717 F.3d 1336 (2013)
107 U.S.P.Q.2d 1024

"]

lawyers_judge:

column1: AbbVie Deutschland GmbH And Co KG v Janssen Biotech Inc
name_numbers: ['AbbVie Deutschland GmbH & Co., KG v. Janssen Biotech, Inc., 759 F.3d 1285 (2014)']
author: [' Lourie, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Lourie, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] prior interference ruling by the Board of Patent Appeals and Interferences regarding priority and nonobviousness
lacked requisite finality for purposes of collateral estoppel;

[2] asserted patent claims for class of fully human antibodies that were defined by their high affinity and neutralizing
activity to known human antigen were invalid for lack of adequate written description;

[3] district court did not abuse its discretion in excluding evidence of interference proceeding;

[4]  district  court  did  not  abuse  its  discretion  in  trial  over  written  description  requirement  by  excluding  additional
testimony summarizing prosecution arguments made to PTO; and

[5] any errors with regard to obviousness issue were not prejudicial on issue of written description that was decided in
competitor's favor.

Affirmed.

O'Malley, Circuit Judge, filed opinion concurring in the judgment.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cAbbVie Deutschland GmbH & Co., KG v. Janssen Biotech, Inc., 759 F.3d 1285 (2014)
111 U.S.P.Q.2d 1780

"]

column1: NexLearn LLC v Allen Interactions Inc
name_numbers: ['NexLearn, LLC v. Allen Interactions, Inc., 859 F.3d 1371 (2017)']
author: [' Moore, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Moore, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] competitor's contacts predating issuance of patent were not relevant contacts for establishing specific jurisdiction;

[2]  competitor's  inclusion  of  Kansas  in  dropdown  menu  on  website  was  insufficient  to  establish  minimum  contacts
subjecting competitor to jurisdiction; and

[3] competitor's isolated offer of free trial to Kansas resident was insufficient to establish substantial connection with
Kansas to warrant exercise of specific jurisdiction.

Affirmed.

"]

"]

column1: Oplus Technologies Ltd v Vizio Inc
name_numbers: ['Oplus Technologies, Ltd. v. Vizio, Inc., 782 F.3d 1371 (2015)']
holding:
["s Corporation, Defendant.

No. 2014–1297.

|

April 10, 2015.

Synopsis
Background: Patent holder brought action in the Northern District of Illinois, alleging infringement of patents concerning
methods of video signal error correction and deinterlacing technologies. Following transfer of venue, holder's motion
to transfer the case back to transferor court for consolidation with holder's other infringement cases in multidistrict
litigation was denied. The United States District Court for the Central District of California, Mariana R. Pfaelzer, Senior
District Judge, granted summary judgment of noninfringement but denied an alleged infringer's motion for attorney and
expert witness fees. Alleged infringer appealed.

[Holding:] The Court of Appeals, Moore, Circuit Judge, held that District Court's order would be vacated and remanded
for reconsideration under lowered standard for awarding attorney fees.

Vacated and remanded.

"]

defendant-appellant. Also represented by Charles Christian Koole, Dan Liu, Mieke K. Malmberg.

Before PROST, Chief Judge, MOORE, and O'MALLEY, Circuit Judges.

"]

column1: Drone Technologies Inc v Parrot SA
name_numbers: ['Drone Technologies, Inc. v. Parrot S.A., 838 F.3d 1283 (2016)']
author: [' Schall, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Schall, Circuit Judge. held that:

[1] assignor was presumed to be correctly named as sole inventor on patents, and thus assignee had standing to bring
infringement suit in its own name;

[2]  district  court  abused  its  discretion  by  issuing  discovery  orders  compelling  defendant  to  produce  source  code,
specifications, schematics, and flow charts relating to accused products;

[3] considering relevant factors was prudent when analyzing whether district court abused its discretion in imposing
default judgment as sanction for defendant's failure to comply with discovery orders; and

[4] factors as to prejudice to assignee and availability of alternative sanctions outweighed other factors, and thus imposing
default judgment as discovery sanction was not appropriate.

Vacated and remanded.

Newman, Circuit Judge, filed concurring opinion.

"]
lawyers_judge:
['

Gene A. Tabachnick, Beck & Thomas, P.C., Pittsburgh, PA, argued for plaintiff-appellee. Also represented by Richard
T. Ting.

Jeffrey A. Lamken, MoloLamken LLP, Washington, DC, argued for defendants-appellants. Also represented by Sarah
Justine Newman, Eric Richard Nitz; James E. Hopenfeld, Singer Bea LLP, San Francisco, CA; Tammy J. Terry, Osha
Liang LLP, Houston, TX; John M. Whealan, Chevy Chase, MD.

Before Newman, Schall, and Chen, Circuit Judges.

']

column1: Amgen Inc v Sanofi
name_numbers: ['Amgen Inc. v. Sanofi, 872 F.3d 1367 (2017)']
author: [' Prost, Chief']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Prost, Chief Judge, held that:

[1]  evidence  showing  that  patent  purportedly  did  not  disclose  representative  number  of  species  was  relevant  to
representativeness question;

[2] post-priority-date evidence showing that patentee engaged in lengthy and potentially undue experimentation to enable
full scope of claims could be relevant to determining if claims were enabled as of priority date and should not have been
excluded simply because it post-dated the claims' priority date;

[3] finding of adequate written description could not be permitted merely from finding of ability to make and use;

[4] competitors were not entitled to judgment as matter of law (JMOL) of no written description and no enablement; and

[5] patents were not obvious.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

"]

column1: Icon Health and Fitness Inc v Strava Inc
name_numbers: ['Icon Health and Fitness, Inc. v. Strava, Inc., 849 F.3d 1034 (2017)']
author: [' Wallach, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Wallach, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] Court of Appeals would consider challenger's arguments regarding patent examiner's purported reliance on expert's
declarations during review of patent;

[2] PTAB's decision affirming patent examiner's obviousness rejection of claims reciting cradle that included electrical
contacts was not supported by substantial evidence;

[3] PTAB's decision affirming patent examiner's obviousness rejection of claim reciting cradle that included infrared (IR)
interface was supported by substantial evidence; and

[4] PTAB's decision affirming patent examiner's obviousness rejection of claims reciting portable first computing device
was supported by substantial evidence.

Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

O'Malley, Circuit Judge, filed an opinion concurring in part and dissenting in part.

"]
lawyers_judge:
["

LARRY R. LAYCOCK, Maschoff Brennan Laycock Gilmore Israelsen & Wright, Salt Lake City, UT, argued for

City, UT.

L. CUTLER, DOUGLAS ALAN ROBINSON, St. Louis, MO.

Before O'Malley, Reyna, and Wallach, Circuit Judges.

"]

author: [' Moore, Circuit']
holding:

[1] falsehoods in inventor's original declaration supported a finding of materiality on inequitable conduct claim, and

[2] district court did not clearly err in concluding inventor's conduct satisfied the intent element of inequitable conduct
claim.

Affirmed.

"]

name_numbers: ['Accent Packaging, Inc. v. Leggett & Platt, Inc., 707 F.3d 1318 (2013)']
author: [' Prost, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Prost, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] elongated operator body could be operably coupled to one or more operator elements;

[2] use of screws did not, by itself, evidence instruction or intention that accused product be altered or dissembled in
any way prior to operation;

[3] assignee was not entitled to additional discovery prior to summary judgment; and

[4] specifications and tolerances of patented baling device were not trade secrets.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.

']

name_numbers: ['Perfect Surgical Techniques, Inc. v. Olympus America, Inc., 841 F.3d 1004 (2016)']
author: [' Moore, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Moore, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] any error in accepting competitor's submission of Japanese patent as prior art was harmless;

[2] remand was required to allow Board to consider whether evidence, considered as a whole and under a rule of reason,
collectively corroborated inventor's testimony that he worked reasonably continuously to reduce to practice; and

[3] patent term “perforated” was not coextensive with or the same as “passages.”

Vacated and remanded.

"]

column1: Novartis AG v Lee
name_numbers: ['Novartis AG v. Lee, 740 F.3d 593 (2014)']
author: [' Taranto, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Taranto, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] statute governing challenges to PTA determinations applies to final adjustment announced at issuance;

[2] patent owner was not entitled to equitable tolling of statute of limitations for challenges to PTA determinations;

[3]  time  spent  in  a  continued  examination  does  not  deplete  PTO's  three-year  statutory  allotment  for  application
processing; and

[4] time after allowance of patent owner's request for continued examination counted toward depletion of PTO's three-
year statutory allotment for application processing.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.

"]

column1: Abbott Laboratories v Cordis Corp
name_numbers: ['Abbott Laboratories v. Cordis Corp., 710 F.3d 1318 (2013)']
author: [' Dyk, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Dyk, Circuit Judge, held that: as matter of first impression,

[1] district courts may issue subpoenas only in patent proceedings for which the Patent and Trademark Office (PTO) has
authorized parties to present evidence by means of depositions;

[2]  inter  partes  patent  reexamination  proceedings  are  not  “contested  cases”  within  meaning  of  statute  authorizing  a
district court to issue subpoenas duces tecum; and

[3] excluding compulsory production of testimony in inter partes patent reexamination proceedings did not raise serious
due process concerns.

Affirmed.

']

column1: Promega Corp v Life Technologies Corp
name_numbers: ['Promega Corp. v. Life Technologies Corp., 773 F.3d 1338 (2014)']
author: [' Chen, Circuit']
holding:
["s,

Inc., and Applied Biosystems, LLC, Defendants–Appellants.

v.

Nos. 2013–1011, 2013–1029, 2013–1376.

|

Dec. 15, 2014.

Synopsis
Background:  Patentee  and  exclusive  licensee  commenced  action  against  competitor,  alleging  infringement  of  patents
directed toward process for examining polymorphism in samples of deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA). The United States
District Court for the Western District of Wisconsin, Barbara B. Crabb, Chief Judge, granted plaintiff's motion for
summary judgment of infringement for some patents, and subsequently granted defendant's motion for judgment as
matter of law (JMOL) that its accused products did not infringe other patent after jury verdict in plaintiff's favor. Parties
appealed.

Holdings: The Court of Appeals, Chen, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] some patents were invalid for lack of enablement;

[2] involvement of third-party was not required “to actively induce the combination” of components of patented invention
outside the United States;

[3] export of single component was sufficient for liability to attach;

[4] polymerizing enzyme supplied by competitor from United States to its foreign facility was “substantial portion” of
components of competitor's accused genetic testing kits;

[5] competitor was liable for accused kits that had been made, used, or sold in United States infringe that did infringe
patent; and

[6] limited field-of-use license on patent for “forensics and paternity” did not cover sales of accused kits for forensic
research, education, and training at universities and other non-law enforcement bodies.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

Prost, Chief Judge, filed opinion dissenting-in-part.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cPromega Corp. v. Life Technologies Corp., 773 F.3d 1338 (2014)
113 U.S.P.Q.2d 1181

"]
lawyers_judge:
['

appellant. With him on the brief were Thomas G. Saunders and Dina B. Mishra; and Mark C. Fleming, Proshanto

column1: Jack Wolfskin Ausrustung Fur Draussen GmbH And Co KGAA v New Millennium Sp
name_numbers: ['Jack Wolfskin Ausrustung Fur Draussen GmbH & Co. KGAA..., 797 F.3d 1363 (2015)']
author: [' Chen, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Chen, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] as matter of apparent first impression, when a trademark owner uses a modified version of its registered trademark,
it may avoid abandonment of the original mark only if the modified version creates the same, continuous commercial
impression;

[2] substantial evidence supported Board's finding that trademark holder did not abandon its registered mark;

[3] substantial evidence did not support Board's conclusion that the “similarity of the marks” factor supported finding
likelihood of confusion;

[4]  substantial  evidence  did  not  support  Board's  conclusion  that  the  “other  marks  in  use”  factor  was  neutral  when
determining whether consumers would likely be confused; and

[5] there was no likelihood that consumers would confuse registered trademark with applied-for mark.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.

"]
lawyers_judge:

Philip Bautista, Taft, Stettinius & Hollister, LLP, Cleveland, OH, argued for appellee.

Before LOURIE, BRYSON, and CHEN, Circuit Judges.

']

column1: HP Inc v MPHJ Technology Inv LLC
name_numbers: ['HP Inc. v. MPHJ Technology Inv., LLC, 817 F.3d 1339 (2016)']
author: [' Lourie, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Lourie, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] substantial evidence supported Board's finding that user's guide for petitioner's document scanner did not anticipate
claim requiring a list of available modules;

[2] Court of Appeals was barred from reviewing Board's refusal to institute inter partes review of petitioner's contention
that patent was unpatentable as obvious;

[3] fact that Board instituted review of petitioner's contention that patent was unpatentable as anticipated, did not require
Board to review all grounds presented by petitioner;

[4] Administrative Procedure Act (APA) did not require Board to address noninstituted grounds asserted in petitioner's
petition for review;

[5] Court of Appeals was barred from reviewing whether Board sufficiently articulated its reasons for finding that it
would be redundant to review petitioner's contention that patent was unpatentable as obvious; and

[6] petitioner was not estopped from raising, in a subsequent court or Board proceeding, its contention that patent was
unpatentable as obvious.

Affirmed.

"]

column1: Alps South LLC v Ohio Willow Wood Co
name_numbers: ['Alps South, LLC v. Ohio Willow Wood Co., 787 F.3d 1379 (2015)']
author: [' Chen, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Chen, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] license agreement, which restricted licensee's rights in patent to the field of prosthetic products, did not convey all
substantial rights in the patent to licensee, and thus licensee lacked standing to sue for infringement without naming
licensor as co-plaintiff;

[2] nunc pro tunc amended license agreement was insufficient to cure licensee's lack of standing; and

[3] licensee could not avail itself of statute, allowing parties to amend their complaints to correct defective allegations of
jurisdiction did not, to amend jurisdictional allegations in its original complaint for patent infringement.

Reversed and remanded.

"]

column1: Astornet Technologies Inc v BAE Systems Inc
name_numbers: ['Astornet Technologies Inc. v. BAE Systems, Inc., 802 F.3d 1271 (2015)']
author: [' Taranto, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Taranto, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] federal jurisdiction statute, providing cause of action against United States for its use of patented invention, applied to
action, and thus licensee's exclusive remedy for alleged infringement was suit against United States in Court of Federal
Claims;

[2] district court's focus on facts that would justify piercing corporate veil of corporate subsidiary was too narrow to
support dismissal of action against parent corporation; and

[3] two-dismissal rule, which treated certain dismissals as adjudications on the merits, did not preclude licensee from
bringing action following its alleged dismissal of its earlier action and patent owner's dismissal of earlier action.

Affirmed.

"]

International Trade's residual jurisdiction to permit court to hear its suit, and

and Border Protection beyond the two year time period.

Affirmed.

"]

to determine amount of attorneys' fees by considering administrative nature of work, low level of skill involved, and fee

column1: Taurus IP LLC v DaimlerChrysler Corp
name_numbers: ['Taurus IP, LLC v. DaimlerChrysler Corp., 726 F.3d 1306 (2013)']
author: [' Schall, Circuit']
holding:
[", LLC, Defendant,

and

Mercedes–Benz USA, Inc. and Chrysler Group LLC, Defendants/Third Party Plaintiffs–Cross Appellants.

Nos. 2008–1462, 2008–1463, 2008–1464, 2008–1465.

|

Aug. 9, 2013.

Synopsis
Background: Patentee brought actions against various defendants, alleging defendants' external websites infringed claims
of patent relating to a computer system for managing product knowledge related to products offered for sale by a selling
entity. Certain defendants asserted a breach of contract counterclaim against patentee, and filed a contract claim against
third-party  defendants,  alleging  that,  by  filing  the  infringement  suit,  patentee  and/or  certain  third-party  defendants
violated various provisions of a patent licensing agreement to settle two prior patent infringement suits. The United States
District Court for the Western District of Wisconsin, Barbara B. Crabb, J., denied third-party defendants' motion to
dismiss, 519 F.Supp.2d 905, construed the relevant claim terms, 2007 WL 5601495, entered summary judgment finding
that accused websites did not infringe the asserted claims, and granted in part and denied in part motions for summary
judgment on the breach of contract claims, 534 F.Supp.2d 849, and awarded damages against patentee under patent
law's attorney fee provision, 559 F.Supp.2d 947. Various appeals were brought.

Holdings: The Court of Appeals, Schall, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] prior art patent anticipated certain asserted patent claims;

[2] patentee's infringement suit was exceptional, warranting award of attorney fees;

[3] piercing the corporate veil to assert personal jurisdiction over patentee's owner was appropriate;

[4] reverse piercing the corporate veil to assert personal jurisdiction over limited liability company (LLC) succeeding the
entity that assigned the patent to patentee was appropriate;

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cTaurus IP, LLC v. DaimlerChrysler Corp., 726 F.3d 1306 (2013)
111 U.S.P.Q.2d 1662

[5] district court provided sanctioned parties necessary notice and opportunity to be heard to satisfy due process.

Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

"]

column1: SanDisk Corp v Kingston Technology Co Inc
name_numbers: ['SanDisk Corp. v. Kingston Technology Co., Inc., 695 F.3d 1348 (2012)']
author: [' Prost, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Prost, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] “recording a relative time of programming (3)27” limitation did not exclude “Block Recording Method,” or require
the recording of an actual time;

[2] “at least a user data portion and an overhead portion” limitation covered one or more user data portion and overhead
portion;

[3] patentee did not dedicate to the public proposed equivalent to “programming (3)27 a logical page address associated
with the original data” limitation;

[4] there was no evidence that one of the patents was literally infringed; and

[5] patentee did not dedicate to the public proposed equivalent to claimed controller.

Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

Reyna, Circuit Judge, filed an opinion concurring in part and dissenting in part.

']

column1: Golden Bridge Technology Inc v Apple Inc
name_numbers: ['Golden Bridge Technology, Inc. v. Apple Inc., 758 F.3d 1362 (2014)']
author: [' Moore, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Moore, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] the patentee's submission of a stipulated construction in an information disclosure statement constituted disclaimer;

[2] term “preamble” meant a signal used for communication with the base station that is spread before transmission and
that is without message data;

[3]  the  manufacturer's  spreading  of  a  physical  random  access  channel  (PRACH)  preamble  during  generation  of  the
preamble did not infringe on the patent; and

[4] the patentee waived its infringement claim based on the use of a signature sequence alone.

Affirmed.

"]

column1: Trireme Medical LLC v AngioScore Inc
name_numbers: ['Trireme Medical, LLC v. AngioScore, Inc., 812 F.3d 1050 (2016)']
author: [' Dyk, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Dyk, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1]  provision  in  consulting  agreement,  which  required  consultant  to  list  any  prior  inventions,  did  not  provide  for
assignment of consultant's rights, and thus consultant's failure to list study related to patents as prior invention did not
result in assignment of his rights to patentee;

[2] estoppel by contract did not bind licensee to consultant's representation under consulting agreement that he owned
no rights in patentee's prototype; and

[3] whether consultant's continued work on angioplasty balloon catheters after effective date of consulting agreement
amounted to developing or reducing to practice an invention, within meaning of the agreement, such that consultant
assigned all rights in patents to patentee, was issue of fact that could not be resolved on motion to dismiss.

Reversed and remanded.

"]

']

column1: Mukand Ltd v US
author: [' Reyna, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Reyna, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] substantial evidence supported decision by Commerce to resort to facts otherwise available and to apply adverse
inference against importer due to its repeated failures to provide requested size-specific cost data;

[2]  substantial  evidence  supported  decision  by  Commerce  to  adopt  adverse  inference  against  importer  for  failure  to
cooperate to best of its ability when responding to Commerce's requests for cost accounting records on basis of product
size;

[3] Commerce reasonably expected more accurate and responsive answers from importer; and

[4] substantial evidence supported decision by Commerce to rely on total AFA.

Affirmed.

"]

column1: IPCom GmbH And Co v HTC Corporation
name_numbers: ['IPCom GmbH & Co. v. HTC Corporation, 861 F.3d 1362 (2017)']
author: [' Chen, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Chen, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] Patent Trial and Appeal Board (PTAB) was required to identify corresponding algorithm when construing means-
plus-function limitation;

[2] challenger was not required to explain why additional prior art references could not have been presented earlier in
inter partes review proceeding;

[3] substantial evidence supported PTAB's finding that combination of references taught claim limitation; and

[4] substantial evidence supported PTAB's finding that skilled artisan would have been motivated to combine references.

Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

"]

column1: Hyatt v US Patent and Trademark Office
name_numbers: ['Hyatt v. U.S. Patent and Trademark Office, 797 F.3d 1374 (2015)']
author: [' Moore, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Moore, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] determination by director that “special circumstances” justified the PTO's disclosure of confidential information was
subject to judicial review under the APA;

[2] Court of Appeals would review, for abuse of discretion, director's determination that “special circumstances” existed,
and that such “special circumstances” justified the disclosure of otherwise-confidential information; and

[3] director did not abuse her discretion when she found that “special circumstances” justified the PTO's disclosure of
confidential information.

Affirmed alternative holding.

"]

holding:

from dissolving a CoQ10 in lemon oil; and

art would have had a reasonable expectation of success in combining the references.

column1: st Media LLC v Electronic Arts Inc
name_numbers: ['1st Media, LLC v. Electronic Arts, Inc., 694 F.3d 1367 (2012)']
author: [' Linn, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Linn, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] assignee's motion to present its proofs first was not concession that competitors had met their threshold burden of
showing intent to deceive;

[2] district court clearly erred in relying on evidence showing, at best, that inventor and his lawyer knew that prior art
was material, and inability of inventor and his lawyer to offer good faith explanation, as basis to infer deliberate decision
to withhold prior art reference;

[3] decision of district court to not credit testimony of inventor and his lawyer could not be used as affirmative evidence
of selective disclosure; and

[4] paying issue fee after prior art reference had been brought to their attention was not deliberate decision to withhold
prior art reference.

Reversed.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0c1st Media, LLC v. Electronic Arts, Inc., 694 F.3d 1367 (2012)
104 U.S.P.Q.2d 1315

"]

column1: Lifestyle Enterprise Inc v US
name_numbers: ['Lifestyle Enterprise, Inc. v. U.S., 751 F.3d 1371 (2014)']
author: [' Taranto, Circuit']
holding:
[" Shanghai Foreign Trade Co., Ltd., Plaintiff,

Guangdong Yihua Timber Industry Co., Ltd., Plaintiff–Appellant,

and

v.

UNITED STATES, Defendant–Appellee,

v.

American Furniture Manufacturers Committee for Legal Trade and

Vaughanbassett Furniture Company, Inc., Defendants–Cross Appellants.

Nos. 2013–1323, 2013–1331.

|

June 2, 2014.

|

Rehearing and Rehearing En Banc Denied Sept. 8, 2014. *

Synopsis
Background: Importers filed suit challenging final results of Department of Commerce's third administrative review of
antidumping duty order on wooden bedroom furniture from People's Republic of China (PRC). Following intervention
by  organization  representing  domestic  manufacturers,  the  Court  of  International  Trade,  Jane  A.  Restani,  J.,  768
F.Supp.2d 1286, granted in part and denied in part motions for judgment on agency record by importers and intervenor,
and  granted  Commerce's  motion  for  voluntary  remand.  After  remand  redetermination  was  issued,  the  Court  of
International Trade, Restani, J., 844 F.Supp.2d 1283, affirmed in part and remanded in part. After second remand results
were issued, the Court of International Trade, Restani, J., 865 F.Supp.2d 1284, affirmed in part and remanded in part.
On third remand, redetermination was issued, and the Court of International Trade, Restani, J., 896 F.Supp.2d 1297,
sustained. Importer and organization cross-appealed.

Holdings: The Court of Appeals, Taranto, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] organization waived claim that importer lacked standing to argue that Commerce should have valued lumber using
weight-based import data rather than volume-based import data;

[2] Commerce's choice of one of two flawed data sets was reasonable; and

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cLifestyle Enterprise, Inc. v. U.S., 751 F.3d 1371 (2014)
36 ITRD 325

[3] exclusion of surrogate financial statements was reasonable.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.

"]

column1: Edwards Lifesciences AG v CoreValve Inc
name_numbers: ['Edwards Lifesciences AG v. CoreValve, Inc., 699 F.3d 1305 (2012)']
author: [' Newman, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Newman, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] substantial evidence supported jury verdict that invalidity on ground of non-enablement had not been proved by
clear and convincing evidence;

[2]  substantial  evidence  supported  jury  finding  that  cylindrical  support  means  of  claim  in  patent  directed  toward
prosthetic device called “transcatheter heart valve” was embodied in accused device;

[3] substantial evidence supported jury verdict that accused device was “generally parallel” to longitudinal axis of stent;

[4]  competitor  could  not  avoid  lost  profit  liability  for  infringement  on  alleged  basis  that  it  could  have  avoided
infringement by manufacturing accused device overseas;

[5] district court did not abuse its discretion in its decision to not enhance damages or award attorney fees after jury
rendered verdict of willful infringement; and

[6] denial of permanent injunction had to be vacated, and cause remanded to district court for reconsideration.

Affirmed in part and remanded in part.

Prost, Circuit Judge, filed concurring opinion.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cEdwards Lifesciences AG v. CoreValve, Inc., 699 F.3d 1305 (2012)

column1: McGuire v US
author: [' Dyk, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Dyk, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] Court was not bound by prior appellate decision as the “law of the case”;

[2] farmer was required to exhaust his administrative remedies although applicable procedures were informal in nature;

[3] farmer's informal meetings and verbal communications with government's supervisory general engineer, and written
sketch, were not sufficient to exhaust his administrative remedies;

[4] farmer did not prove futility with respect to his efforts to exhaust his administrative remedies;

[5] lease with Indian tribes that merely indicated that ownership of improvements attached to property defaulted to lessor
did not give rise to cognizable property interest in replacing bridge;

[6] BIA regulation stating that “[i]mprovements placed on the leased land shall become the property of the lessor [Indian
tribes] unless specifically excepted therefrom under the terms of the lease” did not give rise to cognizable property interest
in applying for permit to replace bridge;

[7] regulation only concerning right to apply for “revocable permit” or regulations that allowed revocation of any rights
granted by government did not give rise to cognizable property interest in applying for permit to replace bridge; and

[8] farmer's finding that production without that bridge was not economically viable did not give rise to cognizable
property interest in replacing bridge.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cMcGuire v. U.S., 707 F.3d 1351 (2013)

Affirmed.

Reyna, Circuit Judge, filed concurring opinion.

"]

['

column1: Keranos LLC v Silicon Storage Technology Inc
name_numbers: ['Keranos, LLC v. Silicon Storage Technology, Inc., 797 F.3d 1025 (2015)']
author: [' Chen, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Chen, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] exclusive license agreement between patent owner and licensee assigned all substantial rights under the patent to the
licensee;

[2] district court did not abuse its discretion in requiring licensee to demonstrate that it acted diligently in searching for
and naming additional products; and

[3] fact that publicly available information might not have been available warranted vacatur and remand of district
court's denial of licensee's motion to amend.

Vacated and remanded.

"]

PLLC, Austin, TX.

Before CHEN, BRYSON, and HUGHES, Circuit Judges.

']

column1: Unwired Planet LLC v Google Inc
name_numbers: ['Unwired Planet, LLC v. Google Inc., 841 F.3d 995 (2016)']
author: [' Reyna, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Reyna, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] book was within scope of prior art for determining obviousness;

[2] prior art taught prioritization that resulted in farther-over-nearer ordering as claimed in patent; and

[3] substantial evidence supported determination of PTAB that skilled artisan would have been motivated to combine
prior art references, rendering patent obvious.

Affirmed; Appeal dismissed.

']

column1: Augme Technologies Inc v Yahoo! Inc
name_numbers: ['Augme Technologies, Inc. v. Yahoo! Inc., 755 F.3d 1326 (2014)']
author: [' Moore, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Moore, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] in provider's patents, term “embedded” code excluded linked code that was not actually in the web page HTML;

[2] competitor's accused systems did not literally infringe “embedded first code module” limitation in provider's patents;

[3] competitor's accused systems did not infringe under doctrine of equivalents;

[4] means-plus-function claims in provider's patent were indefinite;

[5] term “server hostname” in competitor's patent meant a network name of a server; and

[6]  claim  “receiving,  by  an  ingest  server,  the  unique  identifier  to  the  digital  content”  in  competitor's  patent  was  not
indefinite.

Affirmed.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cAugme Technologies, Inc. v. Yahoo! Inc., 755 F.3d 1326 (2014)
111 U.S.P.Q.2d 1409

"]

column1: Microsoft Corporation v Biscotti Inc
name_numbers: ['Microsoft Corporation v. Biscotti, Inc., 878 F.3d 1052 (2017)']
author: [' O’Malley, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, O’Malley, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] Board applied proper legal standard for anticipation;

[2] substantial evidence supported Board's conclusion that alleged infringer failed to demonstrate that prior art reference
anticipated claim requiring that video communication device include storage medium;

[3] alleged infringer waived argument that claim was anticipated by prior art reference;

[4] substantial evidence supported Board's conclusion that alleged infringer failed to demonstrate that prior art reference
anticipated claim relating to set-top box; and

[5] Board's determination was not undermined by its purportedly incorrect construction of “set-top box.”

Affirmed.

Newman, Circuit Judge, dissented and filed opinion.

"]

author: [' Hughes, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Hughes, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] PTAB's finding of a motivation to combine prior art to arrive at claimed method in patent was supported by substantial
evidence, and

[2] PTAB's finding that proffered evidence of objective indicia of non-obviousness of patent lacked adequate nexus with
merits of claimed invention was supported by substantial evidence.

Affirmed.

Newman, Circuit Judge, filed a dissenting opinion.

"]

column1: Sanofi v Watson Laboratories Inc
name_numbers: ['Sanofi v. Watson Laboratories Inc., 875 F.3d 636 (2017)']
author: [' Taranto, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Taranto, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] accused labels demonstrated specific intent to encourage physicians to use dronedarone in patients with cardiovascular
risk factors in accordance with claim in patent, and thus those labels induced infringement;

[2] patent on method for using dronedarone in patients with cardiovascular risk factors was not obvious; and

[3] writing express limitation into parent patent claims did not carry over to continuation patent claiming pharmaceutical
compositions containing dronedarone.

Affirmed.

']

column1: Ad Hoc Shrimp Trade Action Committee v US
name_numbers: ['Ad Hoc Shrimp Trade Action Committee v. U.S., 802 F.3d 1339 (2015)']
author: [' Wallach, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Wallach, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1]  provision  of  Trade  Preferences  Extension  Act  altering  standards  that  Commerce  applied  in  selecting  and
corroborating adverse facts available (AFA) rates did not apply retroactively;

[2]  substantial  evidence  supported  Commerce's  determination  that  withholding  of  information  and  repeated
misrepresentations by exporter rendered its submissions unreliable;

[3] fact that exporter was located in Hong Kong did not automatically entitle it to separate rate status; and

[4] substantial evidence supported Commerce's corroboration of AFA rate.

Affirmed.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cAd Hoc Shrimp Trade Action Committee v. U.S., 802 F.3d 1339 (2015)
37 ITRD 1900

"]

author: [' Moore, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Moore, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1]  Court  of  International  Trade  did  not  abuse  its  discretion  in  concluding  that  equitable  prejudgment  interest  was
unnecessary;

[2] United States was entitled to post-liquidation interest on importer's delinquent antidumping duties;

[3] Court of International Trade did not abuse its discretion by declining to permit surety to make deposit in interest-
bearing account; and

[4] surety waived its opportunity to contest application of post-liquidation interest.

Affirmed.

"]

column1: Plantronics Inc v Aliph Inc
name_numbers: ['Plantronics, Inc. v. Aliph, Inc., 724 F.3d 1343 (2013)']
author: [' Wallach, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Wallach, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] term, “stabilizer support member,” meant structure that extended from ear cushion to concha stabilizer pad and
stabilized headset;

[2] term, “concha stabilizer,” meant stabilizing structure dimensioned to extend between ear cushion and upper concha;

[3] prosecution history disclaimer doctrine could not be applied to limit terms, “stabilizer support member” and “concha
stabilizer,” to elongated structure; and

[4] factual issue existed as to whether patent was obvious.

Reversed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

']

column1: Guangdong Wireking Housewares And Hardware Co Ltd v US
name_numbers: ['Guangdong Wireking Housewares & Hardware Co., Ltd. v. U.S., 745 F.3d 1194 (2014)']
author: [' Dyk, Circuit']
holding:
[" Company, Inc., Defendants–Appellees.

No. 2013–1404.

|

March 18, 2014.

Synopsis
Background: Importer brought action challenging Department of Commerce's final antidumping and countervailing
duty  determination  for  kitchen  shelving  and  racks  imported  from  People's  Republic  of  China,  and  challenging
constitutionality  of  amendment  to  Tariff  Act.  After  Chinese  government  intervened,  the  United  States  Court  of
International Trade, Nicholas Tsoucalas, Senior Judge, 900 F.Supp.2d 1362, ruled that amendment did not violate Ex
Post Facto Clause, and importer appealed.

Holdings: The Court of Appeals, Dyk, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] amendment had retroactive effect, and

[2] amendment did not violate Ex Post Facto Clause.

Affirmed.

O'Malley, Circuit Judge, concurred in result and filed opinion.

"]

Before DYK, O'MALLEY, and CHEN, Circuit Judges.

"]
