column1: AdjustaCam LLC v Newegg Inc
name_numbers: ['AdjustaCam, LLC v. Newegg, Inc., 861 F.3d 1353 (2017)']
author: [' Reyna, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Reyna, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] district court abused discretion by ignoring mandate to evaluate whether case was exceptional under the totality of
the circumstances, and

[2] district court's finding that patent licensee's litigation position was not exceptional was clearly erroneous.

Reversed and remanded.

"]

Sears Brands, LLC, Sears Holdings Corporation, Sears, Roebuck and Co., The Gap, Inc., Williams–

and

and

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cParallel Networks, LLC v. Abercrombie & Fitch Co., 704 F.3d 958 (2013)
105 U.S.P.Q.2d 1625

and

Lowe's Home Centers, Inc., Defendant–Appellee,

and

Maghound Enterprises, Inc., Time, Inc., and Toyota Motor Sales USA, Inc., Defendants–Appellees,

and

Nike, Inc., Defendant–Appellee,

and

Nissan North America, Inc., Defendant–Appellee,

and

Southwest Airlines Co., Defendant–Appellee,

and

Redbox Automated Retail, LLC, Defendant–Appellee,

and

Staples, Inc., Defendant–Appellee,

and

VF Outdoor, Inc., Defendant–Appellee.

No. 2012–1227.

|

Jan. 16, 2013.

Synopsis
Background: Patent owner filed action against competitors, alleging infringement of patent directed toward combining
and transmitting particularized data and functionality “as a group” in order to transfer “executable applet” and reduce
number of transmissions over communications link. The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Texas,
Leonard Davis, Chief Judge, granted summary judgment of non-infringement for some defendants, and severed them
from action and entered final judgment in their favor. Owner appealed.

Holdings: The Court of Appeals, Bryson, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] term, “dynamically generated,” meant constructed at server, by combining requisite functionality with necessary data,
at time of, and in response to, client request;

[2] patent was not infringed;

[3] patentee could not be allowed to amend its infringement contentions in order to make arguments that could have
been made before entry of summary judgment; and

[4] denial of motion to alter or amend judgment was not legally erroneous because it was summary in nature.

Affirmed.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

2

\x0cParallel Networks, LLC v. Abercrombie & Fitch Co., 704 F.3d 958 (2013)
105 U.S.P.Q.2d 1625

"]

column1: Maverick Tube Corporation v United States
name_numbers: ['Maverick Tube Corporation v. United States, 857 F.3d 1353 (2017)']
author: [' Lourie, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Lourie, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] substantial evidence supported Department of Commerce's decision to apply adverse facts available (AFA) to one
importer;

[2] Commerce's original determination that the Turkish market for oil country tubular goods was distorted was not
supported by substantial evidence; and

[3] substantial evidence supported Department of Commerce's decision to apply adverse facts available (AFA) to second
importer.

Affirmed.

"]

column1: Cleveland Clinic Foundation v True Health Diagnostics LLC
name_numbers: ['Cleveland Clinic Foundation v. True Health Diagnostics LLC, 859 F.3d 1352 (2017)']
author: [' Reyna, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Reyna, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] patent claims were directed to patent-ineligible law of nature;

[2] claims did not result in an inventive concept that transformed natural phenomena of MPO being associated with
cardiovascular risk into a patentable invention;

[3] patent owner failed to state claim for contributory infringement; and

[4] patent owner failed to state claim against competitor for induced infringement.

Affirmed.

']

column1: CLS Bank Intern v Alice Corp Pty Ltd
name_numbers: ['CLS Bank Intern. v. Alice Corp. Pty. Ltd., 717 F.3d 1269 (2013)']
holding:
["s, LLC v. Bed Bath & Beyond, Inc., Fed.Cir.(Del.), December 8, 2017

\xa0

717 F.3d 1269

United States Court of Appeals,

Federal Circuit.

CLS BANK INTERNATIONAL, Plaintiff–Appellee,

and

CLS Services Ltd., Counterclaim Defendant–Appellee,

v.

ALICE CORPORATION PTY. LTD., Defendant–Appellant.

No. 2011–1301.

|

May 10, 2013.

Synopsis
Background: In suit concerning infringement and validity of patents generally directed to methods or systems that help
lessen settlement risk of trades of financial instruments using a computer system, the United States District Court for the
District of Columbia, Rosemary M. Collyer, J., 768 F.Supp.2d 221, granted plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment,
and defendants appealed.

Holdings: Upon consideration en banc, a majority of the Court of Appeals held that:

[1] the asserted method and computer-readable media claims were not directed to eligible subject matter under patent
eligibility statute, and an equally divided court affirmed the district court's holding that

[2] the asserted system claims were not directed to eligible subject matter under patent eligibility statute.

Affirmed.

Lourie, Circuit Judge, concurring, in which Dyk, Prost, Reyna, and Wallach, Circuit Judges, joined.

Rader, Chief Judge, Linn, Moore, and O'Malley, Circuit Judges, filed opinion concurring-in-part and dissenting-in-part.

Moore, Circuit Judge, filed opinion dissenting-in-part in which Rader, Chief Judge, and Linn and O'Malley, Circuit
Judges, joined.

Newman, Circuit Judge, filed opinion concurring in part, and dissenting in part.

Linn and O'Malley, Circuit Judges, filed opinion dissenting from the court's judgment.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cCLS Bank Intern. v. Alice Corp. Pty. Ltd., 717 F.3d 1269 (2013)
106 U.S.P.Q.2d 1696

"]

column1: InterDigital Communications LLC v International Trade Com'n
name_numbers: ["InterDigital Communications, LLC v. International Trade Com'n, 707 F.3d 1295 (2013)"]
holding:
[":] The Court of Appeals, Bryson, Circuit Judge, held that substantial investment in research and development
of intellectual property in cellular telephone industry was “with respect to the articles protected by the patent,” within
meaning of Tariff Act's “domestic industry” requirement for exclusion of infringing products.

Petition denied.

Newman, Circuit Judge, filed opinion dissenting from denial of petition for rehearing.

"]
lawyers_judge:
["

*1296  Patrick J. Flinn, Alston & Bird LLP, of Atlanta, GA, filed a combined petition for panel rehearing and rehearing
en banc for intervenors. With him on the petition were John Haynes, of Atlanta, GA, and Ross R. Barton, of Charlotte,
NC. Of counsel on the petition was Paul D. Clement, Bancroft PLLC, of Washington, DC.

Donald R. Dunner, Finnegan, Henderson, Farabow, Garrett & Dunner, LLP, of Washington, DC, filed a response to
the petition for appellants. With him on the response were Allen M. Sokal, Don O. Burley, Smith R. Brittingham IV,
and Houtan Khalili Esfahani, of Washington, DC, and Christopher P. Isaac, of Reston, VA. Of counsel on the response
were Seth P. Waxman and William G. McElwain, Wilmer Cutler Pickering Hale and Dorr LLP, of Washington, DC,
and Mark C. Fleming and Lauren B. Fletcher, of Boston, MA.

Megan M. Valentine, Attorney Advisor, Office of General Counsel, United States International Trade Commission, of
Washington, DC, filed a response to the petition for appellee. With her on the response were Dominic L. Bianchi, Acting
General Counsel, and Andrea C. Casson, Assistant General Counsel for Litigation.

Daryl Joseffer, King & Spalding LLP, of Washington, DC, filed a response to the petition for amici curiae Hewlett–
Packard Co., et al. With him on the response were Jeffrey Telep and Adam Conrad.

Before RADER, Chief Judge, NEWMAN, MAYER, LOURIE, BRYSON, DYK, PROST, O'MALLEY, REYNA,
and WALLACH, Circuit Judges. *

PER CURIAM.

ORDER

A combined petition for panel rehearing and for rehearing en banc was filed by Intervenors, and responses to the petition
were invited by the court and filed by Appellants and Appellee. By leave of court, a response to the petition was filed
by Hewlett–Packard Co., et al., as amici curiae. The petition for rehearing and responses were considered by the panel

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

2

\x0cInterDigital Communications, LLC v. International Trade Com'n, 707 F.3d 1295 (2013)
34 ITRD 2393, 105 U.S.P.Q.2d 1581

that heard the appeal, and thereafter the petition for rehearing en banc and responses were referred to the circuit judges
who are in regular active service.

Upon consideration thereof,

IT IS ORDERED THAT:

(1) The petition for panel rehearing is denied, and a panel opinion and dissent are attached herewith.

*1297  (2) The petition for rehearing en banc is denied.

(3) The mandate of the court shall issue on January 17, 2013.

Before NEWMAN, MAYER, and BRYSON, **  Circuit Judges.

"]

column1: Core Wireless Licensing Sarl v Apple Inc
name_numbers: ['Core Wireless Licensing S.a.r.l. v. Apple Inc., 853 F.3d 1360 (2017)']
author: [' Bryson, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Bryson, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] district court did not reject competitor's construction that mobile station had to have capability to select dedicated
channel when relevant threshold conditions were met;

[2] “means for comparing” limitation meant that mobile station had to have uplink channel selection capabilities; and

[3] reasonable jury could find that accused devices did not infringe patent claim requiring mobile station to be capable
of channel selection.

Affirmed.

"]

column1: MySpace Inc v GraphOn Corp
name_numbers: ['MySpace, Inc. v. GraphOn Corp., 672 F.3d 1250 (2012)']
author: [' Plager, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Plager, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] limiting construction of term, “database,” to relational databases would have been improper;

[2] term, “database,” meant collection of data with given structure that could be stored and retrieved, including both
file, i.e., hierarchical, and relational systems;

[3] district court's analysis of term, “database,” adequately supported court's assessment that there was no triable issue
of fact on summary judgment as to whether prior art was “database”;

[4] ability to upload actual images was obvious;

[5] prior art generated unique transaction identifier for particular entry;

[6] construction that phrase, “password protecting,” did not require that system require passwords in all instances, or
that system restricted access by all other users;

[7] ability of prior art bulletin board to replace entry in file system, as opposed to it being edited, did not affect analysis
of validity of patents; and

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cMySpace, Inc. v. GraphOn Corp., 672 F.3d 1250 (2012)
101 U.S.P.Q.2d 1873

[8] district court was not required in its summary judgment opinion to make specific findings on each of four Graham
factors.

Affirmed.

Mayer, Circuit Judge, filed dissenting opinion.

"]

column1: Levi Strauss And Co v Abercrombie And Fitch Trading Co
name_numbers: ['Levi Strauss & Co. v. Abercrombie & Fitch Trading Co., 719 F.3d 1367 (2013)']
author: [' Taranto, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Taranto, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] district court's judgment that manufacturer failed to prove that competitor's design mark diluted its design mark was
not extant final judgment on merits;

[2] manufacturer's voluntary dismissal of its dilution claim with prejudice had no issue preclusive effect;

[3] district court's determination that competitor did not infringe manufacturer's design mark did not bar manufacturer's
challenges before Board under doctrine of issue preclusion; and

[4]  district  court's  determination  that  competitor  did  not  dilute  or  infringe  manufacturer's  design  mark  did  not  bar
manufacturer's challenges before Board under doctrine of claim preclusion.

Reversed and remanded.

"]
lawyers_judge:
["

him on the brief was Gia L. Cincone.

Of counsel was Bryan J. Sinclair, of Palo Alto, CA.

Before LOURIE, O'MALLEY, and TARANTO, Circuit Judges.

"]

name_numbers: ['Cascades Projection LLC v. Epson America, Inc., 864 F.3d 1309 (2017)']

column1: LifeNet Health v LifeCell Corporation
name_numbers: ['LifeNet Health v. LifeCell Corporation, 837 F.3d 1316 (2016)']
author: [' Prost, Chief']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Prost, Chief Judge, held that:

[1] competitor did not properly raise its argument that district court erred by failing to resolve legal dispute regarding
scope of non-removal limitation;

[2] on issue of non-infringement, whether plasticizer was removed from internal matrix of accused tissue grafts before
transplantation was for jury;

[3] accused tissue grafts were complete when they left competitor's hands and infringed patent in that condition, without
affirmative action by any third party;

[4] non-removal limitation did not mix apparatus with method using that apparatus, and thus it was not indefinite on
that ground;

[5] term “plasticized soft tissue graft” meant “free and loosely bound waters of hydration in the tissue have been replaced
with one or more plasticizers,” without requiring that graft be “dehydrated”; and

[6] on issue of obviousness, whether prior art disclosed “plasticized soft tissue graft” was question for jury.

Affirmed.

"]

column1: DDR Holdings LLC v Hotelscom LP
name_numbers: ['DDR Holdings, LLC v. Hotels.com, L.P., 773 F.3d 1245 (2014)']
author: [' Chen, Circuit']
holding:
['s, LLC v. Hotels.com, L.P., 773 F.3d 1245 (2014)
113 U.S.P.Q.2d 1097

KeyCite Yellow Flag - Negative Treatment

Not Followed as Dicta EX PARTE DAVID J. TANNOR AND ASAF SHIMSHOVITZ, Patent Tr. & App. Bd., May 31, 2017

\xa0

773 F.3d 1245

United States Court of Appeals,

Federal Circuit.

DDR HOLDINGS, LLC, Plaintiff–Appellee,

v.

HOTELS.COM, L.P., Cendant Travel Distribution Services Group, Inc., Expedia, Inc.,
Travelocity.Com, L.P., Site59.Com, LLC, International Cruise & Excursion Gallery, Inc.,

Ourvacationstore, Inc., Internetwork Publishing Corporation, and Orbitz Worldwide, LLC, Defendants,

National Leisure Group, Inc. and World Travel Holdings, Inc., Defendants–Appellants,

and

and

Digital River, Inc., Defendant.

No. 2013–1505.

|

Dec. 5, 2014.

Synopsis
Background: Patentee brought infringement action against competitors, alleging infringement of patents relating to an e-
commerce system and method providing hosts with transparent, context sensitive e-commerce supported pages. After a
jury returned a verdict against competitors, competitors filed renewed motions for judgment as a matter of law (JMOL),
and one competitor moved for a new trial. The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Texas, Rodney
Gilstrap, J., 954 F.Supp.2d 509, denied motion. Competitors appealed.

Holdings: The Court of Appeals, Chen, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] asserted claims of one patent were invalid as anticipated;

[2] asserted claims of patents were not so manifestly abstract as to render them invalid for failing to claim patentable
subject matter;

[3] patent was not invalid for indefiniteness; and

[4] substantial evidence supported finding of direct infringement by second competitor.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.

Mayer, Circuit Judge, filed dissenting opinion.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cDDR Holdings, LLC v. Hotels.com, L.P., 773 F.3d 1245 (2014)
113 U.S.P.Q.2d 1097

']

column1: Ninestar Technology Co Ltd v International Trade Com'n
name_numbers: ["Ninestar Technology Co., Ltd. v. International Trade Com'n, 667 F.3d 1373 (2012)"]
author: [' Newman, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Newman, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] Commission's ruling that its orders were violated with knowledge and in bad faith was supported by substantial
evidence and in accordance with law;

[2] imposition of $11,110,000 penalty was not abuse of discretion;

[3] Commission could assess joint and several liability for penalty against producer and subsidiaries;

[4] provision of civil penalty, under statute addressing unfair practices in import trade, was within regulatory authority
and appropriately assigned to administrative agency; and

[5] producer and subsidiaries failed to show that orders were facially unconstitutional due to failure to identify affected
cartridges.

Affirmed.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

column1: CRFD Research Inc v Matal
name_numbers: ['CRFD Research, Inc. v. Matal, 876 F.3d 1330 (2017)']
author: [" O'Malley, Circuit"]
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, O'Malley, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1]  substantial  evidence  supported  PTAB's  decision  that  claims  requiring  specifying  second  device  and  transmitting
session history after session was discontinued were invalid as anticipated;

[2]  substantial  evidence  supported  PTAB's  decision  that  claims  requiring  specifying  second  device  and  transmitting
session history were invalid as obvious;

[3] substantial evidence supported PTAB's decision that claims requiring specifying second device to resume session based
on user identification were invalid as anticipated; and

[4] claim limitations requiring transmitting session history of first device to session transfer module after session was
discontinued on first device were invalid as obvious.

Ordered accordingly.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Chen, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] the patent phrase “unobtrusive manner that does not distract a user” was indefinite;

[2] the term “attention manager” meant a system that displays images to a user either when the user is not engaged in a
primary interaction or in an area of the display screen that is not used by the user's primary activity; and

[3] the term “instructions” meant a statement that specifies a function to be performed by a system.

Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

column1: Nuance Communications Inc v ABBYY USA Software House Inc
name_numbers: ['Nuance Communications, Inc. v. ABBYY USA Software House, Inc., 813 F.3d 1368 (2016)']
author: [' Prost, Chief']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Prost, Chief Judge, held that:

[1] district court resolved parties' claim construction dispute, regarding the recited term “identifying,” before trial, and

[2] patentee suffered no harm from district court's adoption of dictionary definition for the disputed term “identifying”;
and

[3] entry of judgment against patentee on all of its infringement claims did not violate due process.

Affirmed.

"]

column1: HillRom Services Inc v Stryker Corp
name_numbers: ['Hill-Rom Services, Inc. v. Stryker Corp., 755 F.3d 1367 (2014)']
author: [' Moore, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Moore, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] term “datalink” was not limited to wired connections;

[2] term “interface board including a processor” did not require that messages be sent to a remote location via a wall
interface unit;

[3] term “message validation information” meant one or more data fields within a message that is used to verify that the
message was received exactly the same as it was sent; and

[4] term “bed condition message” meant a message that indicates the status of a monitored bed condition.

Reversed and remanded.

Reyna, Circuit Judge, filed a dissenting opinion.

']

column1: TomTom Inc v Adolph
name_numbers: ['TomTom, Inc. v. Adolph, 790 F.3d 1315 (2015)']
author: [' Wallach, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Wallach, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1]  patent  claim's  preamble  provided  necessary  limiting  structure  only  insofar  as  phrase  “at  least  one  mobile  unit”
provided antecedent basis for later use of terms “said mobile unit” and “the mobile unit” in body of claim;

[2] “destination tracking system of at least one mobile unit” meant a destination tracking system of at least one mobile
unit that did not require initial information relating to existing road networks;

[3] “node” meant a geographic location; and

[4] “storage device” had its plan and ordinary meaning.

Reversed and remanded.

"]

column1: Apple Inc v Ameranth Inc
name_numbers: ['Apple, Inc. v. Ameranth, Inc., 842 F.3d 1229 (2016)']
author: [' Reyna, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Reyna, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] “menu” meant a list of options available to a user displayable on a computer;

[2] claim preambles reciting “synchronous communications system” were not limiting so as to require central back-office
server that communicated data updates to and from multiple client devices;

[3] “central processing unit” meant computational and control unit of a computer;

[4] Board's determinations that patents were covered business method patents were supported by substantial evidence
and were neither arbitrary nor capricious;

[5] patent claims were directed to abstract idea of generating menus with certain features, and thus claims were patent-
ineligible absent additional transformative elements;

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cApple, Inc. v. Ameranth, Inc., 842 F.3d 1229 (2016)
120 U.S.P.Q.2d 1844

[6] claims lacked transformative elements, and thus were patent-ineligible; and

[7] requirement that modified menu be linked to a specific customer at a specific table was not sufficiently transformative
to render claims patentable.

Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

"]

column1: Mid Continent Nail Corp v US
name_numbers: ['Mid Continent Nail Corp. v. U.S., 725 F.3d 1295 (2013)']
author: [' Dyk, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Dyk, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] Commerce had authority to conduct a mixed media inquiry and to exclude from the scope of an antidumping order
otherwise-subject merchandise included within a mixed media item;

[2] Commerce did not reasonably interpret antidumping order for imported nails to justify exclusion of nails included
in mixed media tool kits when it made scope ruling on remand; and

[3] Commerce was required on remand to revisit its mixed media determination in light of the requirement that any
implicit mixed media exception to the literal scope of the order be based on preexisting public sources.

Vacated and remanded.

']

column1: Promega Corporation v Life Technologies Corporation
name_numbers: ['Promega Corporation v. Life Technologies Corporation, 875 F.3d 651 (2017)']
holding:
["s, Inc., Applied Biosystems, LLC, Defendants-Appellants

v.

2013-1011, 2013-1029, 2013-1376

|

Decided: November 13, 2017

Synopsis
Background:  Exclusive  licensee  of  patents  directed  toward  process  for  examining  polymorphism  in  samples  of
deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) brought infringement action against sublicensee that manufactured genetic testing toolkits
abroad. The United States District Court for the Western District of Wisconsin, Barbara Brandriff Crabb, J., 2002 WL
32359938, granted licensee's motion to reconsider claim construction, and later, 2012 WL 12862829, granted sublicensee's
motion for judgment as matter of law (JMOL) that its accused toolkits were not infringing after jury verdict in licensee's
favor. Parties appealed. The Court of Appeals, 773 F.3d 1338, affirmed in part, reversed in part, vacated in part, and
remanded. Certiorari was granted. The Supreme Court, 137 S.Ct. 734, reversed and remanded.

Holdings: On remand, the Court of Appeals, Chen, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] licensee abandoned any alternative damages base;

[2] licensee was not entitled to award of lost profit damages;

[3] retrial could not be granted on waived theory presented for first time post-judgment;

[4] district court did not abuse its discretion in finding under law of case doctrine that waiver of alternative damages base
continued to govern same issue in subsequent stages of patent infringement litigation; and

[5] district court was not required to grant new trial or remittitur on argument that licensee had waived.

Affirmed.

"]

name_numbers: ['StonCor Group, Inc. v. Specialty Coatings, Inc., 759 F.3d 1327 (2014)']
author: [' Hughes, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Hughes, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] substantial evidence did not support the Board's conclusion that the prefix “STON” in the “STONSHIELD” mark
would be pronounced with a short “o” sound;

[2]  any  error  in  the  Board's  conclusion  that  the  prefix  “STON”  would  be  pronounced  with  a  short  “o”  sound  was
harmless;

[3]  substantial  evidence  supported  the  Board's  conclusion  that  the  sixth  DuPont  factor,  the  number  and  nature  of
similar  marks  in  use  on  similar  goods,  was  neutral  in  determining  whether  or  not  to  approve  registration  of  the
“ARMORSTONE” mark; and

[4] the proposed mark, “ARMORSTONE,” was not merely descriptive.

Affirmed.

"]

column1: Shire LLC v Amneal Pharmaceuticals LLC
name_numbers: ['Shire LLC v. Amneal Pharmaceuticals, LLC, 802 F.3d 1301 (2015)']
author: [' Linn, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Linn, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1]patents were not obvious;

[2] district court did not abuse its discretion in denying competitors' motion to amend invalidity contentions to include
on-sale bar claim as untimely and lacking good cause;

[3] providing Abbreviated New Drug Application (ANDA) defendants with active ingredient was within safe harbor; and

[4] pre-approval supplier of active ingredient that did not submit ANDA was not liable for inducing acts that would
constitute direct patent infringement of compound claims at issue.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.

"]

column1: Helsinn Healthcare SA v Teva Pharmaceuticals USA Inc
name_numbers: ['Helsinn Healthcare S.A. v. Teva Pharmaceuticals USA, Inc., 855 F.3d 1356 (2017)']
author: [' Dyk, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Dyk, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] supply and purchase agreement, which obligated purchaser to buy owner's claimed invention once the solution was
approved by FDA, constituted a “sale” of the claimed invention prior to critical date, as required for pre-Leahy-Smith
America Invents Act's (AIA) on-sale bar to patentability to apply;

[2] supply and purchase agreement constituted a “sale” of the claimed invention prior to critical date, as required for
Leahy-Smith America Invents Act's (AIA) on-sale bar to patentability to apply; and

[3] claimed invention was “reduced to practice” before the critical date, and thus was ready for patenting, as required
for the on-sale bar to patentability to apply.

Reversed.

"]

column1: WiFi One LLC v Broadcom Corporation
name_numbers: ['Wi-Fi One, LLC v. Broadcom Corporation, 837 F.3d 1329 (2016)']
author: [' Bryson, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Bryson, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] prior art disclosed type identifier field feature recited in subject patent, thus patent was invalid as anticipated;

[2] prior art's placement of field in header, rather than in message field, was insufficient to avoid finding that patent was
invalid as anticipated;

[3]  phrase  “responsive  to  the  receiving  step,  constructing  a  message  field  for  a  second  data  unit,  said  message  field
including a type identifier field” meant “a field of a message that identifies the type of that message”; and

[4] phrase “each of said plurality of erroneous sequence number fields associated with a respective one of said plurality of
erroneous sequence number length fields” required that each erroneous sequence number length field must be associated
with erroneous sequence number field, but not other way around.

Affirmed.

Reyna, Circuit Judge, filed concurring opinion.

"]

column1: Multilayer Stretch Cling Film Holdings Inc v Berry Plastics Corporation
name_numbers: ['Multilayer Stretch Cling Film Holdings, Inc. v. Berry Plastics..., 831 F.3d 1350 (2016)']
author: [' Dyk, Circuit']
holding:
["s, Inc. v. Berry Plastics..., 831 F.3d 1350 (2016)
119 U.S.P.Q.2d 1773

KeyCite Yellow Flag - Negative Treatment

Distinguished by Tris Pharma, Inc. v. Actavis Elizabeth LLC, D.Del., February 20, 2018

\xa0

831 F.3d 1350

United States Court of Appeals,

Federal Circuit.

MULTILAYER STRETCH CLING FILM HOLDINGS, INC., Plaintiff–Appellant

BERRY PLASTICS CORPORATION, Defendant–Cross–Appellant.

v.

2015-1420, 2015-1477

|

Decided: August 4, 2016

Synopsis
Background:  Patentee  brought  action  against  manufacturer  of  plastic  stretch  films,  alleging  infringement  of  patent
relating to multilayered plastic cling wrap films. Following claim construction, 2013 WL 5972195, the United States
District Court for the Western District of Tennessee, William G. Young, J., 63 F.Supp.3d 786, granted manufacturer's
motion for summary judgment of non-infringement. Patentee appealed.

Holdings: The Court of Appeals, Dyk, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] Markush group of patent claim element, stating that multilayered plastic cling wrap films contained five inner layers
with  each  layer  being  selected  from  group  consisting  of  linear  low  density,  very  low  density,  ultra  low  density,  and
metallocene-catalyzed linear low density polyethylene resins, was closed to resins other than the four listed in the claim
element;

[2] Markush group of patent claim element was open to blends of the four recited resins; and

[3] district court's grant of summary judgment of non-infringement was not premature.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

Taranto, Circuit Judge, filed opinion dissenting in part.

"]

column1: Braintree Laboratories Inc v Novel Laboratories Inc
name_numbers: ['Braintree Laboratories, Inc. v. Novel Laboratories, Inc., 749 F.3d 1349 (2014)']
author: [' Prost, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Prost, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] term “purgation” meant an evacuation of a copious amount of stool from the bowels after oral administration of
the solution;

[2] term “clinically significant electrolyte shifts” meant alterations in blood chemistry that are outside the normal upper
or lower limits of their normal range or other untoward effects;

[3] fact issues precluded summary judgment on infringement;

[4] prior art did not anticipate patent;

[5] patent was not obvious; and

[6] patent was not indefinite.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

Dyk, Circuit Judge, filed an opinion concurring in part, dissenting in part, and concurring in the result.

Moore, Circuit Judge, filed a dissenting opinion.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

column1: Ohio Willow Wood Co v Alps South LLC
name_numbers: ['Ohio Willow Wood Co. v. Alps South, LLC, 813 F.3d 1350 (2016)']
author: [' Bryson, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Bryson, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] failure of director of research and development to call letters from another competitor regarding prior art device to
attention of Patent and Trademark Office (PTO) in second reexamination was material to patentability;

[2] deceptive intent was most reasonable inference for conduct of director in not calling letters to attention of PTO in
second reexamination;

[3] role of director, along with credibility findings against him, was not sufficient to establish that he was familiar with
declarations regarding prior art that had been submitted in first reexamination;

[4]  finding  of  inequitable  conduct  in  second  reexamination  did  not  compel  finding  of  inequitable  conduct  in  first
reexamination; and

[5] district court's refusal to extend holding of unenforceability due to inequitable conduct to two related patents was
appropriately within its discretion.

Affirmed.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cOhio Willow Wood Co. v. Alps South, LLC, 813 F.3d 1350 (2016)
118 U.S.P.Q.2d 1094

"]

name_numbers: ['Wind Tower Trade Coalition v. U.S., 741 F.3d 89 (2014)']
author: [' Wallach, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Wallach, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] it had jurisdiction over appeal;

[2] Department of Commerce's interpretation of antidumping- and countervailing-duty statutes was entitled to Chevron
deference;

[3] plaintiff failed to establish likelihood of success on merits;

[4]  Court  of  International  Trade  acted  within  its  discretion  in  determining  that  showing  of  irreparable  injury  was
outweighed by failure to show likelihood of success on merits;

[5] Court of International Trade acted within its discretion in determining that balance of equities did not favor granting
injunction; and

[6] Court of International Trade acted within its discretion in determining that it was not in public interest to grant
injunction.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

author: [' Rader, Chief']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Rader, Chief Judge, held that:

[1] term “payload platform” meant a three-dimensional structure upon which the payload was directly mounted upon
or affixed to, and

[2] district court did not have personal jurisdiction over nonresident rental company.

Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

']

['

El Segundo, CA.

Brian W. Warwick, Varnell & Warwick, P.A., of The Villages, FL, argued for defendants-cross appellants.

Before RADER, Chief Judge, PROST and MOORE, Circuit Judges.

']

column1: MettlerToledo Inc v BTek Scales LLC
name_numbers: ['Mettler-Toledo, Inc. v. B-Tek Scales, LLC, 671 F.3d 1291 (2012)']
author: [' Moore, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Moore, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] appropriate structure for disputed means-plus-function claim elements in patent was multiple slope integrating analog-
to-digital converter and equivalents thereof;

[2] substantial evidence supported jury determination that prior art patent taught correcting for load position;

[3] substantial evidence existed for jury's conclusion that prior art patent did not teach away from patent; and

[4] district court did not abuse its discretion by denying sanctions for alleged discovery abuses by patentee.

Affirmed.

"]
lawyers_judge:
['

*1293  James L. Kwak, Standley Law Group, LLP, of Dublin, OH, argued for plaintiff-appellant. With him on the
brief were Jeffrey S. Standley and F. Michael Speed, Jr.

the brief were F. Thomas Hecht, Richard C. Himelhoch and Lisa C. Sullivan.

Before BRYSON, MOORE, and REYNA, Circuit Judges.

']

column1: G David Jang MD v Boston Scientific Corporation
name_numbers: ['G. David Jang, M.D. v. Boston Scientific Corporation, 872 F.3d 1275 (2017)']
author: [' Chen, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Chen, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] sufficient evidence supported jury's finding that accused device did not literally infringe claimed connecting strut
columns;

[2] hypothetical claim that added flexibility requirement narrowed scope of issued claim, precluding any ensnarement
analysis on such basis;

[3] hypothetical claim that stated first connecting strut had to include “at least” proximal, distal, and intermediate sections
had same claim scope as issued claim, precluding any ensnarement analysis on such basis; and

[4] assignor was not prejudiced by any lack of pretrial discovery as to assignee's ensnarement defense.

Affirmed.

"]

["

"]

holding:

thus were invalid as unpatentable.

Affirmed.

']

column1: NeuroRepair Inc v The Nath Law Group
name_numbers: ['NeuroRepair, Inc. v. The Nath Law Group, 781 F.3d 1340 (2015)']
author: [' Wallach, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Wallach, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] malpractice action would not necessarily raise issues of patent law for federal jurisdiction purposes;

[2] issue of whether patent could have issued earlier and with broader claims was not “substantial” federal issue; and

[3] state's interests in regulating state's lawyers outweighed potential federal interests in patent law issues.

Vacated and remanded.

"]

']

name_numbers: ['Dealertrack, Inc. v. Huber, 674 F.3d 1315 (2012)']
author: [' Linn, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Linn, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] “central processing means,” as used in means-plus-function limitation of claims of patent was indefinite, and

[2] certain claims were patent ineligible abstract ideas.

Affirmed–in–part, vacated–in–part, reversed–in–part, and remanded.

Plager, Circuit Judge, filed opinion concurring-in-part and dissenting-in-part.

']

name_numbers: ['Amgen Inc. v. Apotex Inc., 827 F.3d 1052 (2016)']
author: [' Taranto, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Taranto, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] requirement that applicant for product could not market product for 180 days after providing RPS with notice was
enforceable by injunction; and

[2] provision governing limitations on declaratory judgment actions brought under BPCIA did not make declaratory
judgment action on patent the exclusive remedy for violations of BPCIA.

Affirmed.

']

column1: Intercontinental Great Brands LLC v Kellogg North America Company
name_numbers: ['Intercontinental Great Brands LLC v. Kellogg North America..., 869 F.3d 1336 (2017)']
author: [' Taranto, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Taranto, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] skilled artisan would have had motivation to use pull-back resealable package for discrete food items with rigid tray,
as disclosed in prior art article, that was usable for variety of foods “such as” discrete items like sushi and canapés
to resolve known problem of insufficiently convenient opening and reclosing arrangement for cookie packaging to be
accessed from top;

[2] expert testimony was not required to conclude that patent was obvious; and

[3] reasonable inference that patentee knew during reexamination that critical statement in prior art article was misprint
was not sufficient to permit finding of intent required for inequitable conduct.

Affirmed.

Reyna, Circuit Judge, filed opinion dissenting-in-part.

']

Before Prost, Chief Judge, Reyna and Taranto, Circuit Judges.

']

Vacated and remanded.

"]

[1] reinsertion of “colorable imitation” language into injunction did not amount to a modification upon which the Court
of Appeals could predicate jurisdiction, and

[2] addition of distributors to injunction did not amount to a modification upon which the Court of Appeals could
predicate jurisdiction.

Appeal dismissed.

"]

column1: Shire Development LLC v Watson Pharmaceuticals Inc
name_numbers: ['Shire Development, LLC v. Watson Pharmaceuticals, Inc., 787 F.3d 1359 (2015)']
holding:
['s: On remand, the Court of Appeals, Hughes, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] term, “matrix,” meant a macroscopically homogeneous structure in all its volume, and

[2] terms, “inner lipophilic matrix” and “outer hydrophilic matrix,” required two separate matrices, such that the matrices
retained their claimed properties and were consistent with their respective Markush group limitations.

Reversed and remanded.

']

column1: Apex Frozen Foods Private Limited v United States
name_numbers: ['Apex Frozen Foods Private Limited v. United States, 862 F.3d 1322 (2017)']
author: [' Clevenger, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Clevenger, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] Commerce's decision to compare exporter's dumping margins calculated by using average-to-transactional (A–T)
method with zeroing and average-to-average (A–A) method without zeroing was reasonable;

[2] Court of International Trade did not abuse its discretion in dismissing for failure to exhaust administrative remedies
exporter's claim that Commerce improperly compared A–A and A–T rates across all of its sales;

[3] Commerce did not act arbitrarily or capriciously in treating antidumping duties that were less than 0.5 percent as
de minimis;

[4] Commerce's use of A–T methodology in calculating antidumping margin was reasonable;

[5] regulation did not require Commerce to limit application of A-T method; and

[6] Commerce's use of zeroing coextensively with its use of A–T methodology was reasonable.

Affirmed.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cApex Frozen Foods Private Limited v. United States, 862 F.3d 1322 (2017)
38 ITRD 2356

"]

column1: PSC VSMPOAvisma Corp v US
name_numbers: ['PSC VSMPO-Avisma Corp. v. U.S., 688 F.3d 751 (2012)']
author: [' Schall, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Schall, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] affidavit of third-party accounting expert, submitted to provide further evidentiary support for importer's arguments,
constituted new factual information;

[2] power of Department of Commerce to apply its own procedures for timely resolution of antidumping reviews could
not be usurped by courts on basis that case may have presented issue of first impression;

[3] importer had not been deprived of due process right to notice and meaningful opportunity to be heard by exclusion
of untimely affidavit of third-party accounting expert; and

[4] substantial evidence supported choice of accounting methodology by Department of Commerce.

Reversed and remanded.

"]

column1: Apple Inc v Samsung Electronics Co Ltd copy
name_numbers: ['Apple Inc. v. Samsung Electronics Co., Ltd., 809 F.3d 633 (2015)']
author: [' Moore, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Moore, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] patentee was required to establish causal nexus between irreparable harm and competitor's infringement;

[2] to establish requisite causal nexus, patentee was not required to prove that infringing features of competitor's products
were exclusive or predominant reason that consumers bought competitor's products, only that there was some connection
between infringing features and demand for competitor's products;

[3] patentee established irreparable harm;

[4] patentee lacked adequate remedy at law;

[5] balance of hardships weighed in favor of injunction; and

[6] public interest weighed strongly in favor of injunction.

Vacated and remanded.

Opinion, 801 F.3d 1352, modified and superseded on rehearing.

Reyna, Circuit Judge, filed concurring opinion.

Prost, Chief Judge, filed dissenting opinion.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cApple Inc. v. Samsung Electronics Co., Ltd., 809 F.3d 633 (2015)
117 U.S.P.Q.2d 1469

"]

column1: Fort Properties Inc v American Master Lease LLC
name_numbers: ['Fort Properties, Inc. v. American Master Lease LLC, 671 F.3d 1317 (2012)']
author: [' Prost, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Prost, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] claims that required aggregating real property, making it subject to an agreement, and then issuing ownership interests
to multiple parties, disclosed unpatentable abstract idea, and

[2] claim limitation that required computer to generate plurality of deedshares did not impart patent-eligibility to claims
that were otherwise directed to unpatentable abstract idea of a real-estate investment tool.

Affirmed.

']

comported with due process, and

[2] exercise of personal jurisdiction over owner by California was reasonable and fair, and thus comported with due
process.

Reversed and remanded.

"]

author: [" O'Malley, Circuit"]
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, O'Malley, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1]  terms  “arbitrator”  and  “arbitrating”  required  a  determination  of  which  user  among  multiple  users  has  exclusive
control of the robot;

[2] substantial evidence supported finding that accused system did not literally infringe arbitrator limitation;

[3]  substantial  evidence  supported  finding  that  accused  system  did  not  infringe  patent  claim  disclosing  method  of
controlling operations of a video conferencing system;

[4] patent was not invalid for obviousness; and

[5] patent owner failed to establish that verdict of non-infringement was more probably than not affected by district
court's error.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.

"]

name_numbers: ['Bosch Automotive Service Solutions, LLC v. Matal, 878 F.3d 1027 (2017)']
author: [' Chen, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Chen, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] substantial evidence supported Board's determination that patent's apparatus claims were unpatentable as obvious;

[2] declaration by patent owner's director of marketing and diagnostic product management lacked proper evidentiary
foundation;

[3] patent's method claims were unpatentable as anticipated by prior art; and

[4] patent owner did not bear burden of proof on patentability of its proposed amended claims.

Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

"]

column1: Aventis Pharma SA v Hospira Inc
name_numbers: ['Aventis Pharma S.A. v. Hospira, Inc., 675 F.3d 1324 (2012)']
holding:
["s: Patentee appealed The Court of Appeals, Prost, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] “perfusion” meant an injectable solution containing the active pharmaceutical ingredient and an aqueous infusion
fluid;

[2] perfusion claim was invalid as obvious based on the prior art;

[3] district court acted within its discretion in granting competitors' motions to amend pleadings, after scheduling order
deadline, to add allegations related to inequitable conduct;

[4] prior art references withheld from Patent and Trademark Office (PTO) were necessarily but-for material, as required
to support defense that patents were unenforceable due to inequitable conduct; and

[5] district court's finding that inventor acted with specific intent to deceive PTO in withholding prior art references was
not clearly erroneous.

Affirmed.

"]

column1: Williamson v Citrix Online LLC
name_numbers: ['Williamson v. Citrix Online, LLC, 792 F.3d 1339 (2015)']
author: [' Linn, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Linn, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1]  claims  requiring  “graphical  display”  representative  of  classroom  did  not  require  pictorial  map  that  identified
participants' location;

[2] presumption that the means-plus-function statute does not apply to a patent claim that does not use the word “means”
is not strong, overruling Lighting World, Inc. v. Birchwood Lighting, Inc., 382 F.3d 1354, Inventio AG v. ThyssenKrupp
Elevator Americas Corp., 649 F.3d 1350, Flo Healthcare Solutions, LLC v. Kappos, 697 F.3d 1367, Apple Inc. v. Motorola,
Inc., 757 F.3d 1286;

[3] term “distributed learning control module,” as used in patent was means-plus-function claim term; and

[4] specification did not disclose sufficient structure corresponding to the “distributed learning control module” referred
to in means-plus-function claims, making those claims invalid for indefiniteness.

Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

Reyna, Circuit Judge, filed opinion concurring in part and dissenting in part.

Opinion, 770 F.3d 1371, superseded on rehearing.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cWilliamson v. Citrix Online, LLC, 792 F.3d 1339 (2015)
115 U.S.P.Q.2d 1105

"]

column1: CBT Flint Partners LLC v Return Path Inc
name_numbers: ['CBT Flint Partners, LLC v. Return Path, Inc., 737 F.3d 1320 (2013)']
author: [' Taranto, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Taranto, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] recoverable costs under the statute that enumerates expenses that a federal court may tax as costs are those costs
necessary to duplicate an electronic document in as faithful and complete a manner as required by rule, by court order,
by agreement of the parties, or otherwise;

[2] costs to make duplicates in an electronic format are recoverable as “the costs of making copies necessarily obtained
for use in the case”;

[3] costs for copying are limited to the duplication needed for the production in the form required;

[4] costs associated with project management, keyword searching, “statistical previews,” “auditing and logging of files
and ensuring compliance with Federal Rules,” and “extraction of proprietary data” are not the costs of making copies;

[5] costs incurred in acquiring, installing, and configuring a new data-hosting server that are incurred for the convenience
of the producing part and its counsel are not costs of “making copies”;

[6] costs of meetings, conference calls, and other communications are not costs of “making copies”;

[7] keyword searching and data analysis performed by a vendor at the request of an opponent is not a cost of “making
copies”; and

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cCBT Flint Partners, LLC v. Return Path, Inc., 737 F.3d 1320 (2013)
108 U.S.P.Q.2d 1969

[8] cost of decryption of a document stored in encrypted form on an electronic source medium is not a cost of “making
copies.”

Reversed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

']

column1: SAS Institute Inc v ComplementSoft LLC
name_numbers: ['SAS Institute, Inc. v. ComplementSoft, LLC., 825 F.3d 1341 (2016)']
author: [' Stoll, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Stoll, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] phrase “graphical representations of data flows” meant graphical representation comprised of icons depicting data
processing steps and arrows to depict movement of data through source code;

[2]  phrase  “data  manipulation  language”  meant  programming  language  used  to  access  data  in  database,  such  as  to
retrieve, insert, delete, or modify data in database;

[3] petitioner was entitled to reasonable notice of Board's change of theory in its claim construction; and

[4] Board was not required to address every claim raised in petition.

Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

Newman, Circuit Judge, concurred in part, dissented in part, and filed opinion..

"]
lawyers_judge:
['

JOHN MARLOTT, Jones Day, Chicago, IL, argued for appellant. Also represented by GREGORY A. CASTANIAS,

MARGOLIES.

Before Newman, Chen, and Stoll, Circuit Judges.

']

column1: Stone Lion Capital Partners LP v Lion Capital LLP
name_numbers: ['Stone Lion Capital Partners, L.P. v. Lion Capital LLP, 746 F.3d 1317 (2014)']
author: [' Wallach, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Wallach, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] Board properly compared applicant's mark with competitor's marks, in determining that marks were similar as to
appearance, sound, connotation and commercial impression;

[2] Board properly focused on registration application and competitor's registrations in determining that application and
registrations shared the same channels of trade and classes of purchasers; and

[3]  Board  properly  relied  on  broad  scope  of  investment  services  recited  in  trademark  registration  application  in
determining that consumers seeking applicant's services were not necessarily sophisticated.

Affirmed.

"]

name_numbers: ['Midwestern Pet Foods, Inc. v. Societe des Produits Nestle S.A., 685 F.3d 1046 (2012)']
author: [' Bryson, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Bryson, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] Board acted within its discretion in admitting at trial competitor's evidence of its advertising, sales, and marketing
activities;

[2] Board properly allowed competitor to rely on evidence of fame of BEGGIN' STRIPS mark that postdated the filing
of application; and

[3] Board's finding of a likelihood of confusion between WAGGIN' STRIPS mark and BEGGIN' STRIPS mark was
supported by substantial evidence.

Affirmed.

Dyk, Circuit Judge, filed an opinion concurring in part and dissenting in part.

"]

column1: Microsoft Corp v International Trade Com'n
name_numbers: ["Microsoft Corp. v. International Trade Com'n, 731 F.3d 1354 (2013)"]
author: [' Taranto, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Taranto, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] term “resource state information,” as used in patent that disclosed system and method for synchronizing copies of
data resource in client-server environment, required some information about resource version;

[2] substantial evidence supported finding that patentee failed to show existence of domestic industry relating to articles
protected by patent that disclosed and claimed a mechanism for notifying application programs about changes to the
state of certain mobile-device components of relevance to those applications, as required to establish violation of statute
proscribing unfair practices in import trade;

[3] substantial evidence supported finding that patentee failed to show existence of domestic industry relating to articles
protected by patent that disclosed radio interface layer between radio hardware and software applications in cellular
telephone, as required to establish unfair practice in import trade;

[4] “retrieving” and “adding” limitations of patent generally disclosing and claiming computer system having graphical
user interface that presented set of representations corresponding to actual computer resources and offered context-
sensitive menus for user interaction encompassed accused devices;

[5] accused devices met display-in-proximity requirement of “displaying” limitations of patent generally disclosing and
claiming computer system having graphical user interface that presented set of representations corresponding to actual
computer resources and offered context-sensitive menus for user interaction; and

[6]  for  context  menu  to  be  in  proximity  of  graphical  representation  of  selected  object,  as  required  by  “displaying”
limitations of patent generally disclosing and claiming computer system having graphical user interface that presented set
of representations corresponding to actual computer resources and offered context-sensitive menus for user interaction,
graphical representation had to remain at least partly visible on screen when context menu appeared.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cMicrosoft Corp. v. International Trade Com'n, 731 F.3d 1354 (2013)
35 ITRD 2081, 108 U.S.P.Q.2d 1443

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.

"]

column1: Intellectual Ventures I LLC v Motorola Mobility LLC
name_numbers: ['Intellectual Ventures I LLC v. Motorola Mobility LLC, 870 F.3d 1320 (2017)']
author: [' Dyk, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Dyk, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] patented file transfer method excluded long-term or permanent storage of files;

[2] substantial evidence supported jury's determination that the patented file transfer method was not obvious in light
of prior patents;

[3] substantial evidence did not support jury's determination that alleged infringer's cell phones directly infringed on the
patented file transfer method; and

[4] substantial evidence supported jury's determination that there was no motivation to combine prior art patents.

Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Newman, Circuit Judge, filed an opinion concurring in part, and dissenting in part.

"]

name_numbers: ['Technology Properties Limited LLC v. Huawei Technologies..., 849 F.3d 1349 (2017)']
author: [' Moore, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Moore, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1]  patentee  disclaimed  fixed-frequency  crystal  oscillator  and  external  crystal  or  frequency  generator  for  patentee's
claimed “entire oscillator,” which referred to variable-frequency CPU clock, during prosecution;

[2] patentee did not disclaim any use of a command signal by “entire oscillator” during prosecution; and

[3] “entire oscillator” meant an oscillator located entirely on the same semiconductor substrate as the CPU that did not
require a command input to change the clock frequency and whose frequency was not fixed by any external crystal.

Vacated and remanded.

column1: EmeraChem Holdings LLC v Volkswagen Group of America Inc
name_numbers: ['EmeraChem Holdings, LLC v. Volkswagen Group of America, Inc., 859 F.3d 1341 (2017)']
author: [' Moore, Circuit']
holding:
["s, LLC v. Volkswagen Group of America, Inc., 859 F.3d 1341 (2017)
123 U.S.P.Q.2d 1146

859 F.3d 1341

United States Court of Appeals,

Federal Circuit.

EMERACHEM HOLDINGS, LLC, Appellant

v.

VOLKSWAGEN GROUP OF AMERICA, INC., Appellee

Joseph Matal, performing the functions & duties of the under Secretary of Commerce
for Intellectual Property and Director, U.S. Patent & Trademark Office, Intervenor

2016-1984

|

Decided: June 15, 2017

Synopsis
Background: Petitioner sought inter partes review of patent which claimed methods for regenerating a devitalized catalyst/
absorber that has absorbed and oxidized nitrates and nitrites after extended exposure to pollutants in the combustion
gases of engines. The Patent Trial and Appeal Board (PTAB), No. IPR2014-01558, 2015 WL 1250951, instituted review
and  determined  claims  were  unpatentable  as  obvious.  Patentee  appealed.  Director  of  the  United  States  Patent  and
Trademark Office (PTO) intervened to defend PTAB's decision.

Holdings: The Court of Appeals, Moore, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] inventor's declaration, without more, was insufficient to establish that he and co-inventor solely conceived of earlier
patent, such that earlier patent could not be used as prior art, and

[2] PTAB did not provide patentee with notice and opportunity to respond to PTAB's reliance on prior art reference in
determining three claims were unpatentable as obvious, and thus PTAB violated Administrative Procedure Act (APA).

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.

"]
lawyers_judge:
['

MICHAEL J. BRADFORD, Luedeka Neely Group, PC, Knoxville, TN, argued for appellant. Also represented by
JACOBUS C. RASSER, Amsterdam, The Netherlands.

JOSEPH ANTHONY FARCO.

intervenor. Also represented by NATHAN K. KELLEY, SCOTT WEIDENFELLER, MONICA BARNES LATEEF.

Before Moore, Clevenger, and Chen, Circuit Judges.

']

column1: Eli Lilly and Company v Teva Parenteral Medicines Inc
name_numbers: ['Eli Lilly and Company v. Teva Parenteral Medicines, Inc., 845 F.3d 1357 (2017)']
author: [' Prost, Chief']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Prost, Chief Judge, held that:

[1] physicians conditioned pemetrexed treatment on folic acid pretreatment, as required on induced infringement claim
for method in proposed product labeling to directly infringe;

[2] physicians established manner or timing of performance, as required on induced infringement claim for method in
proposed product labeling to directly infringe;

[3] method in proposed product labeling encouraged, recommended, or promoted infringement, as required for liability
on induced infringement claim;

[4] “vitamin B12” limitation was not indefinite;

[5] prior art did not disclose claimed doses and schedules of vitamin B12 for purposes of pemetrexed pretreatment, and
thus method patent claim was not invalid as obvious; and

[6]  method  patent  claim  was  not  invalid  on  claim  of  obviousness-type  double  patenting  over  claim  in  prior  art  that
disclosed use of much greater amount of folic acid with antifolate administered to mammal.

Affirmed.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

121 U.S.P.Q.2d 1277

']

[1] concept of providing out-of-region access to regional broadcast content, as claimed in patent, was patent-ineligible
abstract idea, and

[2]  patent  and  its  specification  contained  no  “inventive  concept”  that  transformed  abstract  idea  into  patent-eligible

column1: JBF RAK LLC v US
author: [' Wallach, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Wallach, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] antidumping duty statute governing dumping margin calculations allowed Commerce to use “average-to-transaction”
comparison to determine that exporter engaged in targeted dumping;

[2]  domestic  producers'  targeted  dumping  allegations  were  considered  as  allegations,  rather  than  rebuttal  factual
information, in administrative review, and thus those allegations were not untimely;

[3] exporter failed to exhaust administrative remedies for its claim that domestic producers' allegations were untimely;

[4] exporter was not prejudiced by Commerce's decision to issue a post-preliminary determination; and

[5]  Commerce  was  not  required,  under  the  antidumping  duty  statute  governing  dumping  margin  calculations,  to
determine whether exporter intended to engage in targeted dumping.

Affirmed.

"]

column1: Meyer Intellectual Properties Ltd v Bodum Inc
name_numbers: ['Meyer Intellectual Properties Ltd. v. Bodum, Inc., 690 F.3d 1354 (2012)']
author: [" O'Malley, Circuit"]
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, O'Malley, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] “providing” meant “furnishing, supplying, making available, or preparing,” and thus any single party could satisfy
first step of patented method, which called for “providing a container,” along with other steps;

[2] genuine issues of material fact precluded summary judgment that patents were directly infringed;

[3]  district  court  abused  its  discretion  in  limiting  scope  of  prior  art  competitor  could  introduce  at  trial  to  what  was
purportedly expressly relied on in report of competitor's expert;

[4] district court abused its discretion in excluding testimony of competitor's expert regarding obviousness of asserted
patents, on ground expert's report was insufficiently detailed;

[5] district court abused its discretion in excluding lay testimony of competitor's chief executive officer (CEO) regarding
one of competitor's coffee presses; and

[6] district court abused its discretion in disposing of competitor's inequitable conduct defense on motion in limine.

Reversed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

Dyk, Circuit Judge, filed concurring opinion.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cMeyer Intellectual Properties Ltd. v. Bodum, Inc., 690 F.3d 1354 (2012)
83 Fed.R.Serv.3d 609, 104 U.S.P.Q.2d 1105

"]

column1: Apple Inc v Motorola Inc
name_numbers: ['Apple Inc. v. Motorola, Inc., 757 F.3d 1286 (2014)']
author: [' Reyna, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Reyna, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] term “heuristic” meant one or more rules to be applied to data to assist in drawing inferences from that data;

[2] term “analyzer server” meant a server routine separate from a client that receives data having structures from the
client;

[3] term “realtime application program interface (API)” meant an API that allows realtime interaction between two or
more subsystems;

[4] accused device did not infringe patent disclosing system for encrypting data communications;

[5] expert's testimony regarding reasonable royalty rate was admissible;

[6] fact issues precluded summary judgment on damages; and

[7] patentee was not entitled to injunction for infringement of patent related to smartphone technology.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

Rader, Chief Judge, filed an opinion dissenting-in-part.

Prost, Circuit Judge, filed an opinion concurring-in-part and dissenting-in-part.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cApple Inc. v. Motorola, Inc., 757 F.3d 1286 (2014)
110 U.S.P.Q.2d 1695, 94 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 301

"]

column1: Regents of University of Minnesota v AGA Medical Corp
name_numbers: ['Regents of University of Minnesota v. AGA Medical Corp., 717 F.3d 929 (2013)']
author: [' Dyk, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Dyk, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] phrase “first and second occluding disks,” meant physically distinct and separate first and second occluding disks;

[2] patent had not been infringed by accused product;

[3] prior art that contained two umbrella-shaped parts oriented like umbrellas joined at their tips anticipated claims of
patent;

[4] patentee's disclaimer during prosecution of prior patent applications regarding use of radial frame as equivalent of
peripheral frame for medical device for repairing heart defects did not carry forward to means-plus-function language
used in subsequent application that contained different claim limitation than its predecessors and captured different
subject matter;

[5] phrase, “at least a substantial portion of the central portion of the first member” be “in communication with at
least a substantial portion of the second member,” required that substantial portions of central portions of members
communicated “movement”;

[6] patentee waived any objection to aspect of district court's construction on claim of anticipation that allegedly wrongly
allowed translational movement communicated between prior art's members to satisfy “in communication with” claim
limitation; and

[7] patentee was barred from making argument on appeal that “central portion” of each member in patent directed to
medical devices for repairing heart defects had to fill septal defect, and that prior art's hub did not satisfy that requirement.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cRegents of University of Minnesota v. AGA Medical Corp., 717 F.3d 929 (2013)
293 Ed. Law Rep. 733, 106 U.S.P.Q.2d 1982

Affirmed.

"]

column1: EON Corp IP Holdings LLC v AT And T Mobility LLC
name_numbers: ['EON Corp. IP Holdings LLC v. AT & T Mobility LLC, 785 F.3d 616 (2015)']
author: [' Prost, Chief']
holding:
['s LLC v. AT & T Mobility LLC, 785 F.3d 616 (2015)
114 U.S.P.Q.2d 1711

KeyCite Yellow Flag - Negative Treatment

Distinguished by Fortinet, Inc. v. Sophos, Inc., N.D.Cal., October 28, 2015

\xa0

785 F.3d 616

United States Court of Appeals,

Federal Circuit.

EON CORP. IP HOLDINGS LLC, Plaintiff–Appellant

v.

AT & T MOBILITY LLC, Defendant–Appellee.
EON Corp. IP Holdings LLC, Plaintiff–Appellant

v.

FLO TV Incorporated, Defendant–Appellee

MobiTV Inc., Defendant–Appellee

U.S. Cellular Corporation, Defendant–Appellee

Sprint Nextel Corporation, HTC America Inc., Qualcomm, Inc., Simplexity,

LLC, d/b/a Wirefly, Motorola Mobility LLC, Defendants–Appellees

Letstalk.Com Inc., Defendant.

Nos. 2014–1392, 2014–1393.

|

May 6, 2015.

Synopsis
Background:  Patentee  commenced  action  against  smartphone  manufacturers,  cellular  network  providers,  and
smartphone content providers, alleging infringement of patent for smartphone software that allowed actions such as
impulse purchase transactions, audience participation voting, and sorting of television programs. Patentee subsequently
commenced separate action against other defendants. Following consolidation of cases through claim construction, the
United States District Court for the District of Delaware, Richard G. Andrews, J., 2014 WL 906182, granted summary
judgment in favor of defendants in first case, finding all claims of patent invalid as indefinite, and subsequently entered
judgment of invalidity to defendants in second case. Patentee appealed.

Holdings: The Court of Appeals, Prost, Chief Judge, held that:

[1] Katz exception to algorithm rule did not apply to patent;

[2] even if person of ordinary skill in the art could implement software function involved in patent, such fact did not
compel finding that a microprocessor could serve as sufficient structure; and

[3] patent was invalid as indefinite.

Affirmed.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cEON Corp. IP Holdings LLC v. AT & T Mobility LLC, 785 F.3d 616 (2015)
114 U.S.P.Q.2d 1711

']

column1: Saffran v Johnson And Johnson
name_numbers: ['Saffran v. Johnson & Johnson, 712 F.3d 549 (2013)']
author: [' Lourie, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Lourie, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] term “device” meant a continuous sheet and excluded stents having open mesh holes;

[2]  function  of  “means  for  release  of  at  least  one  treating  material  in  a  directional  manner”  was  to  release  a  drug
preferentially toward the damaged tissue;

[3] structure corresponding to function of releasing drug preferentially toward damaged tissue was hydrolyzable bonds;
and

[4] competitor's medical stents, which both lacked a sheet covering the open mesh holes between their struts and lacked
a drug affixed to their surfaces via hydrolyzable bonds, did not infringe upon patent.

Reversed.

Moore, Circuit Judge, filed opinion concurring in part.

O'Malley, Circuit Judge, filed opinion concurring in part.

"]

column1: Wasica Finance GmbH v Continental Automotive Systems Inc
name_numbers: ['Wasica Finance GmbH v. Continental Automotive Systems, Inc., 853 F.3d 1272 (2017)']
author: [' Schall, Circuit']
holding:
[" NV, SI International (TOPCO), Inc., Cross-Appellants

2015-2078

|

2015-2079

|

2015-2093

|

2015-2096

|

Decided: April 4, 2017

Synopsis
Background: In inter partes review, the United States Patent and Trademark Office, Patent Trial and Appeal Board,
2015 WL 4500655, 2015 WL 3811738, 2015 WL 4500655, and 2015 WL 3811738 determined that some claims in patent
describing systems for monitoring tire pressure in vehicles were unpatentable, and other claims were patentable. Parties
appealed. Appeals were consolidated.

Holdings: The Court of Appeals, Schall, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] phrases, “electrical pressure signal” and “pressure transmitting signal,” encompassed non-numeric representations
of pressure;

[2] phrase, “emittance of a predetermined switching signal,” included both wired and wireless; transmissions

[3] prior art disclosing that its transmitters were all tuned to “common” working frequency did not anticipate claim in
patent that required its carrier waves to have constant frequency;

[4] prior art's broad invocation of “any modulation scheme,” as genus, did not disclose constant-frequency modulation
scheme, as species; and

[5] term, “bit sequence,” encompassed single-bit sequences.

Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cWasica Finance GmbH v. Continental Automotive Systems, Inc., 853 F.3d 1272 (2017)
122 U.S.P.Q.2d 1267

"]

[1] as part of its showing on causation, lessee had to prove that it would have been able to conduct drilling and processing
operations without running afoul of anti-pollution restrictions;

[2] evidence supported finding that emissions resulting from exploratory drilling would have exceeded pollution emissions
cap;

[3] evidence supported finding that lease owner lacked enough credits to offset emissions that drilling project and allow
it to obtain emissions permit; and

[4] evidence supported finding that lease owner would not have been able to use another company's processing facility
to allow it to develop leased properties.

Affirmed.

"]

column1: Belden Inc v BerkTek LLC
name_numbers: ['Belden Inc. v. Berk-Tek LLC, 805 F.3d 1064 (2015)']
author: [' Taranto, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Taranto, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] skilled artisan would have understood importance of aligning core and conductors and connection between achieving
such alignment and preventing core from twisting at aligning die;

[2] reason existed to combine third die, as found in other prior art, upstream from first die to enhance alignment, with
prior art method of manufacturing plastic insulated communication cable, to render claims in patent obvious;

[3] person of ordinary skill in the art seeking to manufacture cables with four insulated twisted pairs and separator would
have been motivated to use prior art method of manufacturing plastic insulated communication cable to solve alignment
issues; and

[4] patentee had not been denied meaningful opportunity to respond to grounds of rejection on inter partes review.

Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

']

holding:

[1] substantial evidence supported finding that prior art taught the location of the finger flap on the top panel of a carton;

[2] substantial evidence supported finding that prior art taught a perforated line for both tearing and folding;

[3] term “free ends” meant a point spaced from the distal ends;

[4] prior art patent satisfied tear-line limitation;

flap between the first and second containers; and

[6] terms recited in the preamble were limitations.

column1: Integrated Technology Corp v Rudolph Technologies Inc
name_numbers: ['Integrated Technology Corp. v. Rudolph Technologies, Inc., 734 F.3d 1352 (2013)']
author: [' Moore, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Moore, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] prosecution history estoppel barred application of doctrine of equivalents;

[2] substantial evidence supported the jury's general verdict award of lost profits for competitor's literal infringement
of patent;

[3] award of attorney fees and costs would be vacated, where court's analysis depended in part on its erroneous finding
of willfulness.

Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

"]

column1: Pioneer HiBred Intern Inc v Monsanto Technology LLC
name_numbers: ['Pioneer Hi-Bred Intern., Inc. v. Monsanto Technology LLC, 671 F.3d 1324 (2012)']
author: [' Clevenger, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Clevenger, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] multiple pre-critical date claims, considered together, could provide foundation necessary, for post-critical date claims
to be held timely;

[2] Board was entitled to analyze together two non-dependent claims; and

[3] junior party provided prima facie justification for relief, which senior party was required to rebut.

Affirmed.

']

name_numbers: ['Amgen Inc. v. Hospira, Inc., 866 F.3d 1355 (2017)']
author: [' Dyk, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Dyk, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] collateral order doctrine did not apply so as to give Court of Appeals jurisdiction to review District Court's non-final
judgment denying holder's motion to compel discovery, and

[2] holder failed to show clear and indisputable right to compel discovery.

Petition for writ of mandamus denied and appeal dismissed.

"]

column1: IGT v Alliance Gaming Corp
name_numbers: ['IGT v. Alliance Gaming Corp., 702 F.3d 1338 (2012)']
author: [' Reyna, Circuit']
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, Reyna, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] district court did not improperly resolve disputed question of fact in determining that wheel game machines competed
in broader gaming machine market;

[2] even if small but significant and non–transitory increase in price (SSNIP) test was applicable, competitor did not
satisfy it;

[3] district court's conclusion that wheel games were not relevant marker was properly based on competition;

[4] competitor's evidence was insufficient to demonstrate that wheel games constituted submarket; and

[5] district court did not improperly resolve disputed question of fact in relation to statements that patent owner made
to support its patent damages theory.

Affirmed.

Bryson, Circuit Judge, dissented and filed opinion.

"]

"]

double patenting reference, and thus invalidate earlier-issued, but later expiring patent, even where patents were subject
to requirement of common ownership.

Vacated and remanded.

Rader, Chief Judge, filed dissenting opinion.

']

column1: Aqua Products Inc v Matal
name_numbers: ['Aqua Products, Inc. v. Matal, 872 F.3d 1290 (2017)']
author: [" O'Malley, Circuit"]
holding:
["s: The Court of Appeals, O'Malley, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1] petitioner had burden of persuasion with respect to the patentability of amended claims, overruling Microsoft Corp. v.
Proxyconn, Inc., 789 F.3d 1292; Prolitec, Inc. v. ScentAir Techs., Inc., 807 F.3d 1353; Synopsys, Inc. v. Mentor Graphics
Corp., 814 F.3d 1309; and Nike, Inc. v. Adidas AG, 812 F.3d 1326, and

[2] decision by Board to reject patentee's proposed amended claims without consideration of entirety of IPR record was
abuse of discretion.

Vacated and remanded.

Moore, Circuit Judge, filed concurring opinion in which Newman and O'Malley, Circuit Judges, joined.

Reyna, Circuit Judge, filed opinion concurring in part, in which Dyk, Circuit Judge, joined, and in which Prost, Chief
Judge, and Taranto, Chen, and Hughes, Circuit Judges, joined in part.

Taranto, Circuit Judge, filed opinion dissenting from the judgment, in which Prost, Chief Judge, and Chen and Hughes,
Circuit Judges, joined, and in which Dyk and Reyna, Circuit Judges, joined in part.

Hughes, Circuit Judge, filed opinion dissenting from the judgment, in which Chen, Circuit Judge, joined.

Opinion, 823 F.3d 1369, vacated.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cAqua Products, Inc. v. Matal, 872 F.3d 1290 (2017)
124 U.S.P.Q.2d 1257

"]

column1: Rapid Litigation Management Ltd v CellzDirect Inc
name_numbers: ['Rapid Litigation Management Ltd. v. CellzDirect, Inc., 827 F.3d 1042 (2016)']
author: [' Prost, Chief']
holding:
["s, Inc., in Vitro, Inc., Plaintiffs–Appellants

CELLZDIRECT, INC., a Delaware Corporation and wholly-owned Subsidiary,

Invitrogen Corporation, a Delaware Corporation, Defendants–Appellees.

v.

2015-1570

|

Decided: July 5, 2016

Synopsis
Background: Patentee brought infringement action against competitor and its parent, alleging infringement of patent
protecting several variants of claimed process for cryogenically freezing liver cells called hepatocytes. The United States
District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, Milton I. Shadur, Senior District Judge, 83 F.Supp.3d 774, granted
defendants' motion for summary judgment of patent invalidity. After the District Court supplemented its holding, 94
F.Supp.3d 940, patentee appealed.

Holdings: The Court of Appeals, Prost, Chief Judge, held that:

[1] patent claims were not directed to patent-ineligible concept, and

[2] claims improved existing technological process.

Vacated and remanded.

"]

column1: GPX Intern Tire Corp v US
name_numbers: ['GPX Intern. Tire Corp. v. U.S., 678 F.3d 1308 (2012)']
author: [' Dyk, Circuit']
holding:
['s: The Court of Appeals, Dyk, Circuit Judge, held that:

[1]  countervailing  duty  statute  prior  to  enactment  of  new  legislation  did  not  impose  restriction  on  imposition  of
countervailing duties by Department of Commerce on goods imported by Nonmarket Economy (NME) countries to
account for double counting;

[2] retroactive legislative amendment was not unconstitutional on basis that referenced and applied to particular case; and

[3]  issue  of  whether  retroactive  legislative  amendment  had  created  situation  in  which  both  antidumping  and
countervailing duties could be imposed in particular case, without providing mechanism to account for potential double
counting, had to be considered by United States Court of International Trade in first instance.

Petition granted and remanded.

 © 2018 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

1

\x0cGPX Intern. Tire Corp. v. U.S., 678 F.3d 1308 (2012)
34 ITRD 1138

']

["..., 865 F.3d 1348 (2017)
